comment: many people are pore because they are stupid, make bad decisions, and among other things they don't have integrity but don't confuse that word with false pride. most rich people i know work harder than anyone els but also smarter, many work 16+ hours a day. this Asian concept of rich is misleading and if you believe this premise you will be the same. i have seen many rich and ultra rich people loose it all through war or other cataclysmic event. it dos not take long the go right back to the top starting from the absolute bottom with nothing. those are the people you need to observe if you want to succeed. they are friendly appreciate hard work and WILL help anyone who puts in the effort they don't see colour, how much you have or who's family you belong too. the rich people in this movie are not the norm. and they are not what they seem either. plus there wealth may just be transitory only to disappear in the obscurity with one bad gamble, stupid family member or economic change.  these are communistic ideas of what successful people are designed to keep you poor. they are bait, the gatekeepers of sorts that hold people back.

comment: In a fair and level transaction, neither are parasites, both receive something positive in the end. When a part of the transaction has to be withdrawn to support inefficient state policies and projects, the real parasite of today's society appears, the enormous state burden. If we try to regulate and tax more to try to balance the equation, we are actually creating more and more jobs for bureaucrats while the problems are made even worse. I believe that state spending should be somewhere around 15%, not the exorbitant numbers we have today. And all this with promises of a better world. Better for whom?

You can escape it by not caring about how others judge your status. You should be able to know what things makes you a better person.

For example morality>wealth. As long as you're not compromising your moral values you should be sure that you're living high value life even if you're poor.

Be so much confident in your meaning of life that others can't dictate what your life should be like and they become confused and forced to rethink about their lives.

comment:
parasite is a very well written movie It talks about power, greed and hope,it says that how humans are capitalist by nature, That a person only thinks about himself that when a poor family has power, they will not help other poor but will only think about themselves, There is a power hierarchy in the society and the one who has more power, he considers the one with less power as a filth. This film talk about privilege also that a higher class person gets everything but a lower class person has to work 10 times more to get that, Everything in this film was well balanced there is no villain in this film the real villain is the situation
Yes bong didn't give any reason for "all or nothing" but that's the whole point that's why it feels surprising,The murder of Mar Park by Mar kim was a very psychological act,The murder of Mar Park by Mar Kim is very surprising and to understand it, you need to understand the psychology of Mar Kim.
Kim never wanted to kill Park, it was the situation that led to this act,Jealousy and anger have already boiled over in Kim's mind against Park,And it's shown in a very subtle way,He used to respect the park a lot, but later he came to know that he just thinks of him as a worker who stinks alot This thing was deeply disturbing to Kim inside,A big truth was already revealed in front of Kim(secret bunker),And right after that he heard Mr. Park say about himself that he stinks, and later her whole house got washed away by the rain all trouble came upon him in one night Still, he has to go to work in the morning, where the Park family is about to enjoy a birthday party But still the park treats him like a worker wo stinks they are completely unaware of his problem,Even when geun se killed Kim's daughter, Park was only thinking about his son and he should logically think about his son first But Kim felt bad for this work of Park because of his hatred, when Park shrunk his nose to avoid the smell, then Kim felt worse,in that situation, his suppressed hatred and jealousy came out in the form of anger, which led to the murder of the park.Kim had no Big reason to kill Park and he never want to kill mr Park it just happened to him like a DREAM a BAD DREAM And he got punished for this because he did wrong he had to leave his family and stay in the bunker and later he also apologized to the park, but now nothing is going to happen with this apology, crime was already committed now he will have to atone for it ,this shows the jealousy and hatred of the lower class against the higher class, And the movie never justifies Kim's crime,Kim was not a psycho killer, he was a normal person, he committed this crime, which he regrets, but now nothing is going to happen by regretting,In the last, a conversation between a father and son is shown which is very emotional, a son will never consider his father a criminal He also knows that my father is not such a person, but nothing can happen now,In the end, the film ends on Hope, despite all this, ki woo never stops hoping,I don't know whether he will be able to get that house or not, but God bless him to buy such a house so that when it rains next time, he can enjoy it with his family like mr park does.
Both families were not parasite in this film the real parasite was human greed,hatred, jealousy and situation
author: G Chudasama Darshit

comment: The use of lines and stairs in this movie is used heavily. Certain characters stand away, below, or above others and you know who's in power during those conversations. When the family escape the house to run back and find their apartment flooded, they go down endless staircases. They go deep below the ground while the Parks are high above the downpour. It's a show not tell moment in the film that speaks volumes. Also worth noting is at the exact middle of the movie is when the genre changes.

comment: It's easy to criticize the combination of western capitalism and democracy. But they are not to be frowned upon. As imperfect as they are, it is the best way of living we have found so far. I think Bong Joon-ho did a great job of portraying the ambivalent imperfection, but this video essay reads it a bit more from the left that i think he intended it be viewed. I think what makes it masterful is precisely that when its all over is hard to side with a particular family. And therefore a particular ideology

comment: I didn't see the message that the "rich family" were parasites at all. Throughout the movie the guy is shown to be a ceo, apparently competent and conscentious, while the wife is tone deaf but otherwise good spirited. What i got was that the dad in the "poor family" couldn't tolerate the polite, but obvious, despise that the rich guy - not even his wife, that as a i said was barely a little tone deaf - had towards him. The constant hints about not passing "the limit", the smell, the request to partecipate in the son's birthday only to "remind" him that it was work, etc. That, imho, is also the only way it justify such a final violent reaction. IT is not some imaginary revenge of the workers, it is a man that felt angry and humiliated, asked to abandon his dying daughter to help once again the rich guy, just because he is being payed. And yeah, of course it is more nuanced than that but we are talking about an emotional reaction.

comment:
My take away from this movie is that desperation from people will give them the motivation to kill you and sleep in your house. Anti Capitalist when you're poor but Capitalist when you're rich. I think this movie's message was that everyone is a hypocrite through and through, that no matter where you are, a narrative where you are the asshole exists. The parks were elitist snobs that didn't give a shit about the people around them except for what service they could provide for the parks. But the Kim's were also lying, manipulative rats that also didn't give a shit about the people around them except for the money they could get from them.

And one last thing about the kims, they didn't even consider for a second to help the other family that had it worse than them. Another metaphor to how people are only morally righteous when it benefits them.

comment:
This movie reflect the harsh reality and mostly in develop country like Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippine, India, etc where the gap between the poor and rich are so massive.
Most of the poor people literally live like this and some are even worse than the house in the movie. This is a sad reality and it‚Äôs really almost Impossible to escape from this cycle.
There is one article that during the pandemic in Jakarta that there are more than 3 families living in a small house and they have to rotate the hours to sleep. So one need to work at day and another need to work at night.
How is it possible that one person only earn $300 per month while other can earn more than $10k a week? It‚Äôs almost impossible to catch and this is why most of this people really believe that the only way is for God to help them.
As For people that live in a country like Australia, Korea, Japan, US, and Europe, we got a better chance to escape from the poor cycle to become the middle class and maybe some can go to upper class because of the education, etc however some of the middle class took it for granted like spending money for lifestyle and still complaining about how is the rich got away so easily. The tax system also make the middle class harder to go up to the next level
author: Hype Beastreet

comment:
Something I find spooky about the ideas this film presents is how there isn‚Äôt really an actionable solution at the moment. I realize this is obvious, but to elaborate, I‚Äôm of the opinion that one must only control what they can actually control or they‚Äôll become depressed. That being said, what can an individual do? What can an individual control? I‚Äôd like to hit a six figure income and find good organizations to donate to while living a good life and following my own ambitions, but who do you give to? What if one organization is a front for another corporate and/or political giant? What if you give your money to someone that pisses it away? Is there a way to get it to individuals who deserve it? Does everyone deserve it? How is that quantified? Who deserves to pick who deserves it?

Furthermore, what can we change in our society without activating a different yet equally flawed and disfigured ideology? Regardless of which you pick, how can you keep them safe from the greedy and corrupt that have historically ruined all of them? Is it a fundamental problem of ideology? Are we doomed to be taken advantage of by corrupt people no matter the social structure?

I suppose this has devolved into worry wort rambling, but I do find myself pondering these questions and in a struggle to come up with a good answer.

comment:
Reaganomics or Siphon Economics, which I like to call it, is NOT real Capitalism! To use an analogy, if Siphon Economics was a car. Then people arguing for it would say things like: If we just take more fuel out of the car. The car will go further and faster. Which any simpleton would understand was a false statement, but switch it to something they dont understand, aka macro economics, and they will be fooled.

This movie isnt anti capitalism. It is anti siphon economics. It is anti badly regulated capitalism.
Capitalism is not about "greed" or "poverty", but it is about efficiency via fiat currency (money). How do you create a product with the least amount of input (raw materials, labor, power, transport etc). The measurement in this context for success is the bottom line because everything mentioned uses fiat currency to to pay for. The more money you make, the more efficient you are. However the negatives is that the more suksessfull you are, the more your out compete others. This creates less competition and in turn can also lead to lower quality products again, but it also creates wealth and leverage concentrations which in turn can damage the middle class and shrink it.

What keeps capitalism alive? Money? LoL, no. It is DEMAND. Who creates the most demand in a society? The middle class. You remove the middle class or shrink it. You will, adjusted for inflation, reduce the size of your nations economy over time unless it is just a low bar raw material export nation. In short, pushing policies that damages the middle class is bad for capitalism. Not taxes the most successful allot is bad for capitalism. Not splitting up "to big to fail" type companies (anti trust laws) is bad for capitalism. Too little or unenforced regulation is bad for capitalism.

Reaganomics, aka Siphon economics, are against any type of policies that would change capitalism to a better version that is also sustainable in the future. Reaganomics focus more on individual companies bottom line, they should get everything they want, at the cost of the nation, its citizens and global demand level. Which long term will LOWER economic activity, because in reality it is just siphoning wealth from the treasury (lower taxes, no corporate responsibility, offsetting costs of labor, environment and so on onto the government) and citizens (anti union or any other form of leverage, against worker rights and so on) in the name of short term profits. Because their actions lower the amount of people that can buy stuff and retain demand over time.

comment:
Seeing yourself as an ant in their system is exactly how the elite (not regular rich people) want you to feel. Abortion was created by them to reduce the population of "ants". Our food is poisoned, we are surrounded by so many chemicals. And all for what? To reduce our numbers.

The real answer is to create our own parallel society and abandon their way of living. This isnt easy and requires mass adoption from people of all backgrounds and expertise, but it would work. Starting local is probably the best idea. Then communities could become self governing councils sovereign from the current top down system that exists.

There are more "ants" than them. If we all stopped paying taxes, and following their system, we could end it. Thats if a large enough group of people commit to it however.

comment:
It's not as to whether the system will work or not, but can you handle the resistance and extra uncertainties?

Said group can't handle the unfairness of x system. You now modify the system to make it more advantageous to said group. Now you have a bunch of people on the other side with fire in their eyes.
You deny their existence and now they're in danger, so they sabotage everything, living everyone miserable as the secretly rebuild their status behind the scenes and once more, become the rulers.

It's never wise to piss off the people at the top as a society unless you're willing to deal with the hatred they're willing to use to distort everything.
I've seen it multiple times in history, x community wants freedom, x lords are mad and want revenge, take all of the moneys with them, and secretly fund warlords.

author: tamale

comment:
I enjoyed this video, but you're wrong about the desire for pale skin being linked to Eurocentrism. I don't understand why so many westerners think this, when Asians will tell you that it has to do with the working class vs the wealthy. That's always been the reason, it didn't require influence from other countries. The wealthy got to stay inside and out of the harsh sun, while the working class were exposed to the harsh sun while in the fields... and this is still the case today in many counties.

In the west you can find the opposite: people will get a tan (real, spray, bronzing lotion, etc) to make themselves look like they're well off and taking vacations to sunny beaches.

To be clear, I don't care how someone wants to present themselves. It's just tiresome to see westerners constantly blaming Asia's pale skin trend on Europe.

comment: The conclusion of this video is stupid as it does not account for the risks taken by the wealthy in order to remain wealthy. What does a poor person have to lose? absolutely nothing. What does a wealthy person have to lose? almost everything. who risks more? a person who has sunk in millions of dollars to make things work and provide employment to the unemployed and make their labour productiveor a random labourer who has no money to lose and everything to gain from the job provided. The pretext that rich people just 'have' money in nonsense, someone worked for it, it was not just given to them. Their fathers grandfathers or other ancestors passed their wealth to the now rich person or organisation. This is a major fault in the socialistic ideology that under capitalism some people just get given money for doing nothing and some start with absolutely nothing is stupid af.

author: Crash Bandicoot

comment:
This film is less a class critique than it is a subversive parody of the heist trope.

There is no consideration of the Parks at the end because, like a bank or art gallery, they exist to serve as a foil for the protaganists' whacky exploits.

There is certainly aesthetic contrast between the 'elevated' life and the 'subterranean' life, but this is to serve the parody.

As for it's creator's claim that the rich are parasites as well, I submit that he is trolling us -- that this is part of the parody. (After all, it depicts the Kim's as hiding like cockroaches under the furniture. And it portrays the anodyne Park family as ... having an evilly overactive olfactory sense? That's parody gold!)

Let the flaming commence! :)

comment:
Thank you for making Korean subtitles. I really didn't know... Through your video, I realized that parasites are not just about Kiwoo's family.

I was also poor, so I sympathized with the Kiwoo family while watching this movie.A year before I watched this movie, I also took care of rich children. The rich families were very kind and gave a lot of money. The house was big and there was a housekeeper. At that time, I always put a lot of perfume on myself before I went to work. I don't think they'll hire me anymore if I smell poor, but I think it was the pride I could do. I was embarrassed because I was like me after watching this movie a year later.

I also felt the pain of the livestock that we eat deliciously after seeing your review. I don't see their pain in front of me, but the pain of a mother cow in a glass of milk. I don't eat meat, but I eat milk. Now I have to cut down on milk. I'm going to eat Almond Breeze.

author: Daniel Jaramillo

comment:
It seems like the poor family should be able to afford some place nicer given that they are all employed by the rich family. Even if they all have low wage jobs, like working at fast food, it should be enough for a reasonable apartment if they pool their money. If they can con their way to work for the rich family, I don't see how they would have problem finding low wage jobs. I don't see any big issue, like health problems, addictions, high debt, mental problems, etc. It's an interesting story, but it's distorted from reality, or at least an exaggeration. I mean, this is S. Korea, a relatively rich country with inequality (at least from using Gini coefficient) that is less of an issue than US and UK.

Also, "leeching" or being a "parasite" seems like a very negative way of thinking about it. The rich family and the poor family are in a somewhat mutually beneficial situation (minus the ending where the rich dad and poor daughter were murdered). That's the point of capitalism, you pay for service and the business gets a small profit, win-win situations. The possible "leeching" parts, perhaps, are the rich wife doesn't do anything even though she's not employed, or the two unqualified tutors that are not really helping the rich kids. Even then, it's not a critique to the rich or the poor in general but these two families specifically. The rich mom could have done more research and hire people who are actually qualified.

comment: So what is anyone doing about it then? Doesn't that make us responsible as well? And make it make sense, I'm considered poor in my country (our housing situation isn't the best, we've lived with visible black mold for about 15 yrs and can't afford this month's $145 rent raise, let alone move, but we have shelter and I'm very grateful for that, don't get me wrong, just need a comparison), yet I'm considered rich in my parent's homeland where my mother and her siblings ate out of garbage bins and knocked on people's doors for food scraps, and many times received spoiled or rotten food that they'd still have no choice but eat sometimes. Yet, here I am giving you a view, a comment, my time, so that you can live a better life. So, this was cool and all, but do you or anyone really have an answer? And what companies or policies should we support? I don't particularly buy from big corps like Apple, Walmart, Amazon, etc. but what about gas (Shell, AMCO, etc.) so that my parents can get to their jobs? It's not that easy my friend, though I really wish it were. Anyway, please don't mistake my questioning for complacency or bitterness, though there is a touch of desperation and sadness, but I'm just not wise enough to figure it out.

author: seigne

comment:
Love this, I also wanted to point out that the whitening skin phenomenon can also be traced to class/stratum and not just eurocentric ideas of beauty (although eurocentric ideas of beauty now play a role). In many places in Southeast Asia at least, where I live, it's a legacy from medieval times where if you were pale or "white" you were most likely of the upper class such as the nobility or royalty. If you were darker-skinned, you were most likely of the lower class since you worked outside under the sun such as farmers, fishermen, etc. Because of this, the beauty standard became such that people aspired to appear like the upper class.

Also at least in Indonesia, the word "white" in the many different languages here refer to "pale" in terms of skin color. But when you literally translate the word to English, it's "white". This word refers to the color as how people understood it during pre-colonial times. When the white-skinned (i.e. European) colonizers came, the meaning of those words shifted, but because the literal word preceded a colonial understanding of skin color, the word remained.

comment: This is a movie. Numerous, numerous people from communist countries have gained significant amounts of wealth as a result of capitalism and pulled themselves out of poverty. This is really.  The benefit that the Parks provide doesn‚Äôt just benefit the Parks, it benefits the people they pay. If they do not like the wages, they can negotiate for more or leave. If enough people are not satisfied with the wages and the Parks want a certain quality of service, they will raise wages. This video is a kindergarten level understanding of capitalism no doubt indoctrinated by a university in which professors applaud a system where wealth is distributed involuntarily. Involuntarily as I‚Äôm at the point of a gun or threat of prison. We are born into a dangerous world where survival is hard, but that is no excuse to take other people‚Äôs property against their will. Capitalism is consent. That‚Äôs all. You get what you can negotiate.

comment:
The criticisms in Parasite are much almost identical to those the Korean satire ‚ÄúYangban ch≈èn‚Äù (‚ÄúTale of a Yangban‚Äù) written during the later Chosun Dynasty. Parasite doesn't represent capitalism. The story in Parasite represents Korea''s Neo-Confucianism and traditional Korean social structure. These systems and their criticism predate both the Enlightenment and Capitalism and one could easily write Parasite as a portrayal of north Korean society and economy, given their reversion to Neo-Confucianism under the banner of KimIlSungism and their centralized economic control. That being the case, I think it is a reach to apply an interpretation of Parasite to Neo-Capitalism.
Those failing morals in Parasite that push the story through to the end are ignorance and greed.

author: Ben10

comment:
This is an extremely delusional analysis. Moral ambiguity was not a significant characteristic of Parasite. I‚Äôm not sure what Bong-Joon-ho‚Äôs allegorical intentions were with the film but regardless, his movie does not succeed at painting the Parks (or capitalism) as any sort of villain, or presenting the poor families as victims. In fact it does the opposite.

Objectively, the Parks never actually do anything wrong. 1) They never actually know the poor family is poor (because they are impersonating middle/upper class workers), even up till the end of the movie when it is explicitly said that Yeon-kyo, the wife, didn‚Äôt understand why her driver killed her husband. This is relevant because it means their remarks about foul smells and boundaries, is not manifestation of class-based prejudice or superiority complex, but a professional expectation. Keep this fact in mind for my next points. 2) The parasite metaphor is inappropriate to describe the Parks. They apparently pay the family very well for their work as Min explicitly states to Ki-woo near the start‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt actually think of a single wrong thing the Parks do that cannot be truly explained as mischaracterizations potentially borne from the prejudice and resentment.

The poor family on the other hand have no shortage of guilt. 1) Ki-woo‚Äôs initial crime of forgery/fraud could be excused since it was masterminded by his friend, but he then assists his entire family to conspire and commit multiple acts of slander and fraud and even man slaughter. 2) The stone given to Ki-Woo by Min at the start is expensive as the director himself has stated. Rather than sell this stone or otherwise monetize it for income, Ki-Woo sees fit to use it as a murder weapon. 3) Kim Ki-take has no reason to be resentful of Yeon-kyo for her remarks about the rain being a blessing, she had no idea, nor could she ever have imagined that he and his family were suffering as a direct result. Besides, if the poor family had been at home eating their own food, bought with the money they now certainly had, rather than stealing food and alcohol from the Parks, they would apparently have saved their home from flooding. 4) The flooding of their home was also their fault, the had left the window open before and had had multiple warnings in the form of the drunk man to close their window. 5) Kim Ki-taek cannot hold against the Parks what they say in the privacy of their own home, without the knowledge they were being surveilled by (essentially) home invaders. 6) my final point is that Kim Ki-take shows no proactivity in ensuring that he as a husband and father provides for his family, the pizza box job is found by his wife, the Park jobs are sought out by his son and all the while he plays a passive role in seeking financial opportunities for his family, yet he has the audacity to fee emasculated/oppressed by another man‚Äôs comfort‚Ä¶

In light of these narrative details and more, it‚Äôs absurd that one would try to paint the main poor family as victims. While their circumstances are very sympathetic and unfortunate in many moments, they are also demonstrably covetous, reckless and criminally opportunistic. The movie taken on it‚Äôs own, does not by any stretch paint a morally ambiguous picture. (I purposely left the poor ex-maid couple out of my critique because their arc is a bit tangential to the main character‚Äôs)

comment: Less to do with class and more to do with the worst of the human condition. Never once felt an ounce of empathy for the Parks. At every opportunity they lied, cheated, steal, manipulated, framed others to only meet their base wants NOT needs. Look at something as simple as the Parks work ethic. They couldnt even fold pizza boxes right. Its BS lie that no one has a chance at upward mobility. Inequality is part of life and and every facet of the animal kingdom. The struggle of the human condition is to over come whatever obstacles come at you because what is the alternative. The Parks are worthy of contempt because every move is done out of selfishness. Even the son went downstairs to try to kill the people downstairs in the basement to continue the charade but he dropped the rock. Tired of the class warfare BS comparisons. This has way more to do the ugliness of human envy, of covetousness and pride. Its a classic example why people are inherently bad, not good.

author: Peter Xiao

comment:
This is a shallow assessment of the film that conveniently overlooks how the family regularly chooses to have a terrible life by blindly trusting their father, who is a terrible, awfully misguided person. They have a tight-knit family, but their leader drives them right off a cliff. The beginning has us pitying them for their unfortunate, seemingly desperate situation. By the end of the film, we realize that they've been doing it to themselves the entire time.

This movie is not a critique of capitalism. It's set up to feel that way in the beginning, and by the end, after all characters are fleshed out, we see where the real critique is. It's a critique of the ever popular "capitalism bad" attitude, and it paints an image of a situation where strong family values don't mean much when your family is a bunch of spiteful, lazy scavengers.

author: Pol Tergeist

comment:
I think it‚Äôs just a good example of the horrors of extreme capitalism. As with extremities of anything. There are a lot of benefits to capitalism. Just like anything, moderation and balance. To over regulate a society to the nth degree as holding supreme equality as the highest virtue is how you end up with North Koreas and Soviet Russias‚Äîagain, another extremity.

I‚Äôve been a private tutor for 11 years. I‚Äôve worked with wealthy families just like this. They are often quite nice, but you do feel like hired labor at times. At the same time, many of those families I‚Äôve worked for were at some point of low or middle class. And at the same time I‚Äôm very grateful to live in a free market society where I can having a tutoring company and work as I please on my terms and it‚Äôs proved not only financially successful for me, but very fulfilling work.

It‚Äôs important to realize though based in fact, parasite is a movie. It‚Äôs meant to drive home a point and theory through very intricate and designed story telling‚Äîwhich it does so beautifully. But it‚Äôs still fiction.

Exploitation certainly exists. But so do good people and the fruits of labor. The truth is, we aren‚Äôt all born with equal opportunity‚Äîthat‚Äôs just not how nature works. Not everyone is a Mufasa or a Michael Phelps. While at the same time, we‚Äôre not all ineffectual and worthless‚Äîwe all have an inner strength that we can and ought to make the most of.

comment:
A sweat shop is only a problem if the workers are forced to work there. If no one is forcing them to work there and they can choose to work somewhere else or go farm, etc. then I don't see the problem.

Most of us choose to go to work or not work or study or not study. Let's say one person chooses to learn about plumbing and another chooses to learn women's lib. The trained plumber gets a job as a plumber and makes $65k a year. The women's lib major graduates and gets a job making $26k a year. Over time those two people could end up with very different levels of wealth. Do you blame the plumber? Do you blame the system? Choices have consequences. A doctor makes more money than an engineer in most cases. Why? It's harder to become a doctor and it requires more years of study. That's not anyone's fault. We all make choices like what to study or learn and those choices will often dictate long term wealth.

author: Elohel

comment:
Ah yes, watching capitalism sucks videos on Youtube, by far the greatest compendium of information ever compiled. Made possible only by capitalism, the system that pays people according to their contribution. Instead of asking that people contribute according to their ability, like marxism.

You can whine all you want about our version of capitalism and it's many flaws, but I went from a hopeless college dropout to starting and owning a small business under this system.

And as for this insane divisive promotion of classism - it's bullshit. I have lots of customers ranging from so poor that they have to call friends to get enough money for me to make their car drivable again, to people with collections of antique cars. And I can tell you that there is no correlation at all between social status and moral worth. Poor people are not more noble than the rich. Of course inequality is vast, and it would be nice if there weren't so much of it. But recognizing that is not the same as pushing the violent narrative that the rich are the cause of all the world's problems. That kind of thinking - that one group of people is somehow below everyone else - is how you get the massacre of the massacre of the kulaks, the cultural revolution, the holocaust, the genocide of the tutsis, etc. Feel free to debate me.

comment:
I enjoyed this video, but I feel like you‚Äôre forgetting a major component about your situation that should have been discussed.

To speak badly about the state of society is a privilege. Most people are just surviving. The average family of 5 has dad making $1000 a month worldwide. For most people, capitalism is not a question, it‚Äôs existence. Everyone at the bottom is hungry to get at the top. But when most westerns, living a comfortable life, think about that, they think pity those poor people. But what westerners really should be thinking about is fear. All westerners need to confront their fear about poorness.

Because you see, we are all complicit in making capitalism work. Almost every human alive. The average worldwide family makes 1k a year. Do you want to make $10,000 a year? You cannot say you disagree with capitalism if you don‚Äôt say yes to this. Some people might not know how far 10k gets you. Check Brazil out. The truth is, the moment you have more, the moment you will never want to give it up. So your answer is almost certainly yes. That makes you complicit. Welcome to the 99%.

Then we can agree that capitalism is a natural state of being. There is no world where western living becomes the norm in the next 100 years. It‚Äôs only if everyone is comfortable with giving up material wealth like Jesus that we can come to some semblance of communism. But that will never happen as long as people want more over others.

The truth is is that the best we can do is push for more socialist policies as capitalism grows. It‚Äôs easy to try to DISMANTLE capitalism, but it‚Äôs hard to actually BUILD a different kind of society, which is what I wish a lot of more people wisened up on. It‚Äôs so normalized to get angry over systems without understanding the system in a 360 lens, not just what you hate about it. Hate leads nowhere.

Lastly, the reason why I brought this up is because I feel like talking badly about capitalism without disclaiming you come from the upper end of capitalism makes you disingenuous. I love your videos, but I‚Äôd appreciate if you showed more humility yknow? Joshster out.
author: Josh

comment: Interesting film. But this doesn‚Äôt change the fact that it does not matter where you came from. You can live your dream life. Cause and effect are real. Follow the principles necessary to achieve your goals and you will be successful. One does not become wealthy. One first becomes a certain type of person and then wealth is a product of that change. Not the other way around. There‚Äôs a reason the wealthy separate them selves. Because they observed this fact and acted on it while others either did not see it or did not act. Either way this creates a major disconnect because the poor won‚Äôt ever be able to understand why you do what you do unless they themselves switch their mindset. These films always show rich wealthy people just living life. Never show the story of how they got the money. Because believe it or not majority of millionaires are self made. Meaning they did not receive an inheritance. And the story of how they got it will show you everything you need to know about why they separate themself from the poor.

author: Kombat1271

comment:
Wow, unbelievable! is that what you gleaned from the movie? capitalism is bad?? Let me tell you something, this pattern of few rich and many poor has occurred many many times in history (under different regimes) and it will continue to happen (even under socialism, please don't be so naive to map pattern only to the current regime). Any new system you invent will still have motivated individuals with high productivity vs lower productivity, the highly motivated highly productive individuals will find new ways to rise to the top. The thing is, this is just as natural as anything else in the universe, it follows power-laws.

My father was a poor worker just like the ones you speak about, he however, worked hard and put me through school and saved up money for my higher education because he didn't want me to be like him, he succeeded, he is the best dad in the world for me, I'll always be grateful to him and his sacrifices. The point I'm trying to make is, in America, familial connections or sacrifice for family member is unheard of, their value system is so hollow that they have to find something external to blame for their predicament.

All of these rich-poor arrangements are exactly the same, they peak and break down and a new one will take its place. I wouldn't trust anyone who is rooting for the new arrangement, because they clearly stand to benefit and come out on top, they will be or aspire to be the new rich/high-status class.

author: Gauransh Sharma

comment:
Mmm - I was born into a family of modest means who worked hard to put me through uni (mainly, though we took out loans, too). I, too, worked hard, saved and am now a ¬£ multi-millionaire even though I've only been an engineer throughout my career. So....
1) the system does promote privilege and wealth through inheritance and old-boys networks but 2) if we work hard, don't squander what we earn, invest for our senior years we can end up with good wealth (I certainly don't need more at 60) but 3) if I'd be born into a properly poor family - rather than one of modest means - I might really have struggled to have the support and learn from my family the ambition to do well.
At the end of the day, capitalism created your iphone and the yt channel and the low-cost airline you go on holiday with - they would never have happened without it. Socialism would make everyone except the state bureaucrats poor. So capitalism in a social democratic society that cares can make opportunity - ask the Scandinavians - and share wealth around better while make the wealth-makers wealthy, but not too wealthy too ('good' greed!).

This type of structure, grew out of the Great Depression, which brought the government more into our day-to-day lives.  A crisis is either created artificially or naturally occurring. The solution is to print money, create more programs, tax more people, regulate more industries and bail out poorly run businesses. Knowing this, to gain control of the people and instigate a structure that does not allow any person or group of people(corporation) to enter any field of the economy. All you need to do is control the government. Which is done through lobbying and typical corruption measures. Making the government a representative of the big corporation and not the citizens of the nation. Causing the weak to suffer and the rich to grow stronger.

All these people complaining here about companies... Where were your ancestors 100 years ago? Look where you are now because of the evolution brought to this world by big companies and markets. author: Niaz Shah

comment:
I feel like the people in the comments section are kind of misguided. Everyone‚Äôs being all pessimistic. Of course many of us in the comments section will never be apart of the 1 percent. Hell most of us won‚Äôt even be in the top 15 percent of wealth? But when was any of that ever a requirement to live a happy and fulfilling life? How many ludicrously wealthy and successful people have been found suicidal or found overdosed on drugs? Life is a game. But the main objective is not to have the biggest house, or the most accolades or the nicest car. Many people have reached those ‚Äúachievements‚Äù and they still don‚Äôt feel like they‚Äôve won the game. The main objective is to find honest, pure and genuine contentment. You find that and you can walk around like a bad-ass confident bitch anywhere you go.

What I liked about parasite (and this awesome video essay) was how versatile it is. As a middle class American, I always found it mind riveting how there were scenes where I related to the Kims, but conversely there were also parts where the bougie-ass family was more relatable. Nothing in this life is black and white. And it shouldn‚Äôt be seen in such a dire light 24/7.

We always pity those really destitute people on the margins. People in war torn countries living in UN assisted camps, people forced to work in sweatshops, homeless people who have no where to sit because park benches are spiky, children and mothers in developing nations who walk a mile for the nearest clean water. We, the privileged people on the Internet, who are sitting safely within a sheltered home with secure enough connection to even see this video, should also be ashamed of reflecting onto the people who are truly on the margins of society.

It‚Äôs such a typical first world thing to say ‚Äúoh poor homeless man‚Äù Or ‚Äúoh poor person in developing country, let me hastily donate eighty dollars to appease my conscience‚Äù...but if we were to actually come into contact with those on the real fringes of society and speak to them, they‚Äôd tell you they‚Äôre either content with their situation or that it‚Äôs not as bad as it seems. And they‚Äôre probably being honest. Think about it. If being ‚Äúpoor‚Äù (because wealth as a concept is relative) is all one ever knows they‚Äôre not gonna mind. Speaking from personal experience, my first few years of life were characterized by me living in a two bedroom apartment only a couple miles away from the US-Mexican border in southern Cali. The fire hydrant as a water park, clothes from Walmart, spaghetti almost every dinner, the Disney channel being a privilege at our more well-off relative‚Äôs house and eating at McDonald‚Äôs as special occasions were all I knew. But damn I was content because it was all I knew. And then my dad actually did get a promotion at work, my family relocated to the east and we lived a relatively stable life. Hell, I even went through tuition based Catholic schooling from the time I was in 1st grade all the way up til senior year. How‚Äôs that for upward mobility not being possible?

I just, I admire this video essay, but the defeatist and pessimistic attitude people have in the comments section is very frustrating. Life is not as rigid as we would like to believe it to be. It‚Äôs just not enough people (especially those in the middle) have enough gusto to work for it. Also, Im not a boomer, I‚Äôm Gen Z and I can see why older generations call us a whiny generation. Yes, the economy these days is way more complicated than what it was say 50 years ago....the job market is over saturated but it‚Äôs not a starkly unfair, or unyielding situation..we literally have the whole ass internet to serve as a walking living breathing business card for employers.

Sure, that main dude in parasite will probably never have enough in his lifetime to afford the Park house? But why look at the situation that way? I think the movie ends on an optimistic note regardless. Because even if he‚Äôll never buy the house, by the end of the movie he‚Äôs in a much better position then he was at the beginning. He has a goal...to work and improve his situation. It won‚Äôt be a lavish, beautiful house but what I love about the ending is that you can interpret as you want.

Even during the scene where he‚Äôs talking to his dad in the gymnasium. Its been a year since I last saw it but there‚Äôs a scene where he tells his dad how he wants to do better. He wants to work hard (and i think he even mentions going back to school?) Both of the families were bad in their own way. Just because they were on the fringes of society, that didn‚Äôt excuse their continual exploitation of the wealthy family. And of course nothing excused the rich family‚Äôs treatment towards the poor family.
We shouldn‚Äôt under scrutinize people because they‚Äôre poor, we shouldn‚Äôt over scrutinize people because they‚Äôre rich. Classism is classism no matter how it manifests.

It‚Äôs reality. A poor person can improve their situation. can a homeless man on the street become the next Jeff bezos in the same lifetime? No. But whose to say he even wants to be as wealthy as Jeff bezos. To him just living in an apartment with running water is lavish enough for him. Yes, most of us in this comment section will never be in the 1 percent. But by prioritizing that goal, aren‚Äôt we just perpetuating the same game capitalism aims to set?

Here‚Äôs my interpretation of the ending...the protagonist goes back to school, gets a job, saves enough to bail out his dad, gets a decent house that can comfortably hold both his parents and himself. They don‚Äôt have to deal with fumigators treating them like pesticides anymore. Bingo bongo and that‚Äôs on the capitalist dream. Upward economic mobility is still a very real possibility. Its just not as needed for most people who can sit comfortably behind a computer screen all day.

In fact, I‚Äôd even wager that the reason we see Ki-woo buying the house at the end was to help us the audience relate to Ki-woo‚Äôs ambitions more. For us, the class of people who don‚Äôt need to work all day, we have the privilege of getting to watch film and critique it. And i bet the director or whoever put the scene in knew a majority of the audience would be middle class. If im correct, I don‚Äôt even think Ki-woo states that he wants to buy the house, his main ambition is to simply make enough to save his dad and improve his situation. But they paired it with the visual imagery of him getting the bougie house because it‚Äôd connect more with the mainstream audience, us,,,the middle class. Because a majority of the viewers would be elated to get sweet digs like that. We‚Äôd be as elated as Ki-woo would be to both simply just leave the flooded parasite den and rescue his father. Emphasis on simply leaving. He doesn‚Äôt want to be the next Park family. My interpretation is he simply wants to improve rather than be a parasite the rest of his life. Because upward mobility, no matter how small or grand, is still and always is possible. :)

comment:
@9:40 Im sorry but this 'eurocentric beauty standards' is bullshit.
Look how beauty standards in Asia has been the same for millennia: it is white pure pristine. Why? "Because only poor people work outside on the land in the sun all day". In contrast, in modern age Europe it isnt being white: "Only poor people have to work all day. Only rich affluent people can afford to be travelling and getting a tan from the sun".

Also, in the Middle Ages, being fat was considered attractive. Because you had the means (money or influence) to get your belly round, unlike the peasants and serfs on the land. It is always about looking healthy.

Modern fashion does whatever, because scrawny women surely are not attractive, and neither are obese. Simply because it is not healthy.

comment: Parasite, which arrived between Green Book and Nomadland, won the Oscar for best picture and the Oscar for best foreign film, which might be a once in a lifetime occurrence. It is a sign of social recognition (at least from an American viewpoint), if not social change. Although a South Korean film, Parasite has a setting and a situation that seem more American than America itself. That is, until you know America better. It could be an indictment of "The American Way". By sheer coincidence, Green Book and Parasite and Nomadland form a thematic trilogy, as they represent the past, the present, and the future of the United States, of life in the dark underbelly of a "first world" country that is a "leader" of "the free world". For a cinema ticket the truth will out.
author: Rick Riffel

comment:
I hate to disagree because this is such a good analysis, but after following Apple for many years (reading biographies, watching interviews etc) and being a design a design student, I think society portrays Apple in a non-accurate way.

Whilst I have never spent a second inside a manufacture plant where Apple products are produced, I have read annual reports that show that:
- environmental standards
- social atmosphere
- income
- health and safety
Is all improving in these factories.

I don‚Äôt care which brand people prefer, but one of the reasons why Windows and Android products are cheaper than Apple is the lack of investment in the above.

Also, Apple owns 1 factory in Texas. That‚Äôs it.

It is the responsibility of the manufacturers to meet the standards of their law.

comment: The truth is this: We humans are imperfect creatures, if you ever delude yourself into thinking that some people are evil while you're the good one just pause. For 100,000 years we were nomads fighting nature and animals, hunting and gathering food with no assurance of survival, life was a misery for most of the time, then we lived 6,000 years as farmers working in the fields for a King, Pharaoh, Nobleman etc, 95% of everyone were dirt poor making the Kims look like royalties. The cruel irony of the last hundred years is that capitalism lifted millions out of these dirt poor conditions others today still live in, and it did all of this while still being an inhuman cruel system. No country has ever prospered without capitalism. No society has ever succeeded that didn't have classes. We know capitalism is a destructive force but so is socialism, whether you're Gramsci, Marx or Horkhimer, or if you're Smith, Marshall or Friedman your vision of the world always fails. No Smith, capitalism won't solve suffering... No Gramsci communist revolution won't solve suffering either cause all of these solutions have a common denominator, humans, and there's the issue. We haven't changed in our biological source code for tens of thousands of years, in our brains we're still nomads fighting for food, that's why obesity exists, it's a perfect example of how our civilisations outrun our own nature as humans. I guess I've outed myself as a pessimist, but I have faith in that technology can solve problems for real. Remember this: Whatever new social system you think will save the world, this system will never enough suppress our natural human faults.

comment:
as a korean film it also thumbs its nose at the japanese!

they selected an actor for the servant dad who looks very japanese, and they have him liking german cars!

also where the other guy bangs his head on the light switches saying "respect",
I think the film is thumbing its nose at the japanese custom of bowing to everyone all the time.

by likening that bowing to banging your forehead on light switches for your boss to drably ascend the stairs.

some parts of the film are korean specific cultural references, whereas others are general references.

that headbanging guy I think was chinese (it is some years since I watched the film, I think possibly they were taiwanese), and here also the koreans are bitching about the chinese,
and in one part the predecessor servant woman feigns being a north korean tv presenter,
this is a cultural reference to north korea.

and these bitchings are essentially divide and conquer, get each nation fearing and despising all other nations.

the rich dad says about his son getting interested in indian culture, and this in fact is red indian, where the son has a teepee, rather than the country of India. This also is misdirection, where they are brainwashing the koreans to associate the word "indian" with red indian, rather than India. This is divide and conquer to prevent koreans associating with India, historically Korea was part of Indochina, where it was a dominion of India. The koreans are partly indian, and their language also has indian words within it eg if you watch the video "mr simple" by "super junior",
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WKJykl7ez9A
you will hear the word dekho used many times, which in the indian languages means "look!", and relates to the english words decor and decorate.

the thais and cambodians also are partly indian. The origin of Thailand was that an indian prince married the local princess, and that is the origin of the thai royal family. With Bali, the language is derived from sanskrit, and the gurkha language also is similar to say hindi.
author: Wond Erful

comment:
@Gao Ai Bai
I replayed some of your link at 50% speed where I can compare the lyrics with the transliteration, at full speed it is too fast for someone who doesnt know korean. The truth is I dont know much about korea, but I have noticed similarities with indian things when watching korean films, which I dont see with say japanese things.

what I am referring to is before the islamic conquest of India, and that islamic conquest of India in fact originates from Genghis Khan, eg shah Jahan who created the Taj Mahal claimed to be descended from Genghis. He ruled from 1628 to 1658 and was the 5th emperor from the Mogul dynasty. I think "mogul" is probably an indian transliteration of mongol, sometimes also transliterated as mughal.

I am talking of conquests from much further back in time, eg there was hinduism in Cambodia, eg the Angkor Wat temple complex was "hindu", which was built 1113 to 1150AD.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angkor_Wat

it began as hindu and eventually was converted to buddhist.

The word "hindu" is itself an externally applied idea, in fact it is a spiritual culture and not a centrally controlled religion, which includes diverse beliefs and traditions, including non religious things such as medicine, astronomy, mathematics, surgery, etc.

There was also spiritual expansion from India, in particular buddhism which reached China and Japan. Before buddhism a lot of the far east was in continual war, whereas buddhism brought in a more peaceful attitude via concepts such as karma and also non injury (ahimsa) and united different nations via a common religion.

I think some of the indian conquest was peaceful via royals intermarrying, namely the legend you mention and the indian prince marrying a thai princess to found the modern thai royal family. The legend you mention sounds right, and would explain the similarities. Koreans arent just going to invent such a specific legend which also conforms with what was happening in other countries.

In europe also, there was expansion via royal marriage, where maybe they became allies rather than a conquest. eg Scotland got united with England via royal marriage, England was unable to defeat Scotland by war.

Modern history tends to be that broadcast by europe, especially England and Germany, but all that had to conform with the anglican and lutheran churches respectively, which said creation was 6000 years ago, and which will always dismiss any non christian accomplishments.

But with indian scriptures, they used an astronomical calender, and would give the date via the stars and planets, and because of the precession of the equinoxes, certain seasonal things gradually change with time, and indian scholars have been able to date scriptural references via the precession of the equinoces far further back than western historians give, where western history says nothing happened before some 6000 years ago.

the sanskrit language in particular is the most advanced human language ever, and is beyond the scope of most humans to speak,
the only people who can handle it adeptly are the brahmin priest caste of hinduism. Western scholars struggle with the language, and have to consult brahmins for whom the language is matter of fact.

And all the major languages of europe appear to be descended from sanskrit, including latin and greek.

Only languages such as hungarian + finnish, and basque are unrelated, hungarian + finnish + turkish are closely related and relate to Genghis Khan's mongol hordes, and are agglutinative languages (based on successive suffices) as are the red indian languages.
whereas sanskrit is vastly more sophisticated, similar to latin, but with much more structure than latin. Latin is a degenerated form of sanskrit.

europeans have then tried to deny this indian basis by looking for a PIE (proto indo european) language as a conjectured precursor for sanskrit, but there is no evidence for this conjecture EXCEPT sanskrit! Ultimately indus valley was THE original civilisation and the origin of sanskrit.

when the germans discovered that sanskrit was the root of even latin and greek, they became obsessed with sanskrit civilisation and began scouring India for everything relating to this, and did intense study, in particular the philosophy which ultimately led to german philosophy. All german academics would study the indian scriptures, eg the upanishads and gita. When Oppenheimer exploded the first atom bomb, he quoted from the hindu scriptures about "I am become the destroyer of worlds". To quote like that is only possible if he had done intense study.

this study of sanskrit led to huge progress in Germany, the germans studied sanskrit civilisation then developed the ideas in their own direction.

in fact the chinese martial arts originate from the shaolin buddhist temples, where the monks were being taught yoga poses to show the mastery of the mind over the body. The chinese then developed this static practice into a dynamic practice for self defence. If you watch martial arts people, you will see they meditate briefly in a static pose before an explosion of violence. All physical action begins in the mind, and the more nerves you utilise the more power and control you get.

There is ginormous progress now in India, and India is closer to europe than all the far eastern countries. But they are nearer the US, the rise of China is partly because it is next door to the US.

chinese exports tend to be by ship otherwise too expensive, and these take a long time. Ships will reach europe quicker from India than from China, but chinese ships will reach the US faster. The US is ultimately a smaller market than Europe, the US is some 360 million people, europe is more than 540 million, and that excludes Russia. the population of India was 1.336 billion in 2019, so is larger than the EU + US combined and will soon overtake China which was 1.398 in 2019.

India has 2 advantages over the far eastern countries: nearer the bigger market of europe, and a better command of english. Far eastern people generally struggle with english, and also each far eastern country has a tricky language to learn. I wanted to email Samsung once, and it was impossible, the only portal was in the korean script!

western history will deny India and China any importance because they are non christian societies, it is religious prejudice.

but historically India was at the centre of the old world, and there was major trade by ship from India both to the far east and to arabia and the east african coast. Europe in fact was backward because it was more isolated from India for ships. europe was civilised by the romans, who were civilised by the greeks, but there is a lot of evidence that the greeks were civilised by their study of indian civilisation.
Greece originally was violent, then they came in contact with India via Alexander, and now became civilised.


european mathematics has its origins in India, where the greeks of Alexander the great brought the wisdom to the library at Alexandria in Egypt, and eg the decimal number system was an indian invention, which reached europe via the arabs. Before that it was roman numerals eg MCMLXXXIV instead of 1984. The concept of algorithm was from an arab Al kwarizmi, which he developed after studying the works of indian mathematics, which had the precursors. european steelmaking also has its origins in India, where the finest steel was indian, and famous british physicist Michael Faraday was assigned to reverse engineer it. But he was unable to, and they had to eventually use espionage to find how the indians made it.

https://www.currentscience.ac.in/Volumes/113/09/1792.pdf

The ancient indians had a huge suite of surgical instruments, which needs quality steel, "surgical steel" and invented cataract surgery. Plastic surgery was another indian invention, where indians were doing nose transplants, and knew what herbs and oils to use to prevent the flesh getting infected. Europeans took the idea and renamed it with a latin name, rhinoplasty which makes it seem to be a european idea!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AIuKuYZ-bd8

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RGyjvyXEKdc&t=5351s

according to western history the oldest civilisations are Sumer and Indus, and Indus was far bigger than Sumer. Sumer is in the desert, but Indus was along a fertile river, where there was a conurbation civilisation stretching along a lot of the river. As well as other rivers such as saraswati.

both civilisations are older than ancient China. Historically all diamonds came from India, today there are other places eg South Africa,
but even the african diamonds are finished in India. There was extensive trade between Sumer and Indus, and there were bead factories in Indus whose exports reached a large zone of the old world, even reaching Japan.

https://www.harappa.com/video/textiles-and-basketry-indus-tradition-archaeological-evidence-and-historical-legacy

https://www.harappa.com/slideshows

In the year 1700, India was the biggest economy in the world, bigger than the entirety of western europe up till that point,

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_regions_by_past_GDP_(PPP)#1%E2%80%932008_(Maddison)

China was ahead only from around 1500, and India was ahead at 1700. China eventually did overtake but how much of that was indian GDP relabelled as british?

colonisation essentially hijacked that economy by shipping all the goods to Britain and labelling them british!

India is central to ancient history if you go much further back in time, but europe has airbrushed it out as much as possible, and presents europe as the origin of progress, allegedly beginning with the greeks.

I have looked at your link, and the link does give your version in the text, but it does sound like dekho, but this seems to be a coincidence. S J Call seems to be bracketed for some reason, why do they say (S J Call) and not S J Call?

the transliteration of the korean looks very non chinese, the sound of the korean language also is totally different from chinese,
the sound flows quite smoothly, whereas chinese is like a series of erratic explosions.

I meant indochina in a general sense of major indian influence and also genetics. Where typically some aspects of the people relate to the chinese race, and some aspects relate to the indians.

eg I watched some other korean film, and they were using astrological things just like the indians do.

technically Nepal isnt part of Indochina, but if you look at the gurkha language, it is closely related to hindi.
so for me Nepal IS part of my definition of indochina.

the tibetans also use the sanskrit script for their non indian language and follow the buddhist religion which is from India.
and I would regard them as indochinese.

technically also Burma isnt part of Indochina, but for me Burma is part of indochina, you have only to look at the skin colour of the burmese, who often are dark skinned. Some are light skinned, some dark.

the word indochina literally means indian china, the fact that the term has become precise to mean places under french rule, doesnt mean we have to be bound by someone else's interpretation of the word. eg historically India included Burma and Bangladesh, but today it doesnt, but you can include Burma in India if it suits your purpose provided you define what you mean, which might be different from what I mean.

eg some people regard "african" to mean anyone from Africa, but you could also mean just the negroid people.
a lot of the people of the mediterranean coast of Africa are of roman descent and you could argue are europeans.
Cleopatra herself was of greek descent. Are the boers africans or dutch or both or neither?

for some "black" means dark colour, but Meghan Markle looks completely white to me, but is classed as "black".

the word India is anyway an externally applied word, the indians call their country Bharat.

officially Vietnam is part of Indochina, but India, Vietnam, China are 3 different countries, so the terminology is absurd if you are very literal. The vietnamese have their own language which at least sounds quite different from chinese or any indian language.
but some of them are dark people.

maybe you are korean and Korea is important to you, but for me it isnt important, and is one of many countries and is irrelevant except for Samsung and LG consumer electronics, the economic success of korea is because the americans have moved business their way to bolster it against communism. The americans hand a lot of business to South Korea and Taiwan, eg smartphone screens made by Samsung, and various PC hardware eg AMD cpus and motherboards made in Taiwan. Do you think the japanese arent capable of creating smartphones and PC hardware? But the business is handed to South Korea and Taiwan with a political motive. Because if they dont, the country will succumb to the north.

South Korea has a geographical problem that North Korea blocks it from the mainland of Asia, and Japan is nearby.

its success is artificial and is the charity of the US. It is successful for the same reason North Korea is unsuccessful, that China ensures North Korea is unsuccessful.

there is a lot of propaganda, the far eastern countries tend to be in denial of India,
you can see this blatant brainwashing in the film itself where they repeatedly associate the word "indian" with "red indian",

eg the rich dad says something like "my son is interested in indian culture", how someone can mean red indian I find crazy,
you have this ginormous country with more than a billion people called India, with adjective indian,
but no, indian means red indian! With the son in a teepee to underline this misdirection. red indian is an externally applied word,
the actual people call themselves sioux, comanche, mohican etc. I watched a film from Mongolia, and the mongolians in fact also use teepees!

where they are using pavlovian programming to make the south koreans think "red indian" when they hear the word "indian".
and for all I know you are part of this brainwashing or are brainwashed.

do you know what brainwashing is?
do you know what propaganda is?
do you know what disinformation is?
do you know what misinformation is?
do you really think cinema is just innocent little stories?
do you think South Korea has no brainwashing? I can see huge amounts of brainwashing in the few south korean films I have watched.

did you know that to publish a film in most countries you have to put in some kind of messaging from a list,
otherwise the film wont get past the censor?

I ran into this problem when I visited Japan and talked of indian things to some japanese guy, and the guy thought I meant red indian! He didnt know what India was! The japanese will meticulously say the story of the buddha, yet are in denial of India! Even Mao's mother was a buddhist.

the fact is if you look at koreans you can see they arent pure chinese, and have an indian look. I would say they have a south indian genetic influence.

But I would have to learn the korean language to really evaluate the language, and DNA analysis to determine the genetics, I cannot take a korean's word, because there is so much brainwashing. History is twisted and warped to suit the opinions and biases of the historian and his financiers.

South Korea is a political front of the US, and North Korea a political front of China. Both countries are puppets. Cut the strings, and the puppets fall. The US is in serious financial jeopardy, so it may happen sooner than you think, like their pull out from Afghanistan. Charity begins at home as they say.

The parasite fim has major brainwashing, eg the guy in the bunker I think was taiwanese or something, I dont have the time to locate the specific nationality, and his wife spoofs a north korean broadcast,
do you think this is just a bit of story? or do you think they might be trying to brainwash south koreans to despise taiwanese by falsely associating them with the north koreans.

when the taiwanese guy bows his head against the switches, I think that is to undermine the japanese obsession with bowing,
but via a korean pretending to be a taiwanese!

they also selected a very ugly man to depict the taiwanese, again to undermine the opinion of taiwanese.
That poor daughter also in real life has to be a rich girl! They select an attractive rich girl to depict the poor girl,
and an ugly man to depict the taiwanese! BRAINWASHING.

it is just not plausible for a taiwanese couple to talk like north korean tv broadcasters!

comment: The movie doesn't have to paint the kim's as saints to be on their side. The kims are a standin for the rest of the poor in the world who have their homes flooded and labor exploited for the rich to live lavishly. This is where the double meaning of the title comes from. The rich family are parasitically leeching off of the poor and have become so alienated to their struggle that they turn their nose to anything that reminds them of lower classes. So if you're poor and society breeds you into thinking that the only good way to live is a rich way, then of course you're going to exploit the rich, become a parasite to the parasite. The point is that there's no way to "do it properly" because exploitation and violence are necessary to bask in so much wealth.

comment:
That one scene where the poor family was hiding from the rich family in the living room so they don‚Äôt get caught, I really love the symbolism that came with it where it demonstrated the hierarchy between the rich and the poor and the power of privilege; where as the rich family were above the poor family(physically and in society) and they were just enjoying themselves and not worrying about anything while the poor family was beneath them(physically and in society) and they basically holding their breathe and struggling while also not trying to be noticed by the family (just the same way it works in capitalism where the rich(lots to the time) are the ones seen by the world and the ones we here about while the poor struggles but is still expected to keep their heads down and mouths shut just to get by in the world) so while the rich family is completely oblivious and doesn‚Äôt truly know what is really happening around them, only what it has to do with themselves, the poor family is aware of what is happening around them and even how the rich family talks about them. The rich family knows what benefits themselves while the poor family knows the reality.

*My thoughts aren‚Äôt completely developed about the thoughts I have about this scene but I thought I should just share this

comment:
Abel Abel ¬†@Abel Abel¬† ¬† well first of all, if you make a claim you have the responsibility of substantiating it.

It would be like me saying "China is evil" and if it isnt then you have to prove it to me.
Thats not how it works, if I want to make a claim, i need to support it by saying "China is evil because communism genocide concentration camps etc..."

So i dont accept the premise in the first part of your response.
Secondly, for people who don't have access to internet or time, that's a different case because what I am claiming is if people have the internet people can't complain. And if someone says they don't even have an hour or two of spare time in their day then I don't believe them. Because otherwise i wouldn't be having that conversation.

I am not saying people should just die off. Theres welfare and unemployment benefits for that.

Thirdly , if 50 percent of world wealth is in the hands of a few people, whatre you gonna do? Steal it from them? It's about competence.
If someone feels that they are more competent than them then they can go ahead build something valuable and earn all that money for themselves.

Oh and another thing.
If you're making 300k a year after getting a PhD degree then sure, my competencies and economic utility of my skills are not nearly as good as yours.
That wouldn't make you an asshole that would make you correct.

You can look down on me or anyone you wish to. It doesn't harm anyone because no one cares.

We didn't invent a market, we invented trade and rhe market was a naturally occurring by product of that.

And why can't you understand the simple concept about trade? Example,
i anticipate that everyone would want a spoon. I get the idea that i can sell a lot of spoons when that happens, so i decide to invest in that idea by buying a lot of spoons, this in turn, makes me bearer of that risk.

Then when soup becomes popular and spoons are needed, then I sell it to people and get more money.

The people benefit because they got a spoon to drink the soup with, and i benefit because I sold them at a higher price.
As the cost, i had the risk of that investment going to shit. And i came up with the idea.

I got money because I correctly predicted the worth of spoon or whatever.
Ridiculous example but there's no exploitation here and value is being generated. Everyone's happy.


Answering your other question, if everyone studies and becomes rich then what will happen, then due to more people being competent, that would generate so much wealth in the world that it would drive down the cost of everything, leading to the relative living standards the same as they are now and in absolute terms, better.

comment:
If you read about history, you will read about Kings and Kingdoms. Rome was one of the few Democracies, but everyone else in Europe had a Monarchy. Kings inherited their status for the most part and every subject that lived on their Land had to pay Taxes. We could now argue that most of those Taxes went to securing the Kingdom as a whole against enemies but... I would argue that a big amount of said Taxes went directly to the King, fueling his rich lifestyle.
Just look at France where... while the common folk suffered from not having enough food to the King and his court living in excess. Which eventually led to the Kings demise.

We just have that situation right now. Modern "Kings" like Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, Elon Musk and allot other CEOs like Activision-Blizzard's Bobby Kotick, which earn astronomical salaries and bonuses while compared most workers hired earn very low salaries, not to forget that Activision-Blizzard laid off allot people in a "record year".
I feel like... you hit the spot right on with the question "Who is the real parasite?".
One could argue that the "real" parasite might be those overpaid CEO's that can mainly earn that much money and increase their stocks because most of the workers that actually generate the wealth of the company don't get paid enough of a wage in return. Allot of the workers might even be on the other side of the world, China and allot other Asian countries like Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia and others come to mind.
Good video!

comment: No no no.  You are missing the most important facts.  Capitalism DID provide upward mobility, and where anyone who worked could become wealthy and own their own house and car.  It was when plank #5 of communism, CENTRAL BANKS, and the separation of the dollar from being backed by precious metals that this changed, and indeed if you look at the 60's, there really was upward mobility.  Capitalism lost its legitimacy, and ceased to be capitalism when bankers acquired the power to create credit out of thin air with which to purchase capital.  That's when we transformed into a caste system which put those in proximity to control over the money supply at the top.  Bankers intentionally create boom and bust cycles through debt in order to impoverish people, and then they leverage the poverty for political power so that they can establish authoritarian regimes which they control, effectively making them kings.  This also exposes "right wing" lies that investors take the risk, when in fact they receive subsidies, bailouts, etc, transferring their losses in the stock market to the general public through taxes and inflation.  The "left wing" lies are that we have capitalism.  We don't.. and we haven't for a long time.  Not since central banks and the government started centrally planning economies.  The bankers are in on it together, worldwide.
author: Terry Thompson

comment: @Clements No.. The prices of everything increase because the central bank prints too much money for the government to spend, and that has absolutely nothing to do with mininum wage.  I already explained that to you by comparing it to the melt value of silver.  Hyperinflation has nothing to do with wages.  The existence of central banks, and the use of fiat currency as a ponzi scheme is why the working class is having difficulty earning a decent living.  It is possible for people to earn a decent wage, with strong purchasing power of the currency absent of central banks and inflation..
author: Terry Thompson

comment: @Terry Thompson Which means it has effectively decreased.
author: Clements

comment: @Clements What do you mean minimum wage decreased?  I look at a chart of the history of minimum wage and it has steadily increased the entire time since its inception.  It has NOT however kept up with the rate of inflation, which means that there has been a gradual reduction in spending power for each individual as prices rise, and the value of the money plummets.

comment: @Terry Thompson Except capitalism is the exact reason that the minimum wge decreased.

comment:
I keep seeing this focus on fresh green looking grass in the park household and it reminds me of the phrase ‚Äòthe grass isn‚Äôt always greener on the other side‚Äô.
From a distance, the jobs that the kim family took over seemed good but when they looked deeper, they saw the state of that housekeeper and her husband, they saw the lack of respect, care or regard that the park family had towards them. They saw how trivial the incidents like the rain that flooded their house were for the family. They thought that for a second, they were on the greener side but no matter how hard they tried, they couldn‚Äôt stay there. Meanwhile, the park family uses the garden however they please, visible from the kid camping out all night as well as the party near the end of the movie. The grass is just an illusion for the american dream. No matter how hard you keep working, in this world, you‚Äôll never get to the green side. Meanwhile, the rich are living in this american dream with no fear of losing it.
