comment:
I don't agree with the idea in this movie. Social inequality and oppression have existed long before late capitalism and is in fact an inherent feature of any society from any time or place.

I also do not agree with basic premise of the movie, portraying both the rich and the poor as parasites of each other. If anything the societal cohabitation between the two "classes" (although I find the word tasteless and only used to provoke controversy) is more akin to mutualism than parasitism. The one only exists in relationship to the other -- the more rich you have then the more poor you have and vice versa. For example, take a look at Singapore, a major financial and shipping hub in East Asia -- lots of rich and lots of poor. Check out the living conditions of the some the people on Youtube -- some places are so atrocious that it cant be filmed.

But again, while the director was no doubt masterful in execution of his vision, his philosophic premise falls short to convince me of the reality of world. I believe the problem of economic inequality can be better understood from an anthropologic perspective rather than a sociopolitical one.

comment:
@Karl Snarks thanks for the thoughtful responses. I hear the infrastructure argument a lot but I don't necessarily agree. Everyone has equal access to the roads, power grid, labor, etc. so those who are able to take advantage of that shared resource to obtain wealth shouldn't owe anyone else unless they use unfair or exploitative methods.

I agree that Marx wasn't all about pure equality...I was just generalizing because most arguments for socialism have soft, undefined (in my opinion) outcomes. Is there a definition of poverty so we can recognize when it's been eliminated? What does "living wage" mean? One can argue that those in poverty are making a living wage since they're not dead (I know I'm being cheeky here to make a point). I'm all for reducing suffering with the understanding that a) we can't help everyone and b) every mission must have defined, objective end state.

I'm not sure worker's co-ops are the best format either as I feel there are a lot of inefficiencies in that system. How would large scale production or trade work? How about cooperation or coordination to manufacturing components which will be assembled at another location/co-op? How would innovation work if one research facility is dependent on the work of another? Etc. It's fine at the small and local scale but, I believe, breaks down when we go beyond that.

author: Maximiliano Monge

comment:
About your note on smell at 6:06 , I wanted to share an excerpt from George Orwell's Road to Wigan Pier. Orwell observed that smell is used as a physical, palpable barrier between classes.

"But there was another and more serious difficulty. Here you come to the real secret of class distinctions in the West ‚Äì the real reason why a European of bourgeois upbringing, even when he calls himself a Communist, cannot without a hard effort think of a working man as his equal. It is summed up in four frightful words which people nowadays are chary of uttering, but which were bandied about quite freely in my childhood. The words were: The lower classes smell .
That was what we were taught ‚Äì the lower classes smell .And here, obviously, you are at an impassable barrier. For no feeling of like or dislike is quite so fundamental as physical feeling. Race-hatred, religious hatred, differences of education, of temperament, of intellect, even differences of moral code, can be got over; but physical repulsion can not. You can have an affection for a murderer or a sodomite, but you cannot have an affection for a man whose breath stinks ‚Äì habitually stinks, I mean. However well you may wish him, however much you may admire his mind and character, if his breath stinks he is horrible and in your heart of hearts you will hate him."

comment: In my mind, the unfairness of capitalism comes with access to information. Capitalism has done me very well in my life, so in that respect, I may be biased, but I believe that you can put someone who knows about money, in the poorest part of the poorest country they could work their way out, but only with the knowledge acquired from the western world. If you swapped a rich person and poor person's money around, the previously rich person would catch up, and the now rich person would likely lose the money. If the world was to be truely capitalistic in the way that it is intended, information should be available everywhere for those that want it. With the internet, almost everyone in the western world has access to all the information that any one person could ever ask for, but in places like these, I can't say that I'm sure that someone could make it out. Capitalism as a concept only works with equal opportunity, obviously equal opportunity will never be possible, luck will always be a factor no matter what, but the world can strive for a base level of equal opportunity, which is an efficient and well thought out education system for everyone that gives genuinely useful information to a child as they are growing up. I think it's an issue that I need to spend a few days at least just thinking about, because the 10 minutes it takes to write this comment is not enough time to properly process and think through the problems that come up in this film, and their possible solutions

comment: The thing that neither the movie nor any similar argument have is a call to action, and there's a good reason for it. The message isn't "overthrow capitalism," the message is futility. It's hard to hear that because we already know that the problem is 100% caused by human nature, and we tend to think that we have mastery over our own nature. But we don't. What can you do? It's not just futile because you're under the boot, but it's futile even when you're on top. As the video showed, owning an iPhone puts you on top, and even people struggling to feed their kids have an iPhone. Will Apple care if you boycott their products? Will you save a single sweatshop worker from stubbing their toe at work? Probably not. So what if you were Steve Jobs? Maybe then you could summon inhuman strength to defy your nature and shut it all down, but the people you displace will just move over you and become you. If you're somewhere in the middle, like you probably are, you can keep most of what you have by giving to a charity that will squander your money in bureaucracy and greed, or you can throw away what you have by buying a gun to go kill your local rich person, and then the media will make it a tragedy, and despite everything it actually is one, and then it becomes fuel on the fire. But what you'll probably do given that those two options suck is just cover your nose and live your life.

comment: What sucks is that people think that getting rid of these "poverty jobs" replaces an evil with a good. They don't realize that it's an incredible opportunity for people in other countries and that taking away said "poverty job" replaces an evil for a WORSE evil not a good by default. It happened to us when I was 11. one day we had a home and food, then the next thing you know some college kid activists from the US came and got the plant that my parents worked at shut down because the working conditions were "too harsh" by their standards even though they didnt even live in the same country. They basically flew in, marched around for a few weeks, got the plant shut down then flew back out leaving us with nothing and no solution. We literally had nothing to eat after that and lost our home :/. Soon after my grandmother got sick from pneumonia because we had to sleep in boxes on the street and she basically ended up starving to death. It's horrible when young  people in privileged countries start fighting for other countries rights because they have no clue how much of a blessing "poverty" (in their eyes) is to us.

comment: It's not exploitation if you agree to work there under the terms you sign. If you don't like your work, leave and find a better one. If you can't find a job, that's that. No one owes you any work. If you force your employer with rules so that they hire you and give you your ideal work, it is by definition exploitation. Capitalism is based on consent. Two parties have to agree to come to a transaction, whether if that's buying a product, a service, or a wage. In econ, it's called the labor market. And like every market, there's a market price for every job. Companies buy worker's time and productivity and compensate them with an income. How much that amount of work that the worker has to provide for the amount the business is willing to pay is negotiable on every individual case. Choosing any side and write laws to give that side benefits that wouldn't have taken place if not backed by the full force of the law, while justifying it with "good intentions", its exploitation. The road to hell is paved with good intentions. Think in terms of reality, not in your personal ideals or emotions.

comment: I've never bought into the idea that this was about class struggle.  This was a story about a family of freeloaders who victimized a richer family.  The terrible sin that the rich family did was to say that one of their member's stink.  The poor family betrays friends, they steal, they lie, they poison people, hurt (and kill) other people, they have no problem ruining lives and careers of other people, they use deception to take advantage of a teenage girl, and ultimately they use violence when they are offended.  In the end, they spend the rest of the movie escaping the consequences of their decisions.  They are upset by what they see in the mirror, not by anything anyone else has done to them.  They are not victims of society, they experience the ramifications of their choices and blame others.  They are more likely to use their obvious talents to cheat the system than to actually achieve within it.

comment:
TLDR; Asian beauty standards are not eurocentric, there are historical, and much more local cultural reasons behind them. Thinking that Asian beauty standards must be because of eurocentrism, is in fact an eurocentric point of view.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I disagree with beauty standards in Asia being "eurocentric". The ideal of having paler skin comes in fact from the difference in skin tone that peasants had from working in the fields being darker, and the nobility who didn't do manual labor outside being much more pale. Other more "European features" being idealized, such as having a stronger or higher nose bridge etc, come from Asian people having more rounded and flatter facial features. So I personally feel that thinking that Asian beauty standards must be because of "eurocentrism", is in itself an eurocentric point of view, at least when it comes to Asian beauty standards.

There are other differences in beauty standards between cultures as well.
If Asia followed European standards of beauty, would they not taking advantage of being able to tan more easily? In Europe being tanned seems to be the ideal, especially with young women these days (sure way to get skin cancer btw).

One other difference is that for example in Japan, being muscular for men isn't the seen as the ideal (although recently there has been a fitness boom in Japan as well). Most Japanese women, when asked, said that they preferred at most a skinny fit body for men, rather than the roided-out bodybuilder action-star look of hollywood actors, which is arguably seen as the pinnacle of male-beauty in the west.

A while back there was an article stating that anime and manga is being drawn following eurocentric ideals, when in fact it just to give a stronger distinction between characters, making things more colorful, and it is a matter of stylization.

Thinking that the whole world revolves around the west is a small-minded and eurocentric way of looking at things.

Otherwise this was an insightful video.

@ Michael Jay
The rich already pay more for it. It‚Äôs the rich in any country that are gonna be business owners who pay the salaries of their employees. It‚Äôs also the rich who by and large already pay the majority of taxes that help to fund the country, at least in the states. So are you saying that they should pay even more? Why? Won‚Äôt that incentivize them to start investing in places that aren‚Äôt going to tax them as much and thereby taking industry away from our country, costing people their jobs? comment:
I feel like this takes a pretty un-nuanced view at the nature of economics and society. Modern capitalist societies are the best places to be on the planet, especially for the poor - seeing how the productive economic activity allows for the expansion of social services and better all-around infrastructure. Many young people in the West don't realize how good they actually have it. I was born in a pretty poor post-soviet country and I'm incredibly thankful for the opportunities afforded in places like the US. I feel like Marxian analysis is somewhat lacking in wisdom and is largely based on a pre-existing feeling of hatred/jealousy for those with more than others rather than a rigorous analysis of the nature of economics (I'm looking at you labor theory of value and exploitation theory)

It's very easy for us to point at factories in poor countries, but let's consider than the alternative is that nobody invested in that area at all, resulting no job, rather than a factory job. Anyway I could go on forever. I think this movie is a good look at the behavior of individuals, but I think it's sort of misplaced to try to make it into some grandiose statement about capitalism.
author: Yeg0r7

comment:
@Jack Middleton I'd say that the people who say this tend to take a cursory look at the state of what they see in a poor town or in a poor area and make short-sighted conclusions. The idea that capitalism "requires" or thrives off of poor people isn't an accurate one but the logic of the claim is that capitalism requires a dynamic in which there is an ownership class and a working class. A person who owns a factory does not have to physically engage in the labor of producing goods in a factory, but they benefit from the profit generated from the labor they hire.

Capitalism itself, as a term, is incredibly vague, but it's typically defined as an economic system where productive property can be owned in private hands. People who criticize capitalism tend to take a Marxist perspective, so they believe that the very act of profit is exploitative because it means you're "stealing" surplus value that is generated by a worker. The problem with such an analysis is that it uses what is called the "labor theory of value" when in reality the value of commodities is completely subjective. There is a lot to this, so I won't write a whole book in this comment section, but feel free to ask further questions if you have them.

I'll just leave you with a simple example to give you an idea of what I mean. A typical critic of capitalism would look at a clothing factory in a poorer country like India or Bangladesh and say "Hey, the business owner is exploiting these poor people and paying them a low wage" First of all I would invite this individual to look at GDP per capita data in Bangladesh and India, to see that they're becoming richer by the year thanks for foreign investment, but I'd also put in in perspective. Imagine you live in a poor area with no job opportunities, and the only real option for you is subsistence farming. If someone from a foreign country decides to invest money to build a factory in your town and offer to pay people to work there - that is an absolute gain to everyone involved. The poor people in the town now have access to a job that didn't exist before, that pays more than subsistence farming, and the factory owner gets access to a labor market that is likely cheaper than in their home market - meaning people in their home country will have access to less expensive clothing - it's a win all around. This is associated with the economics principle of "comparative advantage".

Anyway, that's what I'd say for now on the matter. Most of the people who say things like that either haven't seriously seen the faults in marxist theory, or are frankly just jealous of people who are successful and generally worked hard to get to where they are (80+% of American millionaires are self-made)

comment:
QUICK! Everybody! Spread the word!

Life isn't fair! You have to trade something you have, like hard labor or something special you created, to obtain things you think you need!

Luck is real! Some people are more lucky than others!

Envy is real, too, and it has been weaponized by the politically sophisticated and envious to get more ignorant People to hate anyone who has more than they do and they don't care if you EARNED IT by your hard work! Because... duh UNFAIRNESS.

This movie is a parasite, sucking off the teat of capitalism in order to get an audience. Exploiting the disaffection of the less capable and the guilt of the more gullible.

Or else it's just a well-crafted if preachy parable declaring the obvious: that everyone in an advanced capitalist society depends on the labor of others to obtain things they need and want and the distribution of those things is not equal and only relatively fair.

Head Smack followed by Face Palm.

author: Rare Naoto

comment:
Serious question:
Can someone pls help me understand how it's really the rich family that's the real parasite, as they live of the work of the poor family?

I do realize that the movie is a metaphor for class inequality, but in this specific case: the Park family, apart from being clueless, arrogant a$$holes are not really exploiting anyone. The poor family are hired and paid to drive a car, cook food and tutor the kids. How exactly does the work of a chauffeur, a cook and 2 tutors translate in the Parks living a luxurious life? It's not like the Parks can't drive their own car, cook their own food and do homework with their kids. Having someone else do that for them gives them more free time and confort, but it hardly makes them ultra rich.

The rich dad owns an advertising company from what I remember. His employees ( the people whos work help him make money ) are white collar: copywriters, creative directors, designers etc. His company's paying customers are business owners who are rich enough to pay for their services. So it's not like he's running a sweatshop.

If there are nuances that I'm missing about this specific case I'd really like to know.

comment:
I think a few people in these comments are reading too much into the plot, but I do see a few things.
I do see that there are a lucky few who are able to do exactly what capitalism is for, and that's to give people a chance to make money to get a good life. It's why so many business owners will arm themselves whenever there is a riot. (Especially Koreans.)

The one thing I don't exactly agree with in this video is the "different classes smell" part. I believe the smell is just the fact they aren't able to shower. I have family in Asia who are less fortunate than I am, they don't smell bad. It's just sweat because of the heat.

Also, a few pictures you showed in the video look a lot like places in South America, where socialist governments are common. One very popular example is Venezuela, where people eat rats to survive, but the "rich comrades" are in luxury homes eating the best food one could imagine.

comment:
This movie is communist propaganda that purposely misleads the viewer about the root cause of poverty which is debt.

Because we use fiat currency and no longer use money (i.e. silver, gold) the currency devalues over time and the way to get rich off of inflating currency it to invest in appreciating assets, i.e. stocks and other investments.

Most people are taught to save money and that is incorrect as your currency is losing value. You must hedge your wealth by buying assets like precious metals, stocks, or low risk income generating real estate

Because we are purposely kept in the dark on how to make money, we are led to believe that capitalism and rich people are evil oppressors when in reality it is the banking system and our monetary system that is the root problem

comment: No one is talking about this symbolism; the toilet was the higher spot of the poor's house, this is because they are beneath the sewer pipes level (pointing out that this is a very cheap place) same as the window (the only view they got) is at the same level as the street, them being beneath it. This is a symbolism of how low the poor class is force to live in the society and how they are perceived. The lowest point possible. Below sewer level, and this point of view is stronger when you realize the rich family house is on a uphill, on top of the city giving his great view. Also an extra detail is to think that for something so basic and necessary like a toilet, they have to be in such a tiny, uncomfortable place.

comment: Fun video, though it is kinda funny how you used a Marxist idea of cultural hegemony because South Koreans vehemently despise anything communist, socialist, marxist for obvious reasons. It's kind of incredible too how much this film resonated in the USA especially because there is a cultural difference in perceived wealth gaps in Korea. This is because inequality is much more... tangible(?) there. At least there are things to blame in the USA. Where you live, skin color, immigrant generation, etc but in Korea, a homogeneous society in a country the size of Ohio... well inequality between Koreans is... well just plain inequality. Also Korea is a weird place where in the city of Seoul, one of the world's biggest megalopolises, has basement rooms with luxury apartments just across the alleyway, old toilets that you have to squat to use right next to modern American Standard toilets with bidet attachment. Some parts of the city sparkle while other parts look like they never left the 70s. At least we can try a different city, a different state. Koreans only have Seoul and they are so desperate to survive within it at all cost.

comment: I agree with most of what was said in this video. Except one of the major points that was made. You stated that it is not really an option for the poor to aspire to having wealth and becoming rich, but this is simply untrue for millions of poor people. My father was a part of the lower class in my country (not in North America, Europe or any developed country by the way) growing up with what was necessary to live a life without physical suffering, but he never had more than enough and he had to come out of a town which had high crime rates. Today my dad is wealthy and owns his own companies. You try to say as a fact that coming out of poverty and that the American dream is just a lie sold to the people, but for millions across the world, and definitely for South Korea since it is a moderately developed country, it is indeed possible to become rich and to create wealth. If a child decides to do the best they can in school (if the opportunity is granted to them) they would generally be capable of going to college if they excel in their studies during highschool, and I don't say this baselessly. Even in my country if a kid graduates from his/her highschool with exemplary results they are capable of going to college which would allow them to generate money in a variety of ways. Not just this, but 88% percent of millionaires today are self-made and 80% of millionaires reported starting out with nothing. It may take Ki-woo nearly 600 years to come up with the money he needs to buy the house, but that doesn't take into account what it is that he does for a living or the potential he has doing something else. Some people are luckier than others when it comes to where they are born, but for most of us, with hard work, WE CAN DO ANYTHING! If you read all the way to here, don't let this video tell you that the American Dream is just an illusion and that there isn't any way for you to build wealth and become rich. If you work hard enough and study how to make money, you can do it.

author: BLACK BIRD

comment:
I think that the movie shed some light on the widening gap between haves and have-nots, but i disagree with most of the interpretation. The Parks don't leech off of poor people, the father works on a tech company, how is that parasitic? you may be right to assume that rich people have an advantage in the exchange of value for labor, but i don't find this to be a parasitic relationship. The worker gets money, the factory gets labor. And while you may think that this is completely one sided it is mostly through this kind of exchanges that china has become a powerful country(for example).

Also this idea that it is impossible for poor people to become rich is just about the most ridiculous thing in this video. Rich people squander and lose their fortunes all the time, and poor people rise to be wealthy all the time as well. I'm only saying this because i've seen with my own eyes the process through which people who have next to nothing manage to buy multiple houses and live very comfortably. it would take 564 years for the kid to buy the house if he did the exact same unproductive thing for all that time, but that is not the only thing he could do.

Capitalism is not completely good and like everything else can become bad if left unchecked, but the governments have an even worse history of managing the economy. also this idea that the poor are poor because of capitalism is also ridiculous, the places that you're criticizing are the places to which millions of people from other countries try to get to while losing everything in the process, sometimes even their lives. They do this because they know that even that deal is a lot better than what's going on in their own countries and because they know that it is one of the most effective ways to rise out poverty there is.

I do understand that some countries should not be interfering so much with the political systems of other countries but..... was that you giving a jab at the spread of democracy? i hope not.

While i disagree with your interpretation, the video itself was well edited and the way you presented your ideas was good too.

for the record, no, i'm not a conservative.

Luck is in everything, hard work helps, but working smart is where it's at. I'll check out the vid though

comment:
@11 12 I agree with you there, I have to admit I have a bias towards Musk but tbh he completely reignited a much needed public interest in space exploration, and spacex is literally building rockets that are better than literal government funded space agencies, That's a huge achievement
As in, he feels like the first famous billionaire in a long time that is actually doing the crazy things billionaires do in comic books
And yes, he was privileged, he lived in a good enough home and probably didn't have a major issue with money In his childhood as his dad was rich but what I'm trying to say is that he is self-made, I don't think it's fair to connect a financially secure childhood to a financially successful adulthood, at least not completely
And Musk having an involvement in Bolivia? Can you expand on that?
author: Ashwin Prakash

comment: @Ashwin Prakash A lot of presumptions there, I solely pointed out that he was very much privileged generally speaking, I didn‚Äôt even say anything in relation to politics and economics. It‚Äôs just very concerning to me that so many people like you out there seemingly don‚Äôt even question him and others like him, what happened to skepticism and critical thinking skills? Regardless of your or mine political stances, Elon is a vulture who resembles Tesla‚Äôs rival Edison, not actually innovators like Nikola Tesla himself ( and don‚Äôt even get me started on his contribution to the attempted Coup in Bolivia )

@11 12 Yes, his dad was rich but was it reason behind his success? Not even in the slightest
While making his first website(zip2) with his brother Musk didn't even have enough money to a buy a second pc, and lived in a small rented room where he would have to sleep on the couch, it wasn't his daddy's money that helped him start his first company, it wasn't his daddy's money that saved Tesla from bankrupt, it was his own effort

You have created this idea that the whole system is rigged, and that it's impossible for common folk to climb up to the top of the ladder and because of this ideology many people don't even try to climb and live their lives blaming the system

I know it's fking hard for some people and fking easy for entitled brats born into the family of a company's CEO, but it is in no way impossible to get to where they are, the quote that " You can get there if you work hard " Although usually overused is still not an incorrect statement, one success story is enough to prove that and if you look around yourself you'll see millions of such stories
author: Ashwin Prakash

comment: @Ashwin Prakash His parents owned an emerald mine in apartheid South Africa. As for Gates, his mother was on the board of directors of a bank and his father owned a law firm. He and his siblings all went to Lakeside, a distinguished private high school ‚Äî among the first ones to give high school students access to computer time in the 1970s

@Sugar Dolphin Yes, I have watched that video and even though it tells us that luck plays a much more important role in our progress than we think it's not justification for explaining why some people are rich and some aren't

For example if musk had spend his adulthood going to parties and eating at McDonald's he wouldn't have become what he is today, sure he is very lucky that his companies did not go bankrupt(Tesla did almost) but it was far from luck alone that made him successful, i might even say that in his case, the luck factor was less compared to the effort he put in

I know it's far easier for some people to succeed than others and the same amount of effort doesn't necessarily end up in the same position for different people , that's just how it is
But as long as it isn't impossible to reach a position, the responsibility falls on you, if you work hard you'll get there if you don't, you'll not
It might be harder for you than it is for someone else but that only means that you'll need to put in more effort than the other guy and not that he is destined to be ahead of you

comment:
I found this channel recently and went on a binge. I really enjoyed the analysis. That doesn't mean I agree with it. Parasite indeed has more nuance to it than a Hollywood movie. But that to be honest, is a low bar. The Park family is rich and seemingly superficially kind because they can afford to be. The Kim family is manipulative, and possibly criminal because their survival depends on it. In my opinion, that is where the nuance ends.
Is western capitalism, or neoliberalism the primary reason for the decline of humanity, if there is indeed a decline? Or it merely serves to spectacularly magnify the unpleasant aspects of innate human behavior? I don't pretend to know the answers. But Mr. Joon-Ho sure does. Yes, he does ask difficult questions. But instead of respecting his audience and leaving them open-ended, he squarely and not so subtly points his finger.

comment: We‚Äôre also sold a lie that the past was terrible and our society is universally better in every way. If this lie doesn‚Äôt hold, then people will realise that continuous economic growth doesn‚Äôt mean shit for their standard of living. We‚Äôre told that the current system is about constantly moving forward and advancing us; it‚Äôs ok if our lives are shit because at least we have all these nice modern conveniences that are way better than what came before. Except that‚Äôs not really true; I could point to hundreds of things that the past did better. Construction, clothing, manufacturing‚Ä¶ stuff isn‚Äôt made to last anymore because our society is organised around making a profit, not around guilds and best practice.

comment:
@grung "socialism" in its modern European form (i.e. social democracy with liberal economy) just means the members of society contribute their capital and agree on market manipulation for certain specific industries/services, it's not in any way an alternative to capitalism since it still operates on capitalistic principles within a capitalist worldview. Not at all saying that this is a bad thing but one also has to understand that Korea is already a social democracy with minimum wage, basic free healthcare and pension system etc. so what does Parasite really add to the conversation? Not much really, which is why it wasn't really as popular in Korea until it got global attention.
Socialism in it's classical form where major industries are made public has already failed many times over so no need to discuss it here I'd say.

author: aisha

comment:
Great movie. It‚Äôs no surprise that a Korean director familiar with S. Korea‚Äôs harsh capitalistic society made this kind of movie.

Having one of the most rigorous university entrance exams and averaging the highest weekly working hours, all this results in high suicide rate, brutal turnover rate in white collar jobs, and edgy people with irritable personalities. The incessant quest for excellence and perfection in S. Korea has given it the notoriety as ‚ÄúHell Choson (Korea).‚Äù

Many foreigners who‚Äôve experienced can verify these claims. I, a foreigner who‚Äôs lived and worked there, can attest to the harsh life there.

It‚Äôs normal for white collar workers to have their careers END in their early 30‚Äôs. In need to provide for their families, many of theses workers start their own businesses. One of the common businesses is restaurants. S. Korea has more family owned restaurants per capita than any other country in the world. Imagine going from working in an office one year and the next year, you‚Äôre frying chicken at your tiny carryout.

To put it in a nutshell, S. Korea is a hell hole for Koreans.

Understand capitalism, no consumption is ethical and that‚Äôs why we must put pressure on people like the Park family to be more ethical or just get rid of capitalism all together! :)

comment: These comments are full of people trying to defend one family or the other, or trying to claim one side is more of a Parasite than the other. That's not the point - The point is that both families are doing these terrible things because it's what they feel they must do to succeed. Both families did things that many would not consider morally permissible, but the point is not to compare the moral permissibility of each families' actions, it's to show the reasons why either one of the families felt the need to be that way in the first place. The whole system is corrupt - in this kind of socio economic environment, everyone is encouraged to be parasitic off of each other in order to succeed, and nobody wins.

comment:
@jada rosaline Well the story of Parasite is two poor families (one a bit better off) fighting each other while the rich steal from both of them, and are idolised. During the movie the Kim‚Äôs think about how appreciative they are of the Park‚Äôs for letting them stay at their house, and the guy in the cellar worships a poster of Mr Park and turns on the lights for him everyday, which Mr Park thinks is just a feature of the house.

The Kim‚Äôs would rather tie up two people and kill them rather than defy the powerful upper class who look down on them. The height in the movie represents position in class, which is why the poor people stay down in the cellar.

When Choong-Sook kicks Mun-Kwang (the maid) down the stairs into the cellar, she asserts her higher place in class onto her. Mun-Kwang‚Äôs feels duty to worship Choong-Sook as she is now so much more powerful than her. She would rather do that than see the malicious intent behind her actions.

author: jada rosaline

comment:
While everyone seems content on focusing on symbolism and class warfare aspects of the movie, one important thing is not being paid attention to: the moral atrocity of the Kim family. In my experience, it is actually the first part of the movie that I find highly disturbing: how parasitic and diabolical the actions of Kim family are. Imagine being given a job then taking that opportunity to constantly deceive your employer, taking the jobs of hardworking and honest people who have been in good service for years.

The second part of the movie is actually my saving grace: because it is the part where I feel like Kim family is about to get what they deserved for all their morally disturbing actions, especially when the old housekeeper found out about them and shot it on camera. It is even more disturbing to find out that the mother of Kim family is willing to kill someone for the purpose of hiding their real identities. I‚Äôm not convinced by what the mother said, referring to the mother of Parks family, that she‚Äôs not rich because she‚Äôs nice but ‚Äúnice because she‚Äôs rich‚Äù. There are many rude and parasitic wealthy elites as much as there are lots of morally exemplary middle class, and even poor, people. Poverty is never an excuse to deceive people and rob other good people of their jobs, simply for the reason that ‚Äúpoor people need something to eat.‚Äù

All in all, Parasite is a once-in-a-lifetime experience of a movie. It is something that will disturb you while at the same time making you blown away by how deep, multi-faceted and intricate it is. It absolutely deserves all the accolades it receives.
author: Philosophy That Matters

comment:
What's really fascinating is the fact that the themes depicted in the film seem to be reflected in real life. It may seem like PARASITE seemed to have hijacked the Oscars just like the Kim family. The irony of taking 4 Oscars representing the 4 family members. The movies address growing class tensions in modern society which I believe in something that also happens in the film industry. The idea that any foreign film are marginalized to the bottom with one award nomination. You begin to see how the Oscars are also a "parasite" that reap and lives off the labour of foreign films. They are fully aware on the impact the award show has on films, so they expect to receive numerous film applications which in return gives them a massive viewership on the award night. The Oscars' ignorance is fully shown when they don't bother to involve the cast or crew in any award nominations.

The Park family displays their physical aversion to the smell of the Kim family. A big symbol on Oscars' strong distaste for foreign language in cinema. It is very clear that the Oscars want nothing to do with anything foreign and fully draw a line on their sophisticated world and don't want anyone crossing it. It's very clear they fear being exposed of their privilege which is something that is finally coming to light.

comment: While I agree that capitalism is toxic and most of what you say is on point, pointing the blame on conservative norms and ideals when socialist regimes throughout history have used the morally high ground to exert authority and power is telling to the notion that people are so hung up on being morally good rather than going for what is required, competent governance. Competent governance is not conservative or liberal, competent governance is making compromise and being able to do what is required to maintain the public order while creating as prosperous a state for all as possible. There are no states in the world that have done this yet in my opinion

comment:
I never watched this movie but I think ill try to be the voice of reason here. Of how wrong the views of this person is.
Some of the things she got right is the Elite class. The rich as she calls it does this. Use the poor and others to do their bidding and usually have all the rules rigged to benefit them. Accidents some times happen thought ahem*. for those of you who are not completely blind to whats actually going on right now. Corporatism is the new normal and the united states is to blame for this MOSTLY. Others would say a banking family is what started all this but *ahem most people consider that conspiracy theory. Today you can easily Link most mega corporations and mega banks to very horrible deeds! yes, and these deeds are all about profit and power.

Now what she has wrong. Capitalism is Not what we are seeing today. Capitalism is actually the best bad system humanity has ever made and has created many nations that do well still today and has lifted millions out of poverty. Millions in a world of billions not good but better then the other choices we currently have. It also however creates failing states and in a sense is what world trade is ruled by even now. Some of these dictatorships you hear about only have One resource to captivate and sell on the global market meaning their citizens will never experience the same pleasures you and I experience. To understand this better your need to understand the rules every leader needs to follow if they wish to KEEP or HOLD power. Every state and nation has some capitalism in it other wise they would just fail. What people keep getting wrong is Corporatism being confused as capitalism. Yes the corporations are using the capitalist method, but they are also Posing as a state/nation. A nation or state is a Government power ruled by the few. Look at history books and you see all about loyalty,Honor and duty to the state And betrayal, power grabs and revolts from the state. What do we see today? The very same thing in corporations. The bigger the corporation is the more power they wield on states and Nations. Its at the point where some mega corporations have regional power if they were a nation. This is what we should fear this is the real monster the USA has unleashed on the world. I am very unsure if it can be stopped with out major action and reaction from national powers.

This is why nationalism is making a comeback people are starting to wake up and realize the real danger of globalization. When you lose the ability to make your own stuff you become a slave and depending on the people making it. Who controls all our stuff? Corporations and corporations need slave labor to keep profits and expand power. This is the real scary monster. But lets not kid our self's here. Those of you specifically college age kids NEED to study the Horrors of Communism. Regardless of the evils of corporatism and its for sure bad. IT still not as bad as PURE GENOCIDE. And china is the worse offender of this today having done so over 3 times now to their own people. How many people have to die before people start realizing the evils of the world are In your own backyard in your class and in your society. people need to STEP back and stop thinking with emotion and start realizing there is NO pretty picture and not real solutions with out Localization and building. Dont expect others to solve your own problems.

Also id like to point out what some one else commented on. "Another lesson that can be drawn out of this is how easily the "rags-to-riches" individuals tend to forget their roots or where they started from. The Kims, once they are secured in their jobs and view themselves as moving up the wealth ladder, act the part of the rich. They dismiss the former cook's pleas to help her and her husband, despite the fact that they are similar. But another aspect that drew me to this conclusion was their initial dismissal of the rain" All those so called SUCCESSFUL people in the world. most of them NEVER FORGOT their roots and treated every day as possibility going back to that poor life. That motivation made them do and sacrifice and never gave up. A routine most of you don't even have the courage to do. SO a socialist system penalizing people like that will KILL society and create another Nazi Germany or worse! a communist state. Were everyone does as little as possible because anyone who gains attention will have to tip toe around glass shards or be killed. A nation like that leads to mass starvation and mass deaths and stuff you all would be horrified to no end to experience. Things people complain about now bullying, rape, and Racism. Ha these things would be so MINOR in such a society as that.
author: Terlin1466

comment:
Really good video! Thank you!
I have however realised that all those points don't really get through to audiences. I mean, it seems to me that a certain political sensibility is needed to grasp what the film is saying. I recently overheard my colleagues describing it as unrealistic and bizarre, and thus unconvincing and in the end just a dull weird film. I tried to explain a bit but felt their interest waning rapidly and the hastily changed the subject.
It is not necessarily a generalisable example of reactions, but I feel it is kind of indicative of the cognitive dissonance many of us almost need to live in in late capitalism, not able to process a piece of culture that lays bare the reality of our system, dismissing said cultural product as bizarre and unrealistic.
Watching now your video on Bridgerton, I come to think, we are truly in the society of the spectacle. nothing is real.

author: Yee Yee

comment:
‚Äã@Yee Yee Were reapeting over and over what Im saying. You are not understanding my point, the system you think is as simple you want it to be, nor facts you think are caused by a single individual or a single root cause for everything. The problem we are facing here is NOT one, but multiple complex factors, and more factors if we divulge into those said factors. We have the capabilities to feed everyone, but how can we achieve that goal? These road blocks are not only by the government, but by also individuals, paper work, laws, political, cultural, economy, and above all else, logistics.

You cannot proclaim to politics, or any system thats not capitalism and say with the audacity that these systems or road blocks can be "simply" remove, our system from big or small has road blocks for reasons, some dumb, some logical, and some complex that I have little to no background to say what those are.

And again and I will repeat this again, It IS 2 ways from my experience, my entire family was literally started from humble origins, some of my folks reasoning are due to my past family poor choice of education, availability of work, and more deeper reasons. This is what im saying, its not only the systems at fault here, we have to look pass that and see the individuals. Whats the point of changing or pointing out the system's flaws if we ignore human error? Not upper class people, but all people. From the poor, middle, and upper. Because we are the system here.

I am left with this, because we are neither getting any ground of a solid foundation, please, if you have the time. And Im probably gonna guess you probably have because its summer and... COVID... like here were I live, if you have 20 minutes to spare, please, watch this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rStL7niR7gs&t=1s&ab_channel=CGPGrey
author: Pauuu _

comment:
@Pauuu _ ....i don't think you're understanding my point.
those road blocks are caused by capitalism and human greed, it SHOULD be that easy to give everyone what they need to live, but it isn't do to the people in charge not wanting it to be. that's the point i'm trying to make. the working class can't take advantage of the upper class because the system was built to work against them
author: Yee Yee

comment:
@Yee Yee Again, your view of the world is too simplified, that you fail to conceptualized multiple factors at play. We have the ability to solve the problem, but we have multiple road blocks to reach that point. Political, geography, beucracy, culutural, efficiency, and logistically. And thats juat the tip of what our system is. Even if we are able to feed people, its just a temporary solution to a much more complex situation.

Feeding the poor is not a final solution to poverty, it delves deeper into economics, infrustructure, and family. It literally wont solve a lot, it will solve things of course but its too small and temporary for the long term.
author: Pauuu _

comment:
@Pauuu _ first of all, about not having the money to be able to feed everyone, jeff bezos alone could afford to end world hunger. one man, could completely eradicate world hunger. it's not about not having the means to do it, it's about whether or not it will keep the people at the top in power.

i see what you mean, but the ussr wasn't communist. communism has literally never been successfully implemented, meaning russia was never communist. and making sure people don't starve to death isn't communist, it's basic morals

and yes, the world has more to it than good and evil, but the point is we literally have the ability to solve these problems, but the people in charge choose not to.

it still can't be two ways, because working class people have to work their asses off their whole life just to have what they need to be able to live. upper class people get to take advantage of working class people, with no consequences in return. it can't be both ways

comment:
Very nicely outlined and presented points! The outcomes of neoliberal capitalism stated against a backdrop of hymnal music was a particularly nice touch. I love the cinematography in this movie.

I'm personally a lot more ambivalent toward hegemonic structures because perfect equilibrium seems impossible by acceptable means. Only through an effectively unified monoculture would this be possible as human genetic and geographically defined ethnic diversity is much too widespread for all phenotypes and cultures to be equally valued - so if one standard isn't seen as ideal, another easily identifiable one would be in its place. We're headed somewhat in that direction already - east asian beauty standards are on the rise.

author: Al

comment:
metaphors i noticed:

- mrs park mentions how her son thought he saw a ghost when he saw maid‚Äôs husband = rich dehumanise the poor into entities not actual people
- when kevin says the rock was "hugging him" and later on he drops it, gets caught and injured with it = everything the working class cling onto will be taken from them
- the parks are not aware they have a basement makes the maid and her husband living in it even more symbolic; rich are not aware of the working class' hardships and cover it up (like how the shelves cover the basement)
- their smell that they can't get rid of = inescapable poverty
- mr and mrs park engaging in sexual behaviour and being loud but the kims sleeping peacefully underneath = hints at their working class issues, sleeping with noise so they got used to it but mr park isn‚Äôt used to their 'boiled rag' scent he complained about earlier
- the kims‚Äô house floods right after mr kim reassures their children and tells them to have a bath = they don‚Äôt always have a stable place to go to whereas when mr and mrs park woke up from their son sleeping outside and told him to sleep inside, they don‚Äôt need to worry about it
- little bit of rain was a struggle for their son in a tent outside but an entire flood happened in the kims‚Äô family = working class struggles will always be worse than upper class struggles
- all the blood on white material imagery persistent in the film; sauce mr kim splattered on the tissue the maid used to show that she had TB and then the real blood splattered across the white coloured food at da-song's birthday party from the maid's husband slashing people. he also had blood and white frosting on his face from jessica cake smashing him. perhaps hints at the purity (white aspect) the upper class get to enjoy and the death and horror (red aspect) the working class have to endure
- light in the parks' house keeps blinking (mr kim doing morse code) even after maid‚Äôs husband died = working class issues will continue to live on unless things change

comment: @Tretch i understand where you're coming from, of course creators might not always intend for a certain meaning but in my opinion that's the beauty of art; all the interpretations EVERYONE can make from it, not just exclusive and limited to only the creator's intentions
author: ecstasy

comment: @ecstasy you‚Äôre right, which is why direct metaphors in art are pointless. It‚Äôs kinda the age old struggle in art, artists sometimes make something just because it‚Äôs aesthetic or serves some type of narrative purpose, and then you have a bunch of English teachers and YouTube commenters deciphering some special meaning in it. As you said, there‚Äôs no wrong interpretation, and any scene can be contextualized to serve some type of special meaning, when in reality there‚Äôs a good chance the creators never even intended it to be that way.

comment:
I agree this movie should terrify us because of the reactions like this video to it. There's always capitalism vs socialism argument going on without understanding the root causes. In a nutshell, ANY system that rewards productive agents while providing open access (i.e. equal opportunity) will prevail. It's not about how "hard" one works, a janitor can work as hard as Steve Jobs yet society will value their work differently.

The one that creates more value will be rewarded with more resources. This is something EVERYONE misses. Socialism by definition, although good in intention, does a really poor job at rewarding those that produce value. In fact it does the opposite by removing rewards.

Government's role should be to make sure there is equal opportunities, not like it is now where they just print money and debase the currency at like 2% per year and cause inflation, yes, inflation is only caused one way, by printing. Just look at bitcoin, the value goes up because supply of coins are limited so you have to keep dividing the money. Imagine if government could not print money, you'd have money increasing in value. But no, you have the poor being hit the hardest by inflation because politicians love to spend money, forever keeping the poor, poor.

Cultural hegemony is also showed by associating wealth with America. comment: I am so glad we don't allow dubbing in the US, and we explore the language of the director and the actors actual performance. I have lived in France for 5 years and they dub all foreign film. I feel like the US figured out how stupid it looked when they tried doing it with kung fu films. Why the French think it looks fine, I don't know lack of attention to detail. I feel like they have wine and we have film as our export. Also so many French people love American actors but have never heard their actual voices, that is weird to me. It's art erasure, you can't say you saw an Oscar winning performance dubbed, I'm sorry, but nope. The theaters show like 70% dubbed and 30% subtitled/original language, but if it's airing on TV you will be hard pressed to find the original language, and if you are new to the language they won't even have subtitles in French to try and check what you think you heard. I was asking my husband, so how do deaf people watch TV, that seems unfair in that sense as well. I will say I do understand dubbing movies for kids, for obvious reasons. The other horrible thing dubbing does is make French people think they own things they don't, like movies or tv series. For example I've had colleagues tell me about shows they think are French, and I'll be like nope it's not, how did you not see the hilarious corny dubbing?
author: Niqalia Evans

comment:
One of my favorite details of the movie is that the house, which is pretty overtly a metaphor for the class system itself, is repeatedly said to have been made by the previous owner, the architect Namgoong. This is pretty overtly saying that the system itself is manmade, but the way the architect was represented in the movie was something close to mythic, if not godlike.

Edit: was corrected on the name. Fixed it. Sorry about that.

comment:
Another lesson that can be drawn out of this is how easily the "rags-to-riches" individuals tend to forget their roots or where they started from. The Kims, once they are secured in their jobs and view themselves as moving up the wealth ladder, act the part of the rich. They dismiss the former cook's pleas to help her and her husband, despite the fact that they are similar. But another aspect that drew me to this conclusion was their initial dismissal of the rain.
Where I live, whenever it rains, my first thought is of flooding, because my home tends to get flooded no matter how light or heavy the rain is. When the Kims are sitting in the Park's living room overlooking the window to the thunder and rain, the father remarks how wonderful the sight is. Their first thought wasn't of their basement-dwelling, and the worry of the potential of the floodwaters flooding their room, which was very much likely to happen given their home location. No, they were too busy contemplating their success and drinking to give a momentarily thought to who they are and where they came from. This happens quite often to wealthy people who came from poor backgrounds. The need to assimilate into the "rich persona" subsumes their old identity, until it is eventually expunged from the new persona they have adapted to because now, it has no place. As a result, they suffer the consequences of adopting a false identity in order to fit into a social class.

comment:
üòÇüòÇüòÇCapitalism is great. üòÇüòÇ The amount of nonsense you believe is uncanny

" The need to assimilate into the "rich persona" subsumes their old identity, until it is eventually expunged from the new persona" there is no conscious act there.

If you take any book about primates, you'll see the higher status gives you higher levels of serotonin, and lower levels of cortisol. The same as lower status is higher levels of cortisol,

which comes will being "jumpy" (as in constantly worried and scared), and worse inmune system. It happens in many primates in our evolutionary line, including humans.

The very posture of high ranking primates change naturally, they walk taller.
It is a consequence of acquiring higher status, a biological reaction.
Serotonin makes you happy, that is why they give Prozac to depressed people.

Capitalism is used in social democracies to allow access to education, healthcare and maintain a society where the poor can do everything.

I was able to study physics and engineering paid by the state, for "free".

I was able to watch all the movies I wanted, TV series, I had all the books in the world to read, and with the internet,

I could redirect my career to software, all making 500‚Ç¨ while developing ideas, for 5 years by myself.

I was even able to have trips to the beaches in the Canary islands or Greece on vacations, study languages, etc.
Without Capitalism, non of those things would have been possible.

But since I come from a society that gave me a lot, I want to give back, and gladly pay taxes, because keeps the dream alive, and we have barely no criminals because of it.

Americans, Koreans feel poor because you see the rich in Instagram, and you think you deserve the same. What craziness is that?.

You do not value what you have, you are greedy and being non-solidary, that is why you always vote politicians that would do nothing for the poor, because you center in hating the rich, and talk about race and gender(although the last part is purely American).

I watched this video and read the comments (as yours) and your level of disconnection with reality is insane. You think there is an "intention" an "unfairness fromt he rich",

when the problem it is you, you all along. Ungrateful people who do not care about solidary (you, not the rich) but to hate the rich and virtue signal,

while you do not value what you have in your hands (why do you think Mexicans immigrate there, or Africans?. They would build incredible lives with what you have).

You could move to other country, region, but you wouldn't move your ass, when your ancestors had no problem in going to other countries to make capital and have a better future.

Lazy, delusional, with a fictional realty that allows you to blame it all on capitalism, when capitalism is not even an ideology, is allowing free trade and then you pay taxes.

Your problem is you have no social policies, not "capitalism".

There wouldn't be anything without markets, and is so utterly ignorantly to pretend you can control it and it would still be productive.

I haven't see so many million people living this way. And you like those ideas, because you don't have to move a finger to feel as heroes,

or go to a couple of demonstrations, when you could do so much with what you have if you were not so envious and voraciously consuming

(because you can't live with little while you make, it, you need to comply to your nonsensical consumerist friends).

It will be fun to see if you ever wake up, or start a dumb revolution to go back to the same place and then realize the problem was you all along.

USA, Korea and such, will be a nice show for the next decades (if you don't play with nuclear weapons in between), because you sure as hell will not renounce to your victim-role, it is too sweet.

There will always be a conspiracy in which you are being profited unfairly by the evil rich. This is truly hilarious üòÇüòÇ

comment:
This can be viewed as a general metaphor for our wasteful society indeed.
Stale bread which could be still consumed for soups, salads, fillings etc is also thrown away just like that.
No one seems to care how much work, time & effort went into these kinds of labors.
The spineless Ceos of companies are rather willing to throw food away than to have the balls to tell the customer that they are out of those items.
For example if you go to a bakery 10 mins before closing, you shouldnt expect cinnamon rolls still being there.
But the spineless world of capitalism rather bakes another 2 trays to keep the customer happy.
And no one seems to care that the hard baked goods get thrown away rather than donated to people in need.
Because, you know...Company policy & all....God how I hate our sick world & its intentionally messed up systems.

comment: @Suulito I do agree with what you said. But there is another way to look at it. Is the death of, for example, a highly skilled person who contributed a lot to society throughout their life by excelling in whichever field they chose  same as the death of a person who lived a life not worth remembering? It is kind of intriguing. Death does equalize everyone, but one thing that can never be equalized is other people's memory of you. In Hinduism it is believed that whatever happens after your death is a direct result of your karma in your life. So basically, you could have died as a good person who gave joy and love to others while you were alive, or you could have died as a bad person, who gave pain and caused the suffering of others, or anything in between or apart from these two extremes. The question is... are these people all the same after death? I guess we'll never know.

author: Secret Alias

comment:
This is the first time I watch videos from you and not gonna lie, I was half asleep when I suddenly hear Anne Curtis' advertisement about white skin.

It woke me, then, that I have been 'blessed' with something that I already have since birth and always I find myself being complimented about my white and pale skin. Too often, I have delved into masochistic tendencies like neglecting wounds and scratches on my skin, reasoning that it "would all go away in a day or two" and would leave the blemishes on my skin as if it's supposed to be there. A few years passed and these masochistic tics increased in size and frequency, and more often than not, I find myself smiling as they compliment me still on my skin, not knowing that beneath my long socks are huge bruises and scratches that ache. The moment I stopped it, however, I have discovered that I had a lack of iron in my blood. No biggie, my parents bought me pills for it.

I am a person privileged with these materials that I do not need to work hard for or even lift a single finger- all I had to do was ask. Not for the first time, I ponder on how society can change. It had changed multiple times for the worst, and I think that now is the time that it changes for the best.

comment: I wanted to point this out because capitalism has become such a buzzword lately: class is not an invention or by-product of capitalism. The video talks a lot about capitalism and the lack of social mobility which is not true- there WAS no social mobility with feudalism, the system that existed before capitalism. You were born poor, you died poor (hence fairy-tales like Cinderella touching on social mobility; the dream that a poor girl could aspire to be a queen). There IS social mobility under capitalism, it's just not moral, hence apple getting rich off the backs of the poor. They got rich, so there is social mobility, but from immoral means. How many times do we hear of people that were well-off suddenly becoming homeless? That's social mobility; they dropped below. It's like with Epstein (beside the obvious w/ him)- he scammed his way into a billionaire status. We all know capitalism is not ideal, but it's definitely better than feudalism.

comment:
Like many around here, I used to be extremely poor (after the fall of communist Romania) and now I managed to change my class.
10 years ago poor people were my allies, now just because I moved class they "respect" me because I'm their friend, but would love to expropriate those who don't know.

I love Parasite, seriously, one of the best movies ever, but reality is always too complex to bring marxism on the table just for emotions sake. Nature/capitalism sets the damn game, always.
And also for the director who states that the guy would need 564 years to buy the house, right, but working always as an employee for the same company.
But how come does director have a net worth of 30M, how come it took him only 20 years to make this much, why not 3000 years? Maybe because it's not just a straight line?
Common people work to sustain themselves, rich people invest.
Again, brilliant movie, I love it in every second, but just because someone escapes that class of terror, he or she shouldn't be hunt down.
When the manifacturers die, everyone dies. And snowpiercer perfectly portrayes this, even if again, marxistically. But it's much better at conveying this message.

comment:
i think you were able to point out the key messages of the movie, but to link that to the fault of free market capitalism is too far of a stretch.

Even america is not a free market capitalism (i'm using america because the referred to apple and mostly companies of the us) , the monopolies or in this video you used, the ruling class, are create by the intervention of the government through making policies that favours big companies. I will take the example of skin, sunscreen in particular, american consumers can't get EASY access to other countries' better cheaper products because of FDA's regulations, it disguises itself as protecting consumers, but it actually limited competition, hence create monopolies. I would suggest you the works of Milton Friedman, Friedrick Hayek, their colleages, and deeper dive into economic history. I'm concerned with your opinion on free market capitalism and more government intervention. Government interventions are creating more class differences, simply count the number of rules in your country in the last 50 years, is it increasing, decreasing? And how did that affect the class differences?

I do agree with your opinion on corporates need to be more responsible, but instead of putting more red bans on anything, leaving on big companies are able to survive and work around those red bans. As a used to be labor and currently small business owner, I experience by myself what more red bans mean and affect business.

The whitening skin culture is "no way that this can be divorced from a long history of colonialism", it's an opinion and western colonialism is not that long. :)) I think others have voiced their opinion about this, i think that's enough. You could have taken any other examples. :))

author: b geese

comment:
There is something that Westerners continually get wrong about skin lightening in Asian cultures that drives me fucking insane.
A desire for ligher skins is NOT related to Eurocentric beauty. The first time I saw a white person, I perceived them to be ill. We don't perceive you as white - or when we say "white" we are not referencing European skin color. We consider ourselves white. The desire for light skin over dark skin is a beauty standard in a lot of asian cultures that long pre-dates the modern age. For example, in Central Asia, blue eyes and blonde hair (some of us are born with) were traditionally seen as undesirable. Of course, times have changed but it illustrates that we are not dying to look like Europeans and the "obsession" with white skin is not rooted in admiration of european concepts of beauty. We like our features and have a preference for lighter skin - not european skin.

comment: You mention Apple as a prime example of ‚Äúcool capitalism‚Äù but we always tend to frame our country as the problem. This country is built off a free market economy where other countries like China (thus the outsourcing) are socialist. We need to be more aware of who we hold accountable, because this country will never allow such brazen labor policies the way that communist China does. I write this because I understand that this video is a socialist promotion. Socialism doesn‚Äôt fix the wage gap. it actually creates an even larger gap between the elite (government) and the people. Look at the Hunger Games for example. The hunger games is a prime example of socializing and nationalizing all resources for the distribution of others. True socialism is doomed to fail because the lack of free will involved.

comment:
Parasite is the most thoughtful film to have won an Academy Award since who knows when... And you hit the meaning right on the head. As Sleepytime Gorilla Museum state so well in the poetry of The Creature, a parasite cannot live if it kills its host. And the most successful parasites are the ones that the host is unaware of. So the real parasites today basically keep the people they are leeching from barely alive, but not so close to death that the victim will become aware of what is happening to them.
If John Maynard Keynes could have seen what capitalism would bring to today's generation, he would have never shared the economic theories that came to be named after him. Without Keynes, capitalism would have died decades ago.

comment:
It just shakes me to the core.

The conversation at 11:20 is something similar to what I have with my family occasionally. My parents would be like, "Our son is fitting in so well in the Rich People's school", and I'm like "Once I graduate, I'll raise your standard of living and you both will look very naturally rich."

Yes, I belong from a struggling family. And thankfully, my parents always told me to be honest. However; it does sadden me what the Kims went through. I understand their desire to be rich, and quite honestly, there is greed in me however I know I should not cheat and lie in order to be rich. My greed is like not purchasing new things for myself. Whatever I earn goes to my monthly expenditure, and I can't wait to graduate so that I can start spending on myself.

I feel so bad for the Kims, even though they were the criminals. The parks were definitely the victims, but I can't relate to them which is why I don't feel anything towards them. This was a really sad but a good movie.

author: David ochoa

comment: Lmao I thought the ad for the skin whitening soap you put in was an actual ad since i'm from the Philippines. It actually hits hard considering my country's still extremely affected by "white is always better" to the point where it's a regular topic of conversation among people. It's extremely common to hear remarks like "Oh ew you got darker", or " I look better now that i lhave skin like *insert pale celebrity name here*" in everyday discussions. Hell, even our indigenous tribes are defined by their darker skin and are currently at the brunt of extreme social and racial discrimination here whenever they choose to try and make a livelihood in big cities. It was completely disheartening whenever my girlfriend would almost always become really insecure about her darker skin and asked me too many times if she looked beautiful with her complexion when she's the most beautiful person to me. But how can she not, when whenever you turn a corner you see a poster or billboard for skin whitening soap and when she opens her phone she sees more ads for them. And it makes me sick how a lot of those who reek of privilege here who can afford quality education sit in their classes and pretend to give a damn about their history class about the culture and tradition of our indigenous ancestors; the same people who they right now look upon with disgust and prejudice. Great video! Might have to rewatch the movie since I watched it on my phone which probably made me miss a lot of details.

comment: Social mobility does exist if you have a radical (not in a political sense) new idea, marketing talent, and the drive to work your ass off to make it all happen. Gates, Jobs, and Zuckerberg are not mythical figures. They are real people. I consider myself left of center but I don't agree that the American (or S. Korean) dream is a myth. A number of democratic, capitalist countries present people with the conditions to become rich. Even communist (but really capitalist) China has tons of self-made rich people. It's just that the vast majority of people don't have the talent and drive and sometimes ruthlessness needed to rise to the top. That doesn't make us "losers" in my opinion. We just don't happen to have that great idea and/or the drive to rise above the masses.

comment: @Stavros Adra I don't think I said anywhere in my comment that the USSR was communist.  I don't think that there is consensus that the USSR was communist.  In fact, Resnick and Wolff asserted that the USSR was never communist.   You can't connect my assertion that capitalism is good with the assertion that theft is good unless I accept your premise that capitalism must of necessity be theft.  Capitalism is a tool, and left unchecked people will use it to steal because people will steal if they have power and there are no consequences.  What the the USSR lacked is giving workers power over the means of production and their surplus production.  In a capitalist context, you can fix much of the problems by empowering workers, with collective bargaining and supporting worker owned businesses.

comment: I am a little late but i wanted to chime in by how surprised i was by some of the audience reactions i have seen towards the movie. I have actually seen quite a number of comments expressing their confusion over the movie's ending, as in they weren't sure if the scene with Ki-woo finally buying the Park's house was an open-ending or a foreshadow of the possibility in the future. It kinda shocked me when i saw comments like that because I thought it was clear as day that that scene was, in a way, "ridiculing" Ki-woo's aspiration and even BJH said that it would prob take Ki-woo 500 over years to be able to afford a house like that... I thought those audience reactions themselves show how prevalent the belief in late stage capitalism is, which is why I think this movie is genius since it can still draw out a reaction like that even though the ending was very in-your-face..

comment:
@David Bodor there IS such a thing as ‚Äòmiddle class‚Äô. Marx had a different name for them ‚Äî ‚Äòpetty bourgeoisie‚Äô.

The petty bourgeoisie, or ‚Äòmiddle class‚Äô, are people who own enough means of production to largely supplement their income, but not so much that they don‚Äôt need some form of employment. They often work skilled jobs or in their own small businesses, but are independently wealthy enough to not be destitute if they don‚Äôt have wages. Eg. The ‚Äòmiddle class‚Äô can afford to attend university for a couple of years (at the cost of not earning a salary) to get qualified for high paying jobs, while the workers will always be stuck in their place.

The reason why Marx boiled it down to two basic classes (owners and workers) was to sensationalise the problem. It‚Äôs like clickbait to get people interested enough to realise that they‚Äôre basically being exploited.

If you don‚Äôt believe this, I‚Äôll tell you a story. My family is ‚Äòmiddle class‚Äô, we own some means of production through investments (about $2M all up). This is enough money for us to own our own home. It‚Äôs enough to enjoy a significantly higher standard of living than proletarians‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs not enough to sustainably keep our standard of living for more than 5 years. We work high paying jobs close to the top and invest our earnings, but we aren‚Äôt part of the top. We have proximity to the capitalist class and enjoy some of its benefits, but we aren‚Äôt fully part of it ourselves. It‚Äôs these people who are neither completely dependent on work but don‚Äôt own enough to mooch off the system who are ‚Äòmiddle class‚Äô.

comment: hi, I love the subversiveness of this video - I thumbed up.  Now the question is who is being subversive and what is being subverted in my statement?  Am I the subverted?  haha, just kidding.  But as a would-be writer and film maker (I'm making all this up) I always wanted to know why the daughter was killed and now I see it.  I don't come from rich and powerful therefore I would be blind to the brainwashing because the brainwashed do not know they are brainwashed except that I understood this video or parts of it such that the cultural hegemony might have had cracks and partially flaked off.  Where is the danger and where is the fear?  Who should be terrified, I wonder.  The best solution is just like what Bong and cast did, which was to walk through the metaphorical streets of Hollywood (not literally) and come out unscathed and unchanged, perhaps unimpressed.  Regarding capitalism, its own rule says it can be exploited but to truly solve it you must ignore the rules that they read to you.

comment:
I just realized how this topic is so applicable to the current situation in my country. I am speaking in the context of online learning.

Online learning has raised so many concerns as I live in a 3rd world country. It not been very effective. There is lack of finacial capability to even buy a smartphone (at the very least). Laptops and desktops are luxury, and internet connection is for the priviledged.

Both students and teachers are struggling with today's education and every adjustments that we have due to the pandemic.

Those who need money go through extremes such as selling nude photos, selling their organs and even beging for money online (to name a few) just to afford online classes and basic commodities.

There are people who literally mock those who are incapable of adapting online learning saying "don't enroll if you can't accomodate online learning," and the likes. They are very close-minded and insensitive as to how much the less priviledged are suffering.

Little by little, I get to realize that survival is for the priviledged.
