comment: I don't understand the relationship of why Americans have to be held liable for the living conditions and social inequalities of those countries. Their government is the one allowing such cheap labor. I'm pretty sure Americans would pay more money for an iPhone if it required a higher wage for the manufacturer workers. It seems the narrative here is that the US is to be held responsible of cheap labor in foreign countries. Even if the US was responsible, we would never be able to change the labor problem on that country. So, the alternate solution would be for Apple to cut ties with Foxconn, wouldn't that be also problematic for that region? Wouldn't we do far worse to that economy if we pull the plug?  We can't hold Foxconn at gun point and demand them to pay higher wages, and I highly doubt that Apple would be able to enforce such thing either... This is why I don't understand your whole narrative. You want to make a comparison that in my opinion, does not fit with the issue the movie is trying to portray.

author: Abigail Martin

comment:
The thing that's so frightening is the fact that the poor family will never be able to justify their actions (the "murder" to be more specific), especially the dad.
Think of how dumb it would be to stand in court and go "I hated the way they couldn't stand how i smelled etcetc" he'd just be dismissed as crazy or mentally inept.
When in fact his reasons and motives are pretty darn justifiable from the view of us, the audience. We've been with them through the entire journey we know how much the little actions, the tones, the words everything affected them. It doesn't have to an easy "can be written on paper" reason for doing what they did but rather it was just an outburts of all the accumulated suppression and passive-aggresive disdain the Park family showed to the poor family.
In court of course, the Parks obviously won because not only do they have the wealth and reach but also "fraud" and "murder" are much more serious grievances to anyone at first sight that just "suppressed aggression"

author: Uhh

comment:
I loved this review! The movie was really a roller coaster for me.

On the topic of skin lightening, I know a lot of people have brought up the historical basis in the East in wanting to emulate lighter skin to give off the illusion of affluence. I agree and disagree with this. I think that while that history has helped formulate this way of thinking, we can't just assume the world exists in a vacuum.

Our world is rapidly globalizing (is already globalized) in large part to the internet but also to the long-armed colonization efforts of European countries past. It is much more likely nowadays that while people may have started lightening their skin to appear richer, it's also a behavioral trend that has been enforced and perpetuated by pervasive eurocentric media. I'm not outright disagreeing with anyone here! It's all just a huge bowl of "it isn't that simple".

Thanks again!

comment:
Funny. You keep saying capitalism is the problem. In reality, it's the corrupt capitalists that are the real bad guys. No one is going to be equal, nothing will be equal, and there will never be equality of outcome.

Capitalism is still the best system to exist that gives everyone a chance to become something more. Marxism, communism, and socialism are the exact opposite and are proven to be failures, and our unions and growing government power is proving this even further.

I see a lot of favor for Marxist rhetoric in this video and a lot of anti capitalism, but you failed to conceal your obvious bias and obvious dislike for capitalism and your favor for Marxism by purposely blaming the system itself instead of the corrupt people using the system.

Also, I noticed no one has brought up the poor families spending habits and way of living. You are poor for simple reasons, you either don't know how to manage money and spending, or you work a low paying job and are in a comfortable stagnancy and holding yourself back. I mean, come on, the amount of money people waste and yet blame others for their position in life is ridiculous.

Stop pointing fingers and take responsibility. Communism/socialism isn't going to fix anything. Open borders won't make things better. More diverse hires, and more women in positions won't be a positive outcome.

comment:
No matter what kind of society is established, there is a general rule of human nature that cannot be ignored. We are a society of individuals. Any societal idea that rests on human society operating as a hive-mind to succeed (communism, anarchy, etc) where every person moves as one and cooperates is doomed to fail right out of the gate because it doesn‚Äôt acknowledge how people actually behave. As individuals, we are all out for ourselves and our immediate friends or family members and that‚Äôs pretty much it. Nobody, rich or poor, cares about the welfare of total strangers.

Capitalism, will inevitably leave some people out in the cold as not everyone can be rich, but everyone at least gets a chance to improve their situations. With a society that requires an authoritarian government to make it work or where an authoritarian government otherwise exists, the people who become wealthy and powerful are the politically connected. Everyone else is left out in the cold with no chance to improve their situation. While capitalism is far from perfect, in a world of limited resources it‚Äôs the best system available provided it exists against a backdrop of laws and a generally free society.

comment:
Great work. I would like to comment on a misconception often held by those in the west. The desire for lighter skin (in Asia ‚Äî EXCLUDING INDIA, idk about anywhere else) has nothing to do with Eurocentric ideals of beauty. It is a classist and historical issue where centuries of economic disparity has physically manifested in the skin color of an otherwise homogeneous society. Rich people had light skin because they were indoors and didn't work outside. Poor people had darker skin because lower wage jobs mandated outdoor work. So to be clear:

People in Asia want to have white skin, not to look like a white person, but to look rich. Nothing to do with Eurocentric beauty ideals at all.
author: Mari Anne

comment:
You know what‚Äôs scarier than growing class tensions and their byproduct? Growing class tensions that are systematically propagated by the media and reinforced by the very big tech platforms you posted this (and I just commented) on.

The joke is on us. Capitalism and the villains of capitalism are misleading by design. The people in the basement, the people in the house- they are both exploited by the 10-13 families that are the TRUE beneficiaries of capitalism.

Our society is a big ant farm. ‚ÄúAffluent‚Äù people aren‚Äôt rich- they are the buffer between the true scourge. The face of ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs wrong‚Äù for everyone searching for meaning in a system that was designed to be unfair.

It‚Äôs all of us against very few of them. Until we realize that collectively; it‚Äôll never change.

ŸÑÿß ÿßŸÑÿßŸá ÿ•ŸÑÿß ÿßŸÑŸÑŸá

Didn't know there were any car etiquettes to be followed LOL- so I guess it's also rude to sit in the back rather sit besides the driver (that was hired) and maybe even lying down is also rude because you're taking the driver into consideration? I lie down all the time and put my feet on the window, because I just wanna rest after a long day. I'm in the comforts of my own car, and I think even I would put down my feet if it smelled. comment:
Hereditary Parasite and Mother are at the top of my list for scary movies that are scary in strange way.

Hereditary is just holy damn sh*t from the creep smiling at the daughter all the way to the end.

Mother felt like trepidation at the beginning before turning into a never ending anxiety attack till the credits rolled.

Parasite felt like a mixture of both, when they first started you're rooting for them to get money and move up and out then when the undies get the driver fired it's a sh*t show, and my heart was erratic and my body was tense.

I like a different type thriller/horror because the tense I felt while watching this is not the tense I'm used to or like when I watchmovies of this sort, but every award they got was well deserved the acting how it was shot and the long shot down to the bunker was chefs kiss

Loved it

comment: The ending / Alternatively, one could interpret the choice to hide in the basement as a path to two ‚úåÔ∏èfuture storylines interwoven Into one-another. The father knows how cunning his family are, in jail ( or death sentence) there would be no chance of escape / release. But, by hiding himself inside a Trojan horse like basement that his family ( he prolly didn't know his daughter has died) he is offered up a chance of  hope they can weave together another plan to realize where he is and rescue him. This ending also opens the door to a sequel of how does his son ( and mother) go about making the fortune to buy the house and ultimately live out that last scene of walking into their now owned house and allowing their father to come upstairs and live a new life not in the  lower socio-economical status they were so use to. comment:
The problem with the sentiment that people pull away from movies like this isn't that there isn't truth to be found in it regarding the flaws that can be found in capitalism, but that it tends to convince people to reject the system outright, and swing them into the opposite end of the spectrum, i.e. into the Marxist and communist camp which hold their own issues and severe capabilities for oppression. On the one hand, capitalism, most often thought of in the laissez faire sense, can grow to the extent to which an entity's influence is simply too large to be ignored, and that it becomes capable of gaming the system to itself, such as buying influence in government, or shutting down competitiveness in the market needed to sustain more positive aspects of the capitalism. People who claim to be enormous supporters of the free market on the surface, but will accept government bailouts at the expense of the taxpayer when an economic downturn emerges, are extremely hypocritical. No one should be allowed to steal wood from someone else's ship when theirs is sinking. Whatever reasons they may put forward to legitimate these actions, and whether one agrees or disagrees with the pros and cons of them in any given circumstance, many of the practices currently endorsed by so-called proponents of capitalism are inherently at odds with some of its foundational values, and seem to rarely be criticized by those invested in that system (however I should say this does not mean there aren't honest people who do.)
Speaking from a US perspective, in some ways, the current capitalism we have can be seen as a bastardization of it. In other ways, and sometimes by the same token, we can see the unethical tendencies that come part and parcel with it when allowed to exacerbate unchecked. While there are flaws, it cannot be said that capitalism hasn't contributed immensely to the progress of humanity as a whole, so in that, it's quite risky to throw the baby out with the bathwater in deciding whether it is simply good or not. The capitalist system is in a significant way directly tied to the notion of individual liberty. However, when powerful enough entities establish themselves by way of it, they can act increasingly unethical without taking on the rightly deserved accountability and consequences for it. Inferring from this, I believe the most responsible course of action ought to be to retain capitalism is some respect, but that the extent of it's corruptible nature should be curtailed by strictly enforced ethical principles. Compromise is very important, so while I agree with the right to free enterprise, it doesn't mean that I agree people/corporations should be allowed to use their stature for unabashed favoritism or objectively unethical behavior. If we don't begin articulating and implementing what these principles should be, corruption is simply inevitable.
Corruption is what a lot of these issues boil down to, and they are just as threatening under collectivist systems are they are capitalist ones.
In terms of the more collectivist ideologies, the promises made by these systems can be easily accepted on their surface and theory. The inherent perceived virtuousness of their common messages makes them all the more palpable to the public. However, though with different causes, the natural tendency of the direction these ideologies take produces many of the same issues as unchecked free market capitalism does, and not uncommonly worse. While I don't want to speak for everyone, and there are differing opinions on the extent to which these ideologies should influence the lives of citizens overall, for the sake of conciseness, I'll be more or less referring to communism, since many collectivist proponents tend to accept that it is the end stage of what they view as the natural progression of viable economic systems.

comment:
When we think about corruption, we tend to think about outside forces worming their way into the government to disrupt what their priorities should be, usually through money, bribery, things we associate with capitalism.
When we think about tyranny, we think about government that has grown big enough and strong enough to overstep its boundaries and infringe on our civil and human rights, which is how many people view communism and other totalitarian regimes.
However, it's not immediately clear why our perception is so when we compare these two things. They are both situations we would call out as corruption, but what is the difference, and what are the implications of those differences? I think that the answer sounds something like this:
Corruption in government in a capitalist society fundamentally stems from the fact that we overtly allow the influence of money in government. We have lobbyists, we have politicians that get paid absurd sums of money from entities simply for giving a speech, and we have this tacit notion that money is speech. While this is last part is actually true, the current rules do not result in a fair representation of the public. Some can give more, some can give less. Rather than what we currently have, in addition to stricter bribery laws, we ought to enact legislation that says everyone is only allotted and allowed $1000 dollars to donate however they'd like. Exceeding this would be unlawful and punishable. The issue with corruption of government in capitalist nations is a fixable issue if we can pass the right legislation to combat it. Government is a public service, not a business. The fact that you can come into it an average citizen and walk out a millionaire is a major symptom of that problem. If we get money out of politics, the people whom were involved for which would begin to weed out, and those who are legitimately interested in civil service would would begin finding their way in, as well as becoming freer to work for the public good without corporate interests obstructing their progress. In this scenario, we can get rid of the corruption, and power is retained in the hands of the people both by the democratic system and their financial support.
However, we now imagine a communist system, one in which an overarching governmental body innately controls all of the nations resources and decides how to distribute those resources to the people in a fair fashion. In this system, the individual does not have a the same bargaining chip for their voice or opinion. The government already controls the resources, and they're the ones who make the laws. In this system, without private property and ownership of what you independently produce, the government has the innate right to come to you to take what they say is theirs. Of course, in the pretext of doing so, the government will always insist that it is for "the good of everyone and the country." But imagine if it wasn't. Imagine if this government controls the nation in it's totality, all the way down to the individual citizen and what they produce. If the government is corrupt, they take more for themselves or play favorites with the tribute they take from the hands of the worker, and there is absolutely no recourse for the citizen. The government already has all the land, production, makes all the laws, as well as controls the police and military. It can physically enforce it's "right" to take that tribute from you. Communism is always sold to the public as people collectively owning the land, but it is still big government by any other name. Worse than that, since communist regimes have reliably rejected the individual liberty to bear arms, they are utterly at the mercy of the totalitarian state. Now the state is not only the one with the nations resources, property, and laws in it's grip, it is the only one with guns. Notwithstanding scenarios of basic personal protection from other vagrant citizens, this situation alone should definitely concern people. If the government were ever to become irredeemably corrupt, the people are simply incapable of ever physically taking that power back. This isn't to say it couldn't happen through a long arduous process of infiltration and persuasion of the powers, but history has shown us that the corrupt faction uses every tool at its disposal to prevent that from happening (propaganda, internet censorship, politcal prison, intimidation, coercion, erasure of right to protest, erasure of free speech to criticize, erasure of basic human liberties.) As we see in communist china, the people are living under the ever-present thumb of the government. They have some of the most oppressive, coercive, and fear-inciting intimidation tactics in the modern world. It is a place of thought police and speech police. A place where mere accusation is enough to have you pursued and silenced. A place where they can put you in a chastity cage on live TV to shame you, and make you apologize for criticizing the government in a facebook post. It is a place where if they cannot get to you, they will go after your family. A place where totalitarian control by the state forces you to filter your thoughts, words, and actions to conform to them. A place where your destiny is not your own.
In an ideal world, we would be able to trust the government in managing the totality of power and resource control that we turn over to them, but realistically, the powerful people in government are human like anyone else. They play favorites, want to protect their own interests and power, and will oppress the masses in order to retain these things and the system that supports it. When people vote for communism, they have never received what they thought they were going to get. Many people will criticize capitalistic society as a plutocracy, or worry about the emergence of one. The benefit to a capitalist free nation like the United States is that we can enact laws to prevent this from happening. It is indeed feasible to create a system where people can enjoy the right to free enterprise without allowing that enterprise to get out of control, provided we elect the right leaders and pass the right laws. However, by voting for a communist regime to take power, you are inherently voting for a plutocracy. Collectivist systems like communism are idealistic, and assume that no matter how many attempts at this have resulted in extreme suffering, oppression, or abject failure, one day someone will do it right. This is not a an optimistic endeavor to pursue. Whether it's the history of 100 million deaths, or the fact that people are still risking their lives to escape it today, we must take the idea of implementing it into any part of the world with great caution.
For all of it's history and flaws, capitalism has comparably fared much better overall in improving the lives of citizens under it. It is a system that mimics the natural world. A system that acknowledges that while not all things can be equal in every sphere, equality cannot simply be artificially imposed on the world. Capitalism has been and still is the most reliable and efficient mode of innovation, of raising the overall standard of living for all people, and remains the economic system that provides the greatest amount of liberty to every individual citizen. It cannot be stressed enough, that the radical collectivist systems of the world seem to be fundamentally at odds with the notions of individual, inalienable rights and liberty we take for granted in the US. It's important to remember that communism is not just an economic system, but a political one primarily, and politics is the game bureaucrats play to test to what extent they can dictate your life.
It can be confusing to parse, sometimes, but when we look back at the US, it is a crucial difference that the people control the economy, not the government. While government can make rules and regulations about business practices, they cannot take that business away from you. The notion of free enterprise is inherently power in the hands of the people. It is not something we should be willing to give up, because if we change our minds, who knows how many years, decades, or lives it might cost to get it back. Communism always starts as some form of grassroots "people's movement," but overtime inevitably grows to the oppressive hierarchical power structure they didn't want. Remember this, and also remember to be inherently distrustful of all big government. At the end of the day, big government is always interested in trying to control something, so be wary of what it is they're seeking to control. Lastly, be very careful what your asking for of it, because you might not always like what you get in the end.

comment:
Hey, I loved your analysis! Seriously. I'm happy to see a female having success with these types of videoes. I don't usually like to highlight gender, but I have noticed, that all of my favorite film-analysis and music-analysis channels, are all run by men. This led me to asking myself; whether people would actually listen to a woman talk about this stuff. Since we're so used to men being the authority in cinema. But it seems that people are listening, and I'm just happy to see that.

Edit: I just want to clarify; I'm not saying that I think women are being discriminated against on the platform. I'm saying, I haven't seen many of them, and that I am happy to see one be successfull with this type of stuff. That is all.

Kim ends up imprisoned in the bunker just like the former housekeepers husband Oh Guen -sae previously was. Kim's son is aware of this through Morse code messages his father sends. Just like Da-Song was aware of Oh Guen -sae he translated the cry of help from Oh Guen-sae but did nothing to help, did not alert his parents he knew they were already aware of this consciously or not. He had tried to tell them before on another birthday when he seen 'the monster'. Da-Song was not allowed to mention the divide the line. Hence his anxiety, hyper activity. Da-Songs parents hoped the scenario they planned for him at his birthday at home when Park So-Dam presented his cake would be healing. Instead what happened was possibly something Da-Song saw coming all along. Something that he was playing out whilst trying to resolve; in the game of cowboys and Indians. It seems Da-Song had more insight into his environment than the adults, hence his constant state of hyper activity / anxiety. He was aware of the two worlds. His mum Yeon Kyo told Park So-Dam who pretended to be an art therapist that she 'cannot speak' of what upset Da-Song and became tearful.

At his birthday party, Da-Song was the cowboy and his father and family driver the Indians the minorities. Not sure if that was a symbol of anything.

The families house staff were not even perceived as human, just commodities. Mr Parks left the dying in the garden and had turned his back on all of them.

comment: Fuck outta here with this narrative that "Rich people are parasites because they exploit laborers". They do no such thing. They pay them "fair" value based on equilibrium market prices. Anyone with two arms and half a brain can build an iPhone (Which is becoming more and more automated every year anyway). When there's hundreds of millions of people worldwide with no other marketable skills than those pertaining to doing menial labor then of course their compensation is going to be very little. It's just the way the market works. The Park family did absolutely nothing wrong throughout the movie. They did't leach off anyone. Mr. Park built a highly successful technology company. Hence why he can afford the nice house. He had a valuable idea and made a valuable contribution to society. Mr. Kim has been through dozens of failed ventures. He just doesn't have what it takes. Hence why he is poor. That's not wrong. That's just how life works. The poor in this movie are very much the eponymous "parasites". The rich people are their victims.
author: MoMoneyLessProblems

comment:
Parasite was a hard film to stomach. Often times I definitely think that middle class and lower class communities are allied in a sense against the rich and the oppressive capitalist systems. But Parasite tells the truth that a lot of us middle class and lower class folks don't want to admit. That we often times admire or even worship the wealthy, in hopes that we can get a taste of the life they get to live. We would rather fight each other for scraps and attempt to "eliminate our competition" than unite and try to find a way to dismantle the system and people that put us against one another in the first place.

The Kim family didn't stop to think about the jobs they were stealing and the lives they were ruining by taking them. The original housekeeper had safety in the Park home, away from loan sharks and access to her husband to keep him fed and to check on him. Then she was kicked out from her safe haven, couldn't even tell her husband what happened probably. Mrs. Kim looks down on the housekeeper, accepting the role she has as an upper class housekeeper over the jobless, beaten and desperate lower class former housekeeper. She cannot empathize with her anymore. Even though promising to feed her husband would be such an easy and harmless thing to do, she refuses. The conflict could have been mostly avoided had she not forgotten where she comes from and empathized with the woman and agreed to help her out in such a small way.

Everybody in Parasite is a parasite and a host simultaneously. The poor are hosts to the rich parasites, being used for their mostly cheap labor, doing unfulfilling and draining tasks for low wages, just trying to survive themselves. The poor are parasites to the rich hosts by manipulating them and using them to hopefully advance their social and economic class further up. They didn't care what happened to the people they got fired. They didn't care about the Park family as people, except for maybe Da-Hye who while blissfully was able to enjoy her privilege of wealth, didn't actively think badly of the poor and even despite Kevin and his family smelling like "poor" she still found him attractive.

She became a victim by having her seemingly normal boyfriend being bludgeoned and having to carry him to safety, learning later on that the driver killed her father, the driver who is her boyfriend's father, how her boyfriend's entire family was using her family and that her boyfriend was never really who he said he was, she fell in love with a person that he was not, a person who is later just outed as a scammer along with his mother, permanently living with brain damage. The reason parasite was so good, I believe, is because it wasn't the straight forward "rich people bad" commentary a lot of us expected. It was commentary on capitalist society as a whole, and how even the good intentioned or those who are taking an opportunity for a better life are not all innocent. How we all have blood on our hands.

Watching the Kim family and the housekeeper and her husband fight like animals was one of the harder scenes to watch. How one poor family threatened the other poor family with exposing them for who they truly are in hopes to tear them down the same way they tore them down or maybe even in hopes of getting her job back. How one poor family murdered "one of them" just to keep up with their facade for not even much longer. Only when the Kim family loses everything they had going for them, do they gain some sort of empathy and human-ness back. There seems to be lots of regret, lots of remorse. Losing a daughter, losing a sister but not being able to truly grieve because you have brain damage, losing the chance of normalcy you got only a taste of because you became the very thing you hated or envied, greedy parasites.

comment:
I think a perfect world would be one where those who have the ability and funding to help others do so and sacrifice excess wealth to improve QoL for their fellow humans. In return, those who receive aid do not take it for granted but use said aid wisely and productively to improve their means, and not take advantage of it.

However, our current problem is that robber barons have become the norm and not the exception. They make their wealth on the toil of slaves and at the health of the global environment while influencing politicians to enact legislation that favors them over the proletariat.

Cyberpunk dystopias are a common stereotype, but it really seems more and more accurate. At some point this veil will become entirely unnecessary.

comment: I disagree with people saying "everyone is a parasite" and "everyone is morally ambiguous." The poor family used manipulation and forgery and murder. There is nothing "morally ambiguous" about it. Regarding the "everyone is a parasite argument." Why are people saying the rich family is leeching? They pay the poor family generous amounts of money and it's not like they're doing charity work. It's a job just like anything else to be a tutor, maid, driver, etc. A job is a two way transaction. So unless I am missing something, the Park family never leeched off of any body. People also argue that Mr. Park is a parasite because without his workers, there would not be a company. But I'd argue that Mr. Park is the one that takes the liability and risk for making a company in the first place, buying property, handling insurance, fees, equipment, manufacturing, resources, etc. If his company goes under, his workers can simply find another job, but he will be screwed.
author: TeeSharp

comment: Interesting movie.  Nice analysis.  While capitalism does lead to exploitation of an underclass, it does, in fact, allow anyone from the underclass to move into the upper echelon of society.  By the same token, people in the upper echelon can easily move into the underclass.   It happens all the time.  Possibly not in one generation, but often it does.  The same cannot be said of communism.   There,  only people within the government are in the upper class, and everyone else is exploited.  Socialism is somewhere in between, but is likely to have more barriers, not less, to movement from lower to higher...and vice-versa.  The "safety net" protects people from becoming "too poor" (in theory), but also takes so much of their income to pay for it that it makes it harder to advance.

author: Haru Chan

comment: Great explanation, but my problem with social safety nets is that certain policies, like socialized medicine, don't scale up well. Many people site how safety nets work well for countries like Norway, Sweden and Canada, but fail to realize that all these countries, even if you put all their populations together,  have a grand total population of less than 100 million people. We can't expect policies that have worked for these small population countries to work for a country like the US that has a population of almost 300 million as the compound effect is VERY powerful in large population countries. The cost of socialized medicine would be ridiculously unsustainable in the US due to the population size and how population density varies from state to state. Just because it worked for them, doesn't mean it will work for the USA.

comment:
Did you even watch the video?
It's not a symbiotic relationship, Parasite is a layered definition of what we see. To put it simply, we observe on the outside that the poor family is the parasite leeching off of the rich family, taking advantage of them in order to get good jobs. But in reality, it's the rich family that is only able to maintain their position because of the poor in the first place. If there were no poor people, the rich could no longer sustain such lifestyles. It would crumble very quickly.

comment: A note to the 564 years to buy that house fact: You won't ever achieve higher by saving, which is why the note on saving hundreds of years worth of money based on an average or minimum is stupid, and the reason for that is the following; saving as a strategy to retain and increase wealth tied to an income source (like a job) that stays the same or increases too little, is depending on a lineal growth which is tending to 0, because the expenses are the same and the income is the same, which means the savings are never enough to make a difference, plus, the strategy is vulnerable to a psyche of "Now I have more and can allow myself more" which means that when there's a slight increase in the income, there's a slight increase in the spending, over the years, when the increase starts getting big compared to starting point, the increase in the spending has become big too, the best example is when a new hire earns the minimum allowed for its job post and education, over the years this person attains a higher pay through a higher job and antiquity/experience, eg: mid-managerial position, but by then this person has stopped spending on the basic needs, own housing, transport and plans with friends, or helping the parents if living with them, instead they pay a mid-tier car, nicer clothing, nicer living, maybe kids, etc... In the worst case they're thrown in a curve of decrease and they can't even afford their livestyle, the most fatal flaw of that strategy, and helps to further deepen that situation by the other dinamic involved in this: positive interest and debt. These two can be deemed as the outside factor of the strategy that doesn't fit in, because they can be exponential, due to the interest rates. Positive interest will refer here to the payments the bank does for lending them your money by keeping it there (what most do, if you're lending money outside of that context it's another story) while debt is when  you do the opposite through any entity (bank, institution, person, etc...) the trick is, generally when people get carried out (and most get carried out) they're inflating their debt more than what they're collecting from the debtors, the reason being that the payout of the bank is lesser than what they're expecting from you. Further, the dependance of people on systems of income that depend on their human availabilities and usually 1 only source (this is refering to 1 job or 2 jobs) doesn't allow them to grow in this regard, and things like having kids when not able to care for them in excellence (hence, making these children bad investments and a way to destroy the savings via increasing the costs while having no new income sources) just make it worse. This is what most people don't understand and that's part of why these crazy numbers come up, it is obvious you can't go as fast as an sports car if you keep doing what the slower cyclist is doing.

People who lean against capitalisam after watching this need to realize few things.
It's still the best economics system that humans came up with. Labor is not the only factor for earning money, but how much responsibility and risk can a person take. If you want to just work without thinking you will get minimum wage, and that's fine. But your right to complain because you bare almost no responsibility or risk. Also, individuals have the greatest impact over how big businises behave. Almost eveeryone knows about the apple explotations, and yet you still buy their overpriced shiny phones. What if people just stop buying their products until they treat their employees fairly? They will have to stop or they will go bancrupt.
WE ARE COGS IN A MACHINE, BUT IF WE MOVE TOGETHER WE CONTROL THE MACHINE

comment:
You assume hard work is the only way to climb the social ladder. If that is the case then yeah, all the odds are against you in a capitalistic society. But If you look at the people you show as 'rich' today, lets take Mark Zuckerberg, he became rich off an idea. There is not rich keeping him from becoming rich.
You ignore the power of knowledge and innovation. Hard work is just the fall back of people who fail at those two. Hard work is never supposed to give you an edge, because everyone is hard working. You take this lack of edge and call it a lack of opportunity when opportunity is always there for people who are intelligent and bring new things.
I wonder what society structure you can cook up that is better than this coz there is none. Your argument seems to come from some one who is going to be stuck being poor in a society that values knowledge and innovation. You want to destroy these things and make it 'equal' for everyone because thats the only way you can win.

comment:
What scares me the most is the message that this movie sends: "A Glass of Soju" or ÏÜåÏ£º ÌïúÏûî

If you listen to this song, imagine Kiwoo working (in the upbeat and energetic). He's full of hope as how lively that part was. But in the part Îπ®Í∞Ñ ÎÇ¥ Ïò§Î•∏Ï™Ω Î∫®Ïóê Ïù¥Ï†úÏïº ÎπÑÍ∞Ä Ïò§ÎÑ§ (And finally rains (tears) on my flushed right cheek), the song drastically changed into a sadder tone. Flushed cheeks because he is getting drunk of soju, thinking about his tiring work that no matter how much effort he put into that cycle of works, he will never reach his goal (but the house where his father is hiding in the underground) but just cry. He pours his sadness through drinking soju and getting drunk.

Take note of the ÏÜêÌÜ± Î∞ëÏóê ÎÇÄ ÎïåÍ∞Ä Ï¥âÏ¥âÌï¥ (Dirt under my fingernails get moist). This line sends a signal that he is frustated. How can a dirt under his fingernails be moist? Yes, when he pulls nd scratches his sweaty and stressed head real hard. Thinking of what will happen tomorrow and the following day and so on... if what he is currently doing will help him... or not.


This sums up the ending of Parasite movie: Ki-woo has no hope of saving his father. His father will die alone in that underground basement.

author: Nicole Van Overmeiren

comment:
‚Äã@Jankins Late capitalism specifically describes the dysfunction, injustices, absurdities, and contradictions that are inherent to societies dominated by capitalism. However the sense that capitalism itself is "invisible" isn't really about the objective aspects of the capitalist production, but in how capitalism has become so pervasive that it, along with it's dysfunction, injustices, absurdities, and contradictions, has come to be perceived as so normal and natural that we cannot imagine the world any other way (an ideology the late Mark Fisher refers to as "capitalist realism").

A great allegory of this is actually provided in another movie by Bong Joon-ho: Snowpiercer. In that movie where a train harbouring remnants of humanity endlessly circles the post-apocalyptic world the train has come to be perceived by nearly all it's inhabitants, from the brutally oppressed at the back to the ruling classes at the front, as the entire world. Because of their inability or unwillingness to think beyond the world of the train the solution pursued by the oppressed to liberate themselves from their situation is confined to upturning the social hierarchy of the train and installing themselves as the ruling class, therefore perpetuating the brutal system of oppression inherent to the train.

comment:
First I'm very grateful for you for having posted such value content. Most of us wouldn't have been able to interpret the movie and the director's vision as accurately the way you did here (me included). This one was a real eye opener. Will probably watch it again.
Now that we live in such terrifying conditions (neoliberal capitalism...). There are questions that come to mind such as:
Isn't all of this just the workings of human nature?
What can be the solution?
Before thinking about answering this questions I would like to use quotes from books to establish some undeniabe facts first.
About the so called game of rich being winners and poor being loosers. The game of power perhaps?
As the great renaissance diplomat and courtier Niccol√≤ Machiavelli wrote, "Any man who tries to be good all the time is bound to come to ruin among the great number who are not good." The court imagined itself the pinnacle of refinement, but underneath its glittering surface a cauldron of dark emotions-greed, envy, lust, hatred- boiled and simmered.
(A Cauldron is a large cast iron pot for cooking or boiling over an open fire, with a large pot and frequently with an arc-shaped hanger. Courtesy of Wikipedia).
Meanwhile the court was supposed to represent the height of civilization and refinement.
Our world today similarly imagines itself the pinnacle of fairness, yet the same ugly emotions still stir within us, as they have forever. The game is the same.
Now these above mentioned ugly emotions... They are just as real as a lighthouse is to a ship, they are principles, they are traits of our human nature. They are as real as a ship smashing into the rocks at night because of ignoring the warning, the lighthouse is signaling. [chuckles...]
So in this scenario the cause of all evil in this world roots therefore from human nature. And in light of this we can ask ourselves:
What can we do about it?
There is one answer that could be:
If the world is like a giant scheming court and we are trapped inside it, there is no use in trying to opt out of the game. That will only render you powerless and powerlessness will make you miserable. Instead of struggling against the inevitable (human nature), instead of arguing and whining and feeling guilty, it is far better to excel at power. If the game of power is inescapable, better to be an artist than a denier or a bungler. To transform yourself into a superior actor on the stage of life and enjoy your moment in the limelight.

The above mentionned answer could certainly be the way to the self-destruction of humanity. Today the ultimate power being the pocession nuclear weapons.

The other and second answer is the following: (Here I quote the great Osho)
[The world is certainly preparing for a global suicide, about that there are not two options - it is becoming every day more and more certain. Naturally you think you have to do somthing to prevent it. (just like my 3 questions in the begining)
It is beyond your doing, beyond your control; whatever you do will bring it closer.
What can you do? The power is not your hands; the power is in hands which are absolutely stubborn, and they don't care a bit what happens to humanity. Their ego is their supreme value, the only value. Even though it means their own destruction, they will take the risk; they will destroy whoever the think is their enemy.
In the beginning, when this kind of war material was in the hands of two countries, the Soviet Union and America, there was some possibility that they may come to some negociation. Now with the power of nuclear weapons in five countries, the possibility of negociation has become more difficult, more complicated. And by the time when the power will be in twenty-five countrie's hands. Then the question of negociation does not arise. My suggestion is: time is certainly very short, but it is enough to become enlightned, and it is enough to spread an enlighned atmosphere around the world. That is the only possibility.
If we can make the people of the world...not the politicians, leave them aside; they have the power but without the consent of the people of the world, their power is not of much use. If armies simply say, "No, we are not going to use nuclear weapons," if scientists simply say, "No, we are not going to produce any more nuclear weapons," if the whole intelligentsia of the world unanimously creates a great uproar: "It is not a question of war; wars we have seen in thousands - they have been destructive, but they have not destroyed all life. This is not war, this is simple suicide!".
But these people: the scientists, the armies, the intelligentsia, the poets, the musicians, the mystics, the painters, the actors - the people who have a certain impact on the masses, although they don't have any power except their individuality and their creativity - if they join hands together, this global suicide can be avoided. Not only suicide can be avoided, but with the same energy that was going to destroy all life, the planet can be turned into a paradise. ]

Now obviously this went beyond the scope of capitalism and rich and poor but it is all connected
But yeah here are two great answers. Food for though!
This video was so though provoking, I had to write this essay.

comment:
You make some great points, however, I don't think we can ignore either direction of parasitism. I think ultimately, both families being parasitic on each other points to capitalistic idealism being parasitic on genuine human relationship and society. Vilifying the rich doesn't really solve the problem. Both the rich and poor are involved in a larger vicious system which idealizes the situation of the Parks. But as we see, the Park's lifestyle isn't ideal because even their interfamilial relationships are diminished by this idealization of wealth, and even they suffer the effects of the divisions of class. They try to block out the pain of life, not only as represented by the poor, but also as represented by their own flaws, weaknesses, and suffering. Even they are slaves to the idealization of wealth and wealthy living, and are unable to really be satisfied by it. We see this in the juxtaposition of the Kim family's assumptions that wealth makes it easier to love, and easier to be nice, and the stark reality that both families really love each other while still struggling to love authentically, and both families uphold a false air of niceness, while still sometimes being truly nice, at least to each other. Neither family is simply virtuous or vicious, but both struggle to be truly nice and loving, especially in the face of the pursuit of wealth.
Thus, it does not good to simply treat the rich as the source of the problem. They too are enslaved to the idealization of wealthy living, as even their own attainment of it cannot satisfy, and they are always looking for new sources and displays of affluence to distract from the pain of life. The Kims, insofar as they have affluence to flaunt, do so readily (think of their treatment of the drunk outside their home). Neither family is simply at fault, and both families display a vicious parasitism, even though the lower class Kim family's parasitism is more visible and more immediately shocking. They are problematic and vicious in different ways, but ultimately they are tied to the same source: Capitalistic idealism. Both families treat wealth as the solution to all problems. Both families are ultimately "destroyed" by this, by the separation, wounding, and death of their members. Though the Parks "escape" the violence and the Kims must face it every day since they are still in their home, it is interesting that it is the Parks home where this all takes place. Both have their lives upended by this cruel reality of capitalist idealism. Both presumably continue in this idealism even in the face of that violence. This is the true horror.
author: Icepick L

comment:
This is a really good explanation of the social classes between the rich and poor. but I feel like you're failing to see the other side of the coin.

This film had a very fresh and unpopular theme and I think that's what set it to be the best picture of the year. Instead of the typical stories where the upper class is about oppressing the lower, it views it in a neutral light about it all. Where most films about social class see things as black and white, Parasite presented it in a shade of grey. That it's about the parasites in society in general. It goes as far as to sometimes paint the poor as the bad guys, especially when they meet people who were worse off, or "poorer," than them. I know it sounds terrible to say, but I think that's what is so bold about this film and what set it apart from your average stories about class. I think it's the reason why Knives Out wasn't put on the same level as Parasite, despite it also being about social class. It paints it so obviously who is good and who is bad.

Bong has said some of this himself, in an interview before the Oscars and please forgive me as I couldn't find the source, he said something along the lines of, "Growing up, sometimes I thought we were poor but then I would see people who were much worse off than myself and realized we were very fortunate actually, suddenly I felt like we weren't very poor at all." I wish I could find the quote but I think it was a spoken interview.

I might be wrong on this but one of the things that stuck out to me in the film was that there were the many times throughout the movie where the father and mother behave a bit dark showing lack of certain virtues. "I'd be nice too if I were rich" was said by the mother but then is shown she is willing to kill someone to protect their wealth. The father had times where he's tested on his morality, you can't shake away the moment when they were getting drunk and he nearly hits his wife and plays it off as a joke. When he is driving the car for the rich dad, he shows a lack of self discipline when he continues to turn around and not pay attention on the road. When the rich father, during the son's birthday, wanted to pretend to be Indians for his son to enjoy himself, the poor father asks him, "Why do you do all this?" The rich father replies, "Because I love my son," to which the poor father stops and seems to reflect on that saying "Because you love your son..."

One of the most important things about the film that would've been cool to see in this video is the way the poor perceived what being rich meant, overindulgence. It's a common theme in films about wealth that some view that being rich means living excessively. To put it more simply, you can still be poor even if you have all the money in the world.

Also I want to bring up a quote from "All the Money in the World" that I think relates to the overall picture of what being poor can mean. Near the beginning of the film, the father somberly tells Amy Adams, "I'm sorry that we are poor," and she replies, "We're not poor, we're just broke."

comment:
At first, I thought the gas was poison, and that the family would turn into monsters psychologically, and dominate the Parks. This is what I got from the trailer: confusion. I wanted to know what was going on so I watched it and I was so so so so so so wrong.
This is why I think the movie is called Parasite. The parasite is in society, society is messed up but doesn‚Äôt know how to fix it and when. Society is already engraved in our minds. Rich high up and Poor way down. Even their houses show this the Kims live in a basement with the window on street levels. They are literally and socially below ground and the Parks have a huge house up above ground, with two stories and a backyard. They are way up there.
Society is like plastic. It won‚Äôt go away for a long time and will start dominating everything. When you try to rip through society you will get pushed back farther. The Kims were trying to rip through but ended up far worse than worse. Losing two family members, one dead, one wanted.

comment: 4:52 love the video but I'd also like to add that the basement guy is not just an allegory for the hidden lower class under clean and cool capitalism. I think he and his wife are an allegory for North Korean people/ people living in abject poverty. His favourite thing for his wife to do is pretending to be the North Korean newsreader. He worships Mr Park for providing for him, like North Korean people worship their leader. His communication to the outside world is disconnected except for his relative (wife) living outside his prison. The director is introducing the concept of "lower than lower class", who absolutely cannot afford any of the small materialist pleasures other lower class people might have, and how other lower class people have fear for falling into that position in life, driven crazy by poverty.

comment: I understand the disparity between the dirt poor and rich, as I am a broke college student. What I don‚Äôt understand is how it is fair to make the rich feel bad for what they have. Yes the poor have to work hard for what they need and some rich folk don‚Äôt need anything. But that‚Äôs the cards they were dealt. Just because someone had it better doesn‚Äôt justify an issue, you have to suck it up and carry on (like many do). Who are we to question them? They are living there own lives. Might some use poor people to do all their work? Yes. But do they have a gun to their head? No. I just don‚Äôt think its fair to be mad at the rich for what they have or what they were able to achieve. Instead of being spiteful, go out and become that rich person, if you have to work like a dog then do it, but don‚Äôt complain about others having it easy because it will always be like that, there has been a disparity in the powerful and the poor since the dawn of man and it will always be this way. There is no possible way everyone will be on the same playing field, it is up to you if you make the cut.
author: Dillon

comment: Dillon Because most of the rich don‚Äôt ‚Äúwork like dogs‚Äù to be where they‚Äôre at. People like corporate CEOs profit from the labors performed by lower-working classes that make their money for them, who still find themselves stuck in poverty no matter how hard they work. Jeff Bezos isn‚Äôt getting up every day to send out Amazon packages and move boxes around in the warehouses, is he? The end of the movie even touches on this, where Ki-Woo is shown to have made enough money to buy the house like he wrote to his dad. It then pans back to him sitting with a hopeless expression in his home, and the bleak reality that he will never be able to make that much money in his life. No matter how hard someone works, it is nearly impossible for most to achieve such a high economic status, and the notion that anyone can get rich through pure, hard work is a fantasy that tons of people still buy into to this day. If this were even true, there would be a lot less working poor in the world, don‚Äôt you think? The whole issue with sucking it up and taking the ‚Äúcards you are dealt with‚Äù is that the ‚Äúcard-dealing‚Äù is built upon an exploitative system that favors the rich, making them richer whilst keeping the poor poor at the same time. We live in a broken system, and there‚Äôs no reason that the disparity between the rich and poor needs to exist. It does not have to be this way, and it shouldn‚Äôt. No one person should have billions of dollars, especially dollars that they‚Äôre collecting off the work of the poorer classes they take advantage of. There are so many people who work their asses off and won‚Äôt see even a fraction of that amount of money within their lifetime. Still seem unfair to be mad?

author: genti

comment:
It's also very interesting how they showed, how far one will go to escape poverty and what poverty forces you to do. The Kims have every worker except Min get fired for their own benefit, to replace their position. As they are getting drunk in the house the father is kind of concerned about the previous driver but Kevin just throws it off, saying he was young and pretty, therefore he must have found anothet job by this time, when in reality there was no way for him to know. Then minutes later when finding out about the previous Housmaids husband and while she plead for help, Mrs. Kim refused to help and even threaten to call the police to gain control over the situation. They were all so caught up on their lie, they forgot they both are still poor and in need of money, but instead of helping they have killed each other. So in reality, they never were concerned for the workers before them, as long as they make it out of poverty, they were willing to fight till death, cause beeing poor was already living hell.
Also very interesting is how Kim shames the basement guy for "living like this" but is left speechless when he replies with "a lot of people live in basements", clarifying that the Kims and him are on the same grade, yet Mr Kim had absolutely forgotten from where he himself came from. I think this is also the reason why he was so hurt by the family saying he smells weird, now having to face reality that they do not think of him or his family as equals as he believed since they were so kind to them, but have seen him just as the lesser being like he saw the basement guy at some point.

author: Evie

comment:
There are a couple quick but subtle breaks in the 1st and early 2nd act that hints something different is to come.

While Mr. Kim is driving Mr. Park we see Kim's eyes not on the road which almost causes them to crash into a lane-changing semi truck. The moment is a little jarring and as a viewer we begin to think that things are not as in control as we had thought.

As the art tutoring Jessica is ad libing a theory on Mrs. Park's son, the shift of Mrs. Park's scream is equally unsettling. What Mrs. Park's scream meant is a foreshadowing that we don't get to see until much later.

The last moment I really appreciated is when Mr. Kim fakes us and the family out by pretending to threaten the mother. We go from laughing and drinking to a very uncomfortable moment. Kim plays the part of an abusive husband very well... And it leaves us wondering about their past and what he is capable of.

I'm kind of surprised that I haven't seen Romeo & Juliet mentioned in any of these videos about Parasite yet. I wasn't thinking about R&J during the movie, it wasn't until a little while after when I was thinking about it.

There might not be many parallels other than a relationship between the children from two different families, and the fact that it ends in tragedy. Maybe someone who knows Shakespeare really well could find more.

Would make a lot more sense if one of the kids in the relationship was the one to die. Then it could be another commentary on how tragedy tends to affect the poor the most.... but that point was certainly hammered home enough.

comment: Hello Broey Deschanel! First off, love the name! Second, I just read your pinned comment, and you don't need to apologize for putting in that commercial for the skin-whitening product. In fact, it is spot-on! As a Filipino myself, I agree that the obsession of having white (r) skin is ultimately tied to classism. In fact, the commercial explicitly says "para sa puting pang-dyosa", which (loosely) translates to "white skin like a goddess". I mean, why? Does this mean if I don't have white skin, I am not a 'goddess', therefore I am just an ordinary mortal and therefore "less than"? And don't even get me started on the (strange?) coincidence that the actress in that commercial is Heart Evangelista, who is beyond rich and privileged! Getting back to my point earlier, a discussion on skin color ultimately leads to classism - Refinery29 did this documentary about skin whitening in Asia and the women (a lot of them Filipina) that they interviewed explicitly confirmed that having white skin leads to greater, better opportunities as opposed to having darker skinned.

comment: 10:50 I disagree. I believe in the west, we do have a lot of mobility. My family and I escaped Iraq and Syria with $22000 in debt because we could not afford the flight to Canada, and we owed money to the furniture company as my dad worked in a factory. 10 years later, I managed to get an engineering degree and paid off nearly $38000 of my own student debt, and now almost paying our $22000 in family debt. Life is truly filled with opportunities if you work hard enough for it. Obviously, some people did not make it out of the middle east. There was a lot of elements of luck in terms of surviving the war. But once we arrived in Canada, life was gradually getting better for us. The idea that you can't improve your life financially from nothing is absolute propaganda.

comment: This movie wasn‚Äôt good. It was overhyped and non coherent in writing. I watched this video till the end, the movie never says any of this. It‚Äôs a complete interpretation of the content creator, and if the creators of this movie think the same they‚Äôve done a poor job of conveying that message in the film. This video is U.S. Democratic Party talking points set to the movie in the form of a review, completely interpreted as the narrator saw fit; I believe that ‚ÄúParasite‚Äù is glorified because it‚Äôs a foreign film. If it were made in America by White people, starring other White people, then no one would care. The movie was better than a few Oscar picks though, and the gatekeeping in Hollywood as well as their cherry picking is straight up disgusting. Entertainment, as most things, need a hell of a lot more work
author: WacoDraco

comment: Overall, I think the moral of the story is that there will alwayss be someone "beneath" you. And there's no telling exactly how or why. Capitalism is real, poverty is real, but ultimately, death is assured to everyone. And within life, people are always trying to chase the next thing or maintain what they already have- what may seem like greed to some may be practical, even righteous to others. But most people get a taste of each "side" within their lifetime. That's where privilege gets tricky. Like when rich mom (i watched the movie a while ago so i forgot names) talked about how she used to ride the subway. And the daughter getting to have that bath. I used to live in LA and it is the greatest example of this, probably in the world. You have some of the richest, most successful people in the country living amongst an increasing homeless population. Some of the homeless used to live perfectly normal lives- perhaps even middle or upper class. Yet drugs left them with close to nothing. And yet, the drug crisis is a prominent issue among the upper class as well. I know I went all over the place, but this topic is such a trip. And this film captured the dramatic, horrific, and sometimes comical nature of it all.

comment: Another way this movie describes the divide between the rich and the poor is the direction everything flows. For example, the water flows from the top, where the Parks live, to the very bottom, where it devastated the poor. We also almost never see the Parks go down the stairs in the movie, but rather always go up, while it is the opposite with the poor family, where we almost always see them going down. It shows how this class divide causes all the poor to get the sewage water, the burden on their backs, while the rich constantly keep going up, benefiting from their suffering.

comment: Interesting insight. I really don't think that late capitalism was the main antagonized idea, however. And you mention there is a simple fix for some of the issues of the wealthy living off the poor, but I daresay that this problem has persisted with feudalism,.capitalism, socialism, communism, and every other economic structure. I think the real downfall of both the poor AND the rich in this film was exactly what the rock represented: the pursuit of wealth and it destructiveness to all humankind---wealthy or poor. Greed becomes a driving force that leads them all to tragedy.

comment:
I warned my gf that she needs to be ready physically and mentally for an Oscar winner movie. She wasn't in her best state (she was late for a few days and she was having some stress too) and still decided to watch it with me.
During the movie (especially right before and after the old house keeper return), she had to stand up and walk around the room, bc the movie made her hard to breathe.
Around 10 minutes after the movie, she started to cry uncontrollably without actual reason. At one point she was almost screaming too and I had to shush her down.
She was mad at me afterwards but I'd rather suffer that lol.
That's when I know how much powerful storytelling could do to a person.

author: Araceli Blanes

comment:
there's also a lot of geopolitical commentary in many of the details, which could mirror the analysis laid out in this video on a greater, global scale. aside from the housekeeper's impersonation of a North Korean newscaster and her threat to send the incriminating video evidence as if it were a missile, the film includes sardonic details that underscore colonialism in modern history:
- the tune that the daughter uses to memorize her backstory is actually a very famous song titled ÎèÖÎèÑÎäî Ïö∞Î¶¨ÎïÖ (Dokdo is Our Land) - a Korean island in the East Sea that Japan has been wrongfully disputing over the years as their territorial possession from their days of colonial oppression over Korea.
- ÏßúÌååÍµ¨Î¶¨ ("Ram-Don") is half Chinese-style ramen (ÏßúÌååÍ≤åÌã∞) and half Japanese-style ramen (ÎÑàÍµ¨Î¶¨) served to the wealthy wife in the film, symbolizing two power nations that have colonized Korea at some point in history.
- When the wealthy wife describes how she wants the party tables to be arranged, she describes them as a fleet of Japanese warships surrounding the tent that would stand in for Admiral Yi Sun-Sin's Í±∞Î∂ÅÏÑ† warship (Korean admiral and military general in the Joseon dynasty that took down 133 warships with 13 ships in the battle of Myeongnyang)
- The birthday boy's party theme (defeating the "savage" Native Americans) is a more blatant jab at colonialism that most global audience can recognize.
author: Eugene Kong

comment:
There's more: meta-ly, Bong agreed on dubbing the movie, but in French and intentionally not in English.

Kevin and Jessica were hired in large part due to their American personas (e.g. English names) and prestige (i.e. "Illinois, Chicago" but it's in that order for the Orient like the date, YYYY.MM.DD., c.f. the cremation urn dates) rather than actual tutelage efficacy.

Hiring had more to do with the image of foreign is best (Western educated tutors, Western psychotherapy, Western cooks and operatic songstresses) than real chops.

The food that the rich housewife orders is not native to Korea as well, and she often uses English phrases in her speech, much as how New Englanders used French words and phrases to accentuate their classiness.

The first basement husband says RESPECT in perfect English, reflecting he genuinely understands and means the original meaning of the word. It's important that he doesn't say it as Li Su Pec Tu; transliteration implies an understanding through the lens and understanding of another language.

There's a strong disdain for the Anglicization or, more accurately, the Americanization of modern Korean culture and language. It was the central theme of Metal Gear Solid V, and is more subtly featured here, albeit indirectly and allegorically.

comment:
So called 'exploitation' generates Two things. product and profit(If you are good at it).
'I got the product they got the profit. so I can call them evil' is pure Emo nonsense. As if you're wanna give them 'fair' wage but apple won't let you? you are user of them just like apple.
this movie Predicated on the fact that people hate those who has more then them. just flip their economic status see how it would look. the rich family broke into poor peoples households and listen to them drunk out their mind.


I'm a manual laborer in south korea. I hate smelly people. and my relatives has those 'lower class' houses. those houses goes for over a half a million US dollar in a cheap parts of Seoul. and averages near million US dollar. And over in a slight better schooling district.
And no family with two grown ass children rent those rooms. those are for broke freshmen college kids. and head of the family has jobs.


Our economy grow so fast it just look dated like bad 90's printed t-shirts. just few decades ago majority of korean population lived in clay walled straw roofed house just like my parents. And I'm a millennial.
But. to the rich nations like US or Europe. they look broke as hell. director exploited that and got a bunch of award from said rich nations.


don't get me wrong the director is not a heck. but the movie pay absolute obedience to the zeitgeist we follow. like a good christian tale in a dark ages. I mean who doesn't wanna see rich people getting stabbed?

comment: There is also the connection that late stage capitalism is essentially modern feudalism. In feudal times everyone was a servant to their lord, but the servants closest to the lord (such as Knights and squires) held higher social prestige then those serving the lord from outside his sight (the peasants). We see a direct comparison here where the best jobs were those where they directly served the Parks, and not the jobs where they were just cogs in the system. Like the pizza box folding job where they were completely invisible to the ruling elites, but still to a certain capacity serving them.

author: kha

comment: ‚Äã@Leo Leyva Being pale was linked to wealth because people could afford to stay indoors, meanwhile poor people were working manual jobs outside in the sun. It has nothing to do with race, they're not telling black people they need to be pale to be pretty, it's just their own race thinks being paler is prettier on themselves. I don't agree with the beauty standard, because I think all skin tones are beautiful, especially the darker South and South East skin tones, but there's no racial superiority link to the beauty standard. And actually, most European countries see being tanned as the beauty standard. For the same reasons. Having a darker complexion is seen as desirable in many European countries because it was linked to being wealthy in the 1900s and having the time to relax in the sun and go on holiday, while poorer people didn't have that luxury so didn't really tan (as European jobs in the 1900s weren't so much outside jobs as they were in offices and factories). Neither the desire for being pale or for being tanned is racist though, as they're not enforcing that beauty standard on someone of another race.

comment: I don't even know where to start. This movie is a roller-coaster ride. First, you'll laugh at how witty the family is then feel really really nervous in the basement part and when the poor family is cleaning all the mess they made. Then the dark concept started to rise during the flood. I literally had goosebumps all over my body when they started killing each other at the party. Never expected the brutal scenes. When I started watching this movie I thought I will laugh all the way out because of the funny scenes of the poor family but damn! This movie is the true meaning of unpredictable. The ending is unpredictable. I am actually speechless when the movie ends. Parasite is far fron what I expected. It raised my standards when it comes to movies. I can't stop thinking about it! When I read about the different symbolism used in this movie I was in total shock. This will definitely be one of my all time fave movies. The whole team did a great job! This comment is not enough to describe the feeling and experience after watching the film. Will definitely rewatch this!

author: Matthew P

comment:
So I went to private school. I grew up a rich bitch. Something very clear but still insidious took over the social order of our school. I know there are always divides of popular kids and unpopular kids but this took it a step further. There was little violence but a lot of enforced social isolation. People who didn't fit into the proper mold (ie weren't rich attractive or neurotypical) were bullied relentlessly by everybody. It was like if they had one person to unload all their shit onto then they were safe from social ostracisation, even though the self entitled "popular kids" were always at each others throats and tossed one another aside arbitrarily.

The very kid who first claimed to me that he was part of the popular crowd was kicked out the next year. Why? He developed epilepsy. That was enough to label him a reject.
author: OD

author: Nadif Noka

comment: I stayed in a Hilton hotel in Jakarta. One morning I woke up, drew the curtains, then saw a landscape of slums that contrasted the luxurious swimming pool where people were living their best lives. The direct contrast between the rich and the poor was beyond appalling. The hotel's swimming pool and outdoor leisure was so vast that it had to squeeze the adjacent slums into disorganized cluster. This speaks volumes about the malice of capitalism in the modern world, how it leeches off the resources of the poor to ensure the comfort of the wealthy. After watching parasite, I couldn't help but be reminded of this view. So indeed, we should be terrified because economic divide is something very real in today's society. And, unfortunately, we have grown accustomed and comfortable with this notion.

Because we're lazy and like to dream too much and that's what makes us "poor". This doesn't apply to actual homeless but an average poor person in a developed - or even developing country nowadays, lives far more comfortably compared to some king from 300 years ago. You say our worth is measured by how well are we able to work for others, but what's the alternative? I'll take this over being valued by how well I can hunt bears. I'm not criticising the movie itself since I didn't even watch it, but the whole rich people bad thing is just annoying. It's not that they are ‚Äùbad people,‚Äù but it is the nature of the system to accumulate and exploit workers as much as they can for profit. Rich people are living in a privilege position. Serfs did not try to get rich under feudalism because they knew it didn't matter how much they work; it is pretty much impossible for them to get out of the class they were born in. The problem is, how can we tolerate the system that allowed the wealthiest 1% own half the world's wealth, when children in Africa are dying of hunger. We have to ask ourselves. Can we do better than this?
