author: zenfri

comment: I mean, Foxconn is contracted by many other tech giants to build their products too, to focus solely on Apple is a moot point. I have relatives that live in Hong Kong, who were up in Shenzhen to work at those factory campuses. The socioeconomic condition means that they believe the work they endure is a fact of life. It is highly exaggerated by the west of being close to 'slave labour' when the skill level of work is relative to how they are paid. A lot of the western criticism does not take into consideration that standard of living and affordability is very different to the west and people live in relative comfort, not so concerned about being 'in poverty'. The scandals at Foxconn only picked up and escalated in the media when locals started to pick up that the conditions were not to a 'western standard' and workers started to develop mental health symptoms by way of exposure. As an inductive example, one of my cousins that worked at the campus that focused mainly on Microsoft products like keyboards and mice, saved enough to travel a bit with his girlfriend. This was his first time going overseas, and to Australia in fact. He returned, and couldn't last in the same job for more than two months and started developing symptoms of depression shortly after. The other cousin was actually stationed at one of the Foxconn factories that assembled for Apple. I used to remember him complaining about some of his fellow workers would slack off and hold up their entire line and get hated on by that whole team. You don't hear anything about about these things in the west. It's more local media stuff. The west is focused on pushing class-warfare, and profiting from the lower, middle-class outrage. Anyway, my cousin stayed there for about 3 years and got promoted to supervisor and is now a line manager. I guess the first example was similar to how the Kims were generally content with their living arrangement, until they were given a glimpse of the outside, their mentality of class had shifted, it's as though they cannot go back. The Parks were ignorant, while the Kims were hyperaware of this class divide.

comment: Thank you for presenting a clear overview of the film & the social commentary. As a person of Asian descent, I have to add that class system has been our story for many, many generations. And when things got crazy in Old China, at the turn of 1900‚Äôs, finally it took a group of radical rebels, to kick out all the corrupt foreign businessmen & annihilate the upper class aristocracy. Then they introduced communist party, where all people were equal as employees of government. It also meant, the government regimented every aspect of ones life, no detail too big or too small. It was like 1984. No ideas or expression was allowed except what was in the red book. Even words were regimented. ~ After awhile, Red China opened its doors again, to do business with the world. ~ And, it seems, the cycle just keeps repeating itself. ~ However, I suggest a little less greed & corruption at the top, and really allow more people at the bottom to participate in a fair market society, where the majority can live well .. That‚Äôs the way to go .. üå±üå±üå±

author: cherries

comment:
I wouldn't say we 'created' these structures so much as they were bound to evolve to the point that they're now at in the way that they have. These structures and systems are as much a part of nature as anything else.

'Capitalism' by any other name is a system that most closely mirrors our natural propensity towards taking advantage of other living beings and technologies to secure our own safety/ meet our own needs and satisfy our own goals and desires.



It seems to me that all lasting social systems throughout history have reflected, and will inevitably continue to reflect this unfortunate reality (barring some significant paradigm shifting advancement in technology that renders resource inequalities, sexual competition and social hierarchies a thing of the past, that is. Whether that be virtual worlds or some kind of singularity with AI or something else altogether...?).

comment:
I'd like to add some thing myself
They might be far fetched but this movie gives us a lot of space to do so.
1) Regarding the rich mother falling asleep in two random moments. This might be a mocking because she does nothing and still falls asleep, while the working class is tired so people fall asleep from lack of it or she is so bored she has nothing to do, that she falls asleep again in contrary to others that have too much to do and thus get exhausted.
2) Again this might be far fetched but it's just my point of view. The man in the basement, the one that has been there for 4 years is a very good representation of North Korea. He lives so close to the rich ones, yet they don't know him at all because he is hidden there, far from the rest of the world. He is eating barely enough to survive yet still feels thankful for Mr. Park who is 'feeding' him yet Mr. Park doesn't even know him. His life's purpose is to do use light patterns as an ode to his greatness. The fact that his wife did a news reporter from N.Korea and did it so well, according to him, further proves those two are connected.
3) The main character (the poor son) is eventually most of us. Capitalism promises that by hard work, everyone will be able to succeed. Just like the rest of us, he wants to work well and make money, to get his dad out of there. To 'raise' him, from the basement to the top. We all want a better future for our parents, to please them for everything they've given us. Especially in Korea, as far as I know, kids tend to be close with their parents even when they get older. However, the son never makes it. His son won't make it as well. and so on and so on. Unlike Capitalism's promise, it's a state that can hardly change.
4) The boundaries about the rich father what talking about. It gives me goosebumbs to think that he said something along the lines of 'Mr Kim has been close to crossing the line but never does so' yet at the end of the movie he does, comes really close to him, in the most aggressive way possible. What a masterpiece this movie was!

comment: One detail that people missed in this film is the fact that Mr. Kim (father) at one point was an employee of Mr. Geun-sae (man living in the bunker). In the first half of the film, there is a scene where the Kim family is having lunch at a driver's cafe and Jessica (daughter) asks her father if he ever got to drive Mercedes-Benz vehicles during his occupation as a driver. Mr. Kim then revealed that he never did get to drive Mercedes-Benz cars until he began his job as a valet driver. He also revealed that he found his valet job after working at a Taiwan cake shop that went bust. In the second half of the film when it was revealed that Gook-moon gwang (former housekeeper) was harboring her husband in the hidden bunker, her husband reveals that his Taiwan cake shop went bust and he had to turn to loan sharks to try to save his business which led to him being indebted and hiding from those debt collectors.
author: Vag Pounder

comment:
No. Ki-Taek didn‚Äôt work for Geun-Se. They both started their own businesses when the Taiwan Cake boom started in Korea in 2016, and they both went down when a tv program falsely claimed that the cakes contained ingredients harmful to consumers and everyone started boycotting the cakes.
Ki-Taek made that face while hiding in the stairs because he shared the same experience. He felt a mix of empathy for the man, a relief that he didn‚Äôt end up like him, and also fear that he could‚Äôve easily ended up like Geun-Se if he wasn‚Äôt as lucky.
It‚Äôs one of those details that Korean audiences could catch on instantly, but it wasn‚Äôt important enough for the plot that it didn‚Äôt change the interpretation of story for foreign audiences.

comment: Some spoilers I guess. The way people excuse the actions of the poor family in this film blows my mind. They cause all the problems in the film and are the antagonists, not protagonists. They get 2 cushy high paying jobs with no real issues then start scheming and fucking over other lower class people even going so far as to fuck with some woman's serious allergies?? Then it gets even worse, and the whole excuse is "oh but they are poor, therefore exploited, therefore all the murders and ethically despicable shit they do is just fine." The rich people are not saints, profiting off the poor in a shitty system but seriously.. The daughter saves the poor son's life while his family is in the process of killing hers. No one thinks that's fucked up? IDK if the director predicted this, but maybe he's trying to expose some ethical collapse in our society caused by poverty. That's what this video and many comments about this movie look like to me. Like "good" ending was so much shittier than the real ending. If he made it and they lived happily ever after, what would the message be? Lie, exploit, and kill anyone in your way and even if your own family dies at the end it's worth it, who cares about the body count behind you?

comment:
I'm one of those who viewed the film as trying to portray a fairly obvious satirical/ cynical message to a certain segment of the audience. The message being that we're all parasites and that both ends of the spectrum are essentially the same.



The class battles and wealth/ opportunity disparities that we have always had and will likely always have, as serious and real as they are, are all vanity games in the end because we all have the capacity (and for most - the heavy inclination) to get ahead at the expense of another/ others, no matter what the cost when it comes to consistency with ethics/ honor/ dignity/ empathy and related.

comment:
This anatomy only fits in Korean and other Asian countries where the law of demand and supply is not in favour of the poor. Opportunities are fewer where people who are more competent are so many, make the chance of becoming rich is really hard. Ki-woo (the Kim's son) is really competent but he's doesn't have the opportunity that he needs to get into college.


However, this is a whole different story in the States and other first World western countries where opportunities are plenty and the only thing you need to do is to work hard. I've seen so many Vietnamese oversee people who got richer despite the poor qualifications they have back in Vietnam. The reasons they can earn more is because the opportunities they have plus the hard work they do in the State that get them to that position. I live in Australia and I can survive with a waiter job here at minimum wage of $23 AUD/hour. I would say capitalism benefits from China's communism with the low wage they have to pay for workers over there, but if you are living under the capitalism of a first World country and you're still poor, it's on you.

author: elick marie

comment:
Hi everyone! Wow thank you so much for all the kind comments it's really cool to see people engaging with the video :) I just wanted to address two things: 1) I apologize if my skin whitening example came off as Eurocentric. I should have acknowledged that the aspiration for paleness in certain places has deep historical/cultural roots. However, I used that example because the desire for whiter skin is not just limited to East Asia, and there is no way that this can be divorced from a long history of colonialism that has impacted so many cultures around the world - not to mention contemporary beauty standards promoted through global mass media. I myself am half Guyanese, and the colourism that exists in our culture is historical, but it is also very much entangled with Eurocentrism. 2) Many people have argued that capitalism is at least better than its alternative: communism. I never once mentioned communism in this video and I made an effort to specify that I'm talking about neoliberal/late capitalism. I (personally) believe more government intervention and a more robust social safety net is a viable answer to an untethered and deregulated free market system. The Scandinavian countries are a great example - and if you're looking for somewhere more diverse - even Canada (although it's far from perfect) has a pretty strong social system. Corporations need to be held more accountable and should never have more power than a government in my opinion. Anyway - thank you all for the support, I really appreciate it! :) I hope to make videos more frequently in the future!


Also - I know my audio is iffy but the constant comments about it are a little melodramatic. I really don't think my audio quality is an insult to the director or cinema at large, but whatever do you I guess!


Edit: forgot to pin this! hope it clarifies some stuff!

comment: East asian aspiration for whitness is not eurocentric; it's based in their own cultures valuing of paleness. That does not mean to say that it is good, rather that defining it as eurocenterism is evidence of your own eurocenterism. Also, to put so much emphasis on "late stage capitalism" is a bit dishonest when that culture (either South Korean or modern American) derives from an even more hierarchal system with far less economic mobility (more so in Korea than the U.S.A.). While I understand and enjoyed the movie; I think both it and your argument are dramatic and overly nihalistic in conclusion (for the movies case this could be said to be done for theatrical reasons).
author: mr. b

comment: Hi there. I'm half Indian. I've seen a lot of comments like this saying that that Asian skin whitening has nothing to do with Eurocentric beauty standards. I made that statement in the video because there is absolutely no way you can make the argument that the aspiration for whiteness in Asian cultures is completely divorced from Eurocentrism. The colourism that exists in my culture/family has deep historical roots, but it is also very much entangled with a long history of colonialism and contemporary beauty standards. In addition, skin whitening does not just occur in Asia. As to your second critique, I am making an analysis based on what Bong presented to us in his movie - whether the nihilistic ending was for theatrical purposes or not. Perhaps we just differ in opinions there.

author: Destrobius

comment: What's sad is that there is no form of system better for our society than capitalism. Of course, modern capitalism combines some elements of socialism as well through provision of various welfare benefits and other devices that act to more evenly level the playing field and soften the lower edge of society. However, social inequality will always remain, because we are all born unequally. What's also meaningful about this movie is that there is no real antagonist. It's not overtly a movie about the lower class revolting against the rich upper class. If anyone feels the movie was about that, that's a misunderstanding of the movie. It depicts the darkness of social inequality without necessarily condemning the winners of our capitalist society. The fact that there is really no one to blame or attack in the movie makes it even more tragic.

author: Rose

comment:
While I loved the film, I don't particularly like how everyone is tearing into the very core of capitalism as if it isn't actually more beneficial to society as, lets say, communism. But while I feel strongly about that, that is not to say that capitalism doesn't triumph over communism in SOME of the worst ways; and that being harsh status difference that separates the rich from the poor. Most middle class people are likely to stay at their staus, but have a chance at becoming rich, while having a slim chance of landing in poverty, while most impoverished people are stuck. I feel like this movie did highlight why the impoverished suffer from being so stagnant, because while they may be skilled, their inability to afford school or (mostly) college can leave them where they are until someone along the line breaks off from the chain.

But again, I don't think it's black and white. Capitalism isn't inherently evil, but I don't believe there is such a thing as a perfect system either. Again though, as much as I am for capitalism, I feel like this movie did such a good job at pointing at many facets of economic status in society. Like, while there may not have been a middle class family in the mix, I do believe that Min, the friend who gave Ki-woo that tutoring job, may have been the representation for that. I think it's safe to assume that he was that 'path' for Ki-woo to reach higher, because as most middle class people, he has the opportunity to either stay where he is or become richer, and in this case he granted his friends entire family the chance to become higher just because of something simple as posing as a college tutor, which Ki-woo probably couldn't get into for whatever reasons (and this is just an assumption, but I'm pretty sure that most colleges in Korea (I think) deeply scrutinize what school you came from to determine if you should be a student at their college. But feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, I just often hear drama about "you want to go to that school?! Won't college be hard to get into?" kinda stuff.)

author: Sayan Bandyopadhyay

comment:
The funniest part of the movie for me is how the rich are assumed to be higher-up in terms of social darwinism, how you're trained to just assume that they're simply better people who deserve their positions and that they're definitely better and put in more labor than the lazy poor people, but in actuality it is the poor family that both out-labors the rich and out-smarts them. The poor are the alphas, the rich are the betas, and if their economic roles were reversed the Parks would probably starve in the streets.
I know a person who's deeply indoctrinated into the Capitalist mindset. It is never the fault of the corporation, or the business, it's always either the government or poor people, expect when the government helps the rich, then it's fine, but if it even thinks of helping the poor riots should break out in the streets. I know it should terrify me, but the fact that this person wouldn't get even a whiff of this message is hilarious to me. They are the basement dweller that's bashing their brains in like a trained dog in a vain attempt to please their superior, who they only assume is superior due to their status.
The movie's tone might change in the second half, but in a certain sense, it's still a comedy trough and trough.

author: nessman69

comment:
It‚Äôs terrifying because it is the kind of reality we live in and it appears that it is something that we cannot (and even if we can, we are still unwilling to) change.

Humans may be superior in intellect among all living species in this planet and, hence, can easily outsmart other living things in order to survive and even reign supreme in the biological food chain, we have one major flaw that nature instilled in us to ensure of our eventual extinction‚ÄîGREED.

We created a social system where living in excess seems to be the ideal lifestyle. We greed for wealth beyond the sufficient amount for us to survive or live a decent life so we can afford to buy more and more stuff we don‚Äôt actually need. In turn, we leach off of mother nature to create/manufacture products in excess of what‚Äôs necessary at the expense of our natural and human resources leaving tons and tons of waste that can‚Äôt be naturally degraded. And voila! We have our governments to ensure that everything is under control and that this is how things are supposed to work out.

While we think that we‚Äôre living life to the fullest by having more than what we need at an instant, we remain oblivious to parts of the world that continue to have too little to survive...and are being maintained that way so the other half could live a totally opposite life. Worse is even if we‚Äôre aware of such inequities and injustice, we feel it to be beyond our grasp to change or that it simply has nothing to do with us.

We created poverty, wars, diseases and climate change. And in the end, those who have less are the ones who are more unprotected from all of it. And we know for a fact that the trend has always been putting majority of the world‚Äôs wealth to a handful and leaving the rest divided among billions of others.

Mother Earth doesn‚Äôt need a more superior species to keep humans under control. We created that monster ourselves.

WE ARE OUR OWN PARASITES. And boy! We are unforgiving.

author: Benjamin Madeira

comment: In my opinion  "Parasite" is one of the best movies in the last decade, and this analysis is simply brilliant, I agree 100% that every class lives through expenses of the other and what I loved the most is that the director neither idealize the Kim's nor condemn the Parks, is a very objective view with characters that have both virtues and defaults like real human beings, thank you so much for this contribution, however I think blaming capitalism per se for some of the problems the film points out is too symplistic and I don't see that's Bong Jo's intention. There are a lot of things that are not desirable in modern society however I have to ask this: what economic system is a better alternative ?? Socialism also has an upper class gathered in the dominant party. Myself as an inhabitant from a latin american country where state interventionism is still very strong I can tell you that politics which are oriented to a socialist model are everything but succesfull in order to improve people's lives, my dad grew up in a country without foreign companies around, without free market awareness and again in a land ruled by strong statism policies... he was miserable, he literally spent all his childhood living in a paperboard house and eating only twice a day, he had to  do all type of minor services by himself to afford his school and finally after many years of struggle he was in a much better situation however during his productive years there weren't many opportunities unless you were a friend of a politician, that was before we were "invaded" by neoliberalist policies.  There will always be better-paid jobs than others, simply because we as a society value unique talent more than low-skilled labor, I mean I agree we should be awared about social injustice and we can do a lot more to close the barriers but  I've worked in the filming industry and in a production even if it's small there are hundreds of people involved and I'm sure Mr. Bong Joon Ho has no remorse of him or his main actors earning more money than those others who had a lesser role by making his films besides he lives in a world where he doesn't have to be part of the top 1000 billionaires to enjoy a very decent level of life.  It's the way it is, as Churchill said: "capitalism is the worst system except all others"
author: joseafalvel

comment:
There are more choices than communism and high-inequality corporatism. The problems in the movie were how poor the Kims are, how difficult it is to escape poverty despite opening businesses like the cake shop, that 500 university graduates apply to be a security guard, etc. You can solve these without the USSR.

Scandinavian social-welfare capitalism ensures it's easier to work your way up and the poorest live better lives. More people can afford university, your life isn't ruined if your business goes bust, and it's easier to be an entrepreneur who gives other people jobs.

comment:
Great to see someone mentioning Gramsci. I think we can divide this film in two big moments regarding class relations: 1- the lower class family that's stuck in poverty trying to reach the top by all means possible. This isn't possible neither by hardworking or cheating or even by reproducing the same classist agression/competition with members of their own class (the previous maid and her husband) . 2- The family members realizing that they do not belong in the healthy environment and upper class mannerisms, leading to class consciousness (each member of the poor family reacts to it differently).

You did a great job in the video, congratulations!

author: Austin Langdon

comment:
Excellent! What insightful analysis and thorough research! There's one thought I wanted to express, though: I feel like the cultural hegemony that the Kims have bought into has less to do with worshiping the upper class (I would argue that they look down on the Parks, and see them as nice but foolish) and more to do with their own pride. They've had a taste of what it's like to have status and money, and now they will not let go of it, no matter what. Even if it means killing fellow workers, they will keep climbing the "social staircase" (notice the visual metaphor in the film of the two families racing to the top of the bunker stairs, dragging each other down). In this sense, I believe capitalism has taught them not to be content with servitude, but to claw their way to the top.

I actually am writing a paper on this as my college integrative project (incorporating Marx and Rousseau), so it's definitely good to see other folks doing their research and finding the deeper meanings behind Parasite! What a fantastic film, truly. I will check out the sources you quoted and see if I can incorporate them in my bibliography.
author: Rachelle Savard

comment: @Broey Deschanel Oh yes definitely there is a bit of a love-hate dynamic going on between  the two families. The Kims believe themselves to be better than the Parks on some level, because they are smarter, or at least more wily. On the other hand, they are jealous of the Parks' wealth and status. They've seen the privileged lifestyle of this bourgeois family and want it for themselves. This is what leads the Kims to thinking of the house as "their house," even though it will never actually be theirs. They feel entitled to it because they are starting to believe they can integrate into the world of the Parks (through the means of Kiwoo marrying Dahye). So on some level they hate these snobby rich people. But they also want to be them, as we see with Kiwoo's fantasy at the end. No matter what, money always corrupts. Even though the poor may despise the rich, they still desire that lifestyle for themselves (which is hypocritical of course, but very human).
author: Rachelle Savard

comment: That's a great interpretation, perhaps that's truly what's going on here. Would you say it's a mixture of pride (pitying the Parks) and idolizing them to the extent that they want to become them (not because they think they're better by any means)? And yeah this film is loaded with visual metaphors - the vertical mobility of the stairs. etc. Good luck on your project and thanks for the comment :)

author: Luna Bautista

comment: First, I would like to say wow, this analysis took a lot of time and research which is highly commendable. However, because you are analyzing this movie from a very limited framework, you have missed out on the overall theme of this movie which isn't about capitalism, though it does play a part in it. It's easy to get stuck in this black and white mindset where society is constructed to keep rich people at the top and poor people at the bottom. Rich people are simply benefiting from a capitalistic system and poor people can never rise to the top. This simply isn't factually true. If you took less time looking over theories and more time looking at the research data you would see that the facts point to a different narrative. For example, intelligence is a bigger factor of success than socio economic status. In other words, a rich person born in poverty has a higher chance of becoming richer than a person of lesser intelligence born in wealth. There seems to be a wide variety of factors and there still needs to be more research. However, from what we do know, there are a few components that are seemingly crucial. One, you need to have emotional intelligence in order to take risks such as starting your own business. That means, having a stable supportive social support network so when you fail, you can keep going and learning from your mistakes. Not having a stable emotional support group as well as a poor emotional well being will greatly stifle your ability to do well. Second, you need to have the right personality. People who are open, disagreeable, and conscientious tends to make more money than those who aren't. In order words, you need to have an entrepreneurial mindset in order to attain a lot of wealth. If you are interested in studying and helping people instead of making money, then you won't make a lot of money because that isn't your goal. And of course, intelligence is probably the biggest predictor of wealth and unfortunately, this disadvantage is not socially constructed but naturally imposed. So in the end, yes, there is a clear inequality between rich and poor in modern capitalistic societies such as America but it seems to be inherited in natural injustices rather than socially constructed injustices. But even if you aren't intelligent, nor have the right personality to break into the 1%, it doesn't mean you can't live a comfortable and happy life because you don't need to smart or rich to be happy and happiness is a better end to strive for.
author: k

comment: I would have to disagree. Just because someone is intelligent does not guarantee they can climb the socio-economic ladder. You can see it in the film itself - Ki-Woo and Ki-Jeung are shown to be highly skilled and intelligent individuals, but neither of them is able to escape their socioeconomic situation. They stand in complete opposition to someone like (forgive me) Donald Trump, who is by no means an objectively intelligent individual, yet who amassed an empire based on economic status and connections alone. There are always external factors at play - did you parents have time to support and encourage your education? are you able to afford a better education? does your school have the resources/funding to provide adequate learning? does your government offer adequate funding? do you have to forgo your ambitions to take care of relatives? All of these combine to disadvantage someone from attaining higher socioeconomic status - wealth cannot be equated to innate biological qualities. Of course it's a socially constructed injustice, economic wealth itself is a manmade thing.

author: Cycling Zen

comment:
Thoughtful video that engages with the ideas and theories with great enthusiasm. I always enjoy these. Well edited, well argued. Brisk pace and gets large concepts across in an efficient way. This movie was terrific.

Let's go on a trip together. There's a number of things that prevented me from buying into an anlysis of this movie that is primarily sociological or economic. One is, if killing Mr. Park was a justifiable action according to this video's thesis, i.e. the wrongful oppression of many through cool capitalism and cultural hegemony which should be defied, how do we explain Mr. Kim's remorse and shellshock afterward?

There's a hint of Crime and Punishment in here which brings the movie beyond economic and sociological interpretation. Namely the individual psychology and personal struggle with aforementioned structures, cool capitalism, cultural hegemony, and with murder, personal corruption, exploitation of others, etc. Mr. Kim's human reaction to murder goes beyond economic and cultural analysis. The mere fact of being human confounds rational justifications. If cool capitalism and cultural hegemony are so wrong and deserve to be rebelled against, then why doesn't Mr. Kim revel in his victory? Because life is so much deeper than economic or sociological analyses. And I think, despite Bong's overt interpretations of his own film, that this movie argues that point at its core.

While I agree that there is a fearsome takeaway from this movie, I don't think the emphasis is placed on theoretical structures. Those things are pervasive in the movie and certainly frame it, but they take a backseat to the characters and the importance of personal conduct in the face of economic or social circumstances.

The movie contains, oddly, an archetypal hero myth structure in the falling action. The hero rescues his father from the underground, or at least aspires to do so. This is a reference to the power of the individual and how he can rejuvenate society by upright action. This points to a significant shift in Kevin's personality that suggests, retroactively, that the movie was foremost about Kevin's psychological journey and personal development, rather than an explication of economic and sociological concepts. I won't go into any great depth about this line of argumentation because of the limits of this format. But it's something to consider on your own if you've made it to the end of this comment.
author: Brandon Yeo

comment:
@elliphant21

Korea's economic situation is nothing short of a disaster. So shortly after its miraculous rise in wealth, it is now projected to enter permanent economic recession similar to Japan. Corruption plays a big role, as well as an aging demography and overdependance upon international trade. Nothing you've brought up is false. Kiwoo may never be able to realize his explicit noble aspiration. In fact, he most certainly won't.

That lies outside my argument, however. I did not say he would be able to rescue his father. I said that he had experienced a personality shift that, maybe for the first time in his life, has lifted his eyes UP, changed his target to one that rises UP. There are many small steps to take, and along that steep and difficult path upwards, there is potential for personality growth and psychological development.

I'll repeat my point. The economic analysis which you've put forward does not fully encompass Kiwoo's humanity. It's a cliche, but it rings true here: money does not buy happiness. Marcus Aurelius wrote, "the happiness of your life depends on the quality of your thoughts." Kiwoo's thoughts--more, his entire perspective--has changed and put him on an upward trajectory. Again, upward in terms of his character and personal development. This brings in the symbol in the movie, the scholar's rock. Does it represent wealth? Or the qualities that make up a wealthy character? Kiwoo obsesses over this symbol throughout the movie and he understands it in the end.

There are many people like the Kims aiming DOWN. What happens when enough people, like Kiwoo, stop? The movie leaves this question hanging open.
author: Brandon Yeo

comment: ArtificialxSky you bring up some good points however, I think kiwoo‚Äôs aspiration to get rich in order to rescue his father is actually one of the most heartbreaking parts of the movie. bong said in an interview that it would take kiwoo 564 years to work and save enough to buy that house, which shows just how broken our socioeconomic system is. it seems reasonable that someone should be able to get out of poverty from their hard work alone, but in reality kiwoo is powerless against capitalistic society and will be stuck in the same metaphorical basement apartment until he dies. this myth of upward mobility only exists in our society so that the poor will continue to have hope in the system that exploits their labor and eventually kills them. this hope for future upward mobility upholds the system because the lower class is too busy trying to survive and get out of poverty to have an effective revolution that changes the system. bong uses kiwoo‚Äôs aspirations to show that whether an individual can climb the economic ladder does not matter because the cycle of class struggle will continue. kiwoo could become rich but the new tenants of his old family apartment will still get flooded out and the poor will continue to suffer while the ignorant rich continue to profit off the labor of the poor below them.

comment: Hi! I agree with what you're saying, although I think it might speak to a larger issue with theory and film analysis itself. When you apply a theory to a certain film, you're looking at it from a certain lens (in this case I looked at it from a socio-economic/cultural studies lens). I think it just requires multiple analyses and theories to observe the movie from different angles. Perhaps there's another theory that can explain why the Parks are victims. Maybe you could apply feminist film theory to explore Mrs. Park's character, or auteur theory to explore how Bong uses space/architecture to visualize his themes. But I don't think I could tackle all of the film's complex themes in a single video. I also agree that the relationship between the rich and poor is very complex and I don't think the Parks themselves are necessarily the villains of the movie, but actually the system they're living in ("we live in a society" lol). I also do think that the Parks' ability to physically remove themselves from the situation/house does speak volumes, even if they've experienced a traumatic situation. Thanks for the thoughtful comment!

author: David Miranda

comment:
Well. I grew up in South Korea during the 90's as a rich family but went to a public school for my parents believed that it is important for me to do that. After my birthday party as a kid, a lot of kids wanted to come over my house. They stole my toys and snacks. One kid who started to bully me a little was asked to leave and he smashed a window on the way out. Since we never moved, the "rich boy" stigma always followed and I was always bullied or cast out. When I went to collage, I thought it was a new start and never told anyone where I'm from all anything about my upbringing. But one day I let my guards down and invited a friend over to my place. After that the rich boy stigma began again. My friends always told me how I don't have to worry about student loans, that I don't really need to get a job, some even told me that me studying hard for exams was just for personal satisfactions while for others its about life and death. When I told them I never had friends growing up and was bullied all my life because of my family's wealth they just shrugged and said that's easy compared to being ordinary people's struggle.

My grandfather made an honest living. My dad also made an honest living. I hope I can make an honest living and continue the legacy. But I plan to "draw the line" from now on. I don't expect to be welcomed by the poor or the so called "normals" so I don't welcome them. I'm happy to live as a employer who pays handsomely and I'm happy that they see me just as that.

If you want to be happy as a normal dude, learn to be content or become rich. If you want to be happy as a rich, don't try to be down to earth or any of that bullshit because you will be hated. Pay handsomely and use that to draw your line.

comment: Factories workers in China are being exploited? So what do we do? Do we eliminate all the factories in China, or do we eliminate all the factories in the world? Do we eliminate all factory jobs and all service jobs? What jobs are considered dignified? The problem I see is that the Chinese worker are being singled out as singularily the ones being exploited in the economic system. In reality, it is not as simple as black, and white. Everyone in the economic system is being exploited in one way or another. Also, that jobs, and roles are considered dignified is also subjective. The conclusion the narrator is trying to draw does not do justice to the actually complexity of the movie. The movie is telling us a largest, more profound points.

comment:
parasite is a very well written movie It talks about power, greed and hope,it says that how humans are capitalist by nature, That a person only thinks about himself that when a poor family has power, they will not help other poor but will only think about themselves, There is a power hierarchy in the society and the one who has more power, he considers the one with less power as a filth. This film talk about privilege also that a higher class person gets everything but a lower class person has to work 10 times more to get that, Everything in this film was well balanced there is no villain in this film the real villain is the situation
Yes bong didn't give any reason for "all or nothing" but that's the whole point that's why it feels surprising,The murder of Mar Park by Mar kim was a very psychological act,The murder of Mar Park by Mar Kim is very surprising and to understand it, you need to understand the psychology of Mar Kim.
Kim never wanted to kill Park, it was the situation that led to this act,Jealousy and anger have already boiled over in Kim's mind against Park,And it's shown in a very subtle way,He used to respect the park a lot, but later he came to know that he just thinks of him as a worker who stinks alot This thing was deeply disturbing to Kim inside,A big truth was already revealed in front of Kim(secret bunker),And right after that he heard Mr. Park say about himself that he stinks, and later her whole house got washed away by the rain all trouble came upon him in one night Still, he has to go to work in the morning, where the Park family is about to enjoy a birthday party But still the park treats him like a worker wo stinks they are completely unaware of his problem,Even when geun se killed Kim's daughter, Park was only thinking about his son and he should logically think about his son first But Kim felt bad for this work of Park because of his hatred, when Park shrunk his nose to avoid the smell, then Kim felt worse,in that situation, his suppressed hatred and jealousy came out in the form of anger, which led to the murder of the park. Kim had no Big reason to kill Park and he never want to kill mr Park it just happened to him like a DREAM a BAD DREAM And he got punished for this because he did wrong he had to leave his family and stay in the bunker and later he also apologized to the park, but now nothing is going to happen with this apology, crime was already committed now he will have to atone for it ,this shows the jealousy and hatred of the lower class against the higher class, And the movie never justifies Kim's crime,Kim was not a psycho killer, he was a normal person, he committed this crime, which he regrets, but now nothing is going to happen by regretting,In the last, a conversation between a father and son is shown which is very emotional, a son will never consider his father a criminal He also knows that my father is not such a person, but nothing can happen now,In the end, the film ends on Hope, despite all this, ki woo never stops hoping,I don't know whether he will be able to get that house or not, but God bless him to buy such a house so that when it rains next time, he can enjoy it with his family like mr park does.
Both families were not parasite in this film the real parasite was human greed,hatred, jealousy and situation

comment:
This film is less a class critique than it is a subversive parody of the heist trope.

There is no consideration of the Parks at the end because, like a bank or art gallery, they exist to serve as a foil for the protaganists' whacky exploits.

There is certainly aesthetic contrast between the 'elevated' life and the 'subterranean' life, but this is to serve the parody.

As for it's creator's claim that the rich are parasites as well, I submit that he is trolling us -- that this is part of the parody. (After all, it depicts the Kim's as hiding like cockroaches under the furniture. And it portrays the anodyne Park family as ... having an evilly overactive olfactory sense? That's parody gold!)

Let the flaming commence! :)
author: Bryan Hann

comment:
I don't think the rich guy deserved what he got in the end. I think they are the victims here. They never treat them bad. Both the husband and wife give respect to the ones working for them. Only time he's not so respectful is when he talks about that smell and even then I didn't think it was enough to get him killed (plus leaving his kids fatherless and wife, widowed).
The poor family on the other hand conned them, stole two people's jobs when they could've certainly stopped at their son and daughter, used their living room when the family was away on a trip and used their food and alcohol. And to top it all of they're talking about having it all for themselves as if they worked for it (not to mention, how they treated that previous housekeeping lady and her husband). If they hadn't got greedy, none of those things would've happened. And when you consider that the rich guy worked from the bottom up (some Korean commenter said that), they're even more in the wrong.
I don't know if this was intended, but it seemed to me that the movie wanted us to feel a bit sympathetic for the poor family in the end. And because of that, I didn't like the ending. It was certainly cleverly made and very funny.

author: zye3011

comment: I felt like the Kim's family met their Karma, even though it was depressing and awful.. First off, the two kids could have kept up the deception and atleast saved and try to better their circumstances. The sister, Ki-jung  had stood a really good chance because she was clever, talented and impressed the Park family. But what put me off was that they had the house keeper and driver dismissed out of pure selfishness and greed. They capitalized  too much off the situation. The second thing was that they outright refused to help the previous housekeeper even when she offered to pay them, yet they were in the same class as her. Plus they were the reason for her being out of a job. What would it cost to feed a guy once a week, when they themselves were deceiving the Park family. None of them took into account the mental health or desperation of the housekeeper and her husband. SMH.   And what I couldn't understand, how comes no one thought of their home which was in a basement during a storm. They were so caught up on trying to leave a rich lifestyle that they forgot their own home.

comment: I‚Äôm not a Korean, but I‚Äôve lived in Korea for a year. I love the small details in this movie that show the uniqueness of Korean culture. Everything from the sock hanger rack, to the jarred ginseng and plums (both of which are incredibly expensive according to my Korean friends), to the soju, to the discussion about daily particle levels. I feel like you miss a layer of understanding if you haven‚Äôt lived in Korea and for me this movie is special because of this display.

author: buck lmao

comment:
a student at my university wrote an essay last year on the amount of visible lines between characters in almost every shot - they‚Äôre separated by staircase railings, bookcases, walls in the background etc etc to show the division between classes. in addition there is an emphasis on height differences with characters moving up & down staircases, uphill and downhill, living in both basements, lying under the table etc. it‚Äôs an incredibly smart way that manages to properly Show these divisions and how poor people are invisible to the rich without explicitly saying so.

many people have tried to nitpick at this movie and say things like ‚Äùhow could the son have survived a blow to the head with a rock‚Äù or other minute critiques but im telling you, bong joon-ho thought of it all. the stone is a gift from his friend to represent academic success and serve as a good luck charm + source of aspiration, but when the basement is flooded it floats, showing how hollow the son‚Äôs hopes are whilst simultaneously solving what would otherwise be a possible plot hole. it‚Äôs clear that this movie was made with incredible care and effort. ive been a fan of bong joon-ho for several years now, so it is very satisfying to see him finally get the recognition he deserves. this IS a fantastically well made film and worth every last bit of the hype.


also it was kinda funny seeing celebrities praise this film without understanding it at alllll

author: Carmen Downery

comment: They scammed themselves into the jobs in the Park household but once into the job, they did the work, essentially and did the job well. Besides being overall, a social satire on the wealth/income divide in modern South Korea (and the world),  it shows also how the disadvantaged have so much trouble breaking into steady employment --- even jobs in households,  security guard jobs --- those jobs that conventionally are thought to be lower class jobs and supposedly easy to get.  The movie also shows that the poor aren't stupid, unqualified/unaccomplished or deserve to be poor --- they are just the vast majority who don't have the capital, the luck or other means to get further education, strike it in business, etc. because the post-capitalist world rewards the few and supresses the rest.  The real world is of course complex but the movie did a great job portraying a pretty realistic world while at the same time telling an engaging story that was funny, sarcastic, and tragic.  I agree,  virtually a flawless movie that was visually stunning.   I watched it late last year in a movie theatre --- remember those?

author: christi land

comment:
Bong: In this movie, the rich never look down at the poor. (ex driver, PM 2.5, under the table, the basement of my house, Morse code...)
And the poor don't dare look up. (They can't imagine deceive their owners to steal their homes or steal property. "Respect!", Just yelling and fighting among the same poor.)

There are no decisive villains in this movie. But from a small dispute, 'class murder' occurs.
Capitalism is said to be right, but what should we do about that 'gap'?
As mentioned above, The poor are becoming increasingly difficult to dream of gaining rank. And rich people are becoming less interested in others.

I'll just show you this time. Let's think together. What kind of society should we build?
(Of course, this is not a film that promotes socialism, it's a question of a better way in a capitalist society.)

author: dfjsklfljkds sdklfjlsdjfsdf

comment:
No matter what wins any one single award, someone can always think of something that might be technically better and didn't get it. At the end of the day, something has to win and Parasite is a perfectly good movie with good writing, and a high degree of competency. For the year, I'm not sure I can think of a better Korean film, or one that isn't better in some ways but worse in others. I also don't think anything about it was over-hyped. It pretty much came out of nowhere and had very little mainstream hype.

The 2nd point about the smelly insult. You are watching the moment he makes a turn as a character. You have to think of that whole sequence as being together processed by him. The sniff is the straw that breaks the camel's back. He's clearly realizing things during the whole sequence. I had some issues with it too. I wish he had come to his realizations and made the turn a bit sooner. I thought while he waited in the bushes he was going to have put it all together and would have reacted "better" sooner. But the sequence doesn't fail. And if we look in real life, people end up often make that turning point late and at odd times. I've seen people put up with plenty of shit all day long, take in stride and be professional, but then go off "get triggered" because a tape dispenser is empty. Yes it might be nice if people took action at more opportune times, but they don't.

Two moments in a movie doesn't ruin it anyway. We can pick any movie apart until it looks like a train wreck. Frankly too, if you watch a lot of Korean or other foreign films, those two bits can't really bother you that much. Even just looking through the director and writers' filmographies....come on, you can't be that bothered by two explainable scenes otherwise...it feels like you just are looking for a reason to complain about Parasite.

comment:
Yeah I felt the same, I feel like it was unnecessarily violent.


I think it would have been great if the family just got away that night, back to their crappy home, their lives ruined because all their money and belongings are trashed and for all the horrible things they did they end up right back at square one.


It would also have been poetic if after that flood it turned out the Parks organised that gym for them all to sleep in as well as providing food for them, so in the end it'd turn out that the Parks(representing the rich) aren't automatically bad people and at this point of course the main family gets found out, unable to continue their ruse any longer, back home to that guy pissing outside their window.


The only hole that leaves is the mother since she doesn't leave the house, I guess it could be changed so that she opts to be with her family.

comment: I wasn‚Äôt a huge fan of the movie. The only idea I enjoy for myself is the fathers confinement at the end acts as his jail cell, the son won‚Äôt ever reach that point of buying the house and if he does he would be too late, and the mother grief for losing her daughter which I personally think the son should‚Äôve passed or remained with lasting trauma to his brain and the mother should have been in prison. The son went downstairs with the intent to kill. The fathers inability to control his emotions and responding to the husbands disparaging of his odor  caused them to be further trouble. Even if it was the tipping point for him seeing his daughter die that was a direct result of his families choices. I understand the display of disadvantages between different classes but you start to lose respect for the lower class when they start to have complete disregard for other people. Even the son kissing his student in which his best friend trusted him not to. Not a horrible movie but I missed why people are praising the movie so much. I watched it twice and maybe the third time might shine some light.

comment:
I think that's part of the point of it though, you're not supposed to root for this family because they're poor and you're not supposed to hate the Parks because they're rich. The main family completely ruin it for themselves, what happens is entirely their fault, all because they had to get greedy and have that party.


I don't think the film is quite as mesmerizing as people make it out to be but I liked that aspect of it, it's frustrating because every member of this family is clearly brilliant in their own way but circumstances lead them to a life of crime instead...at the end of the day though, they still chose to do that, they're bad people and being disadvantaged doesn't give you the excuse to act this way.

comment: Because he simply snapped. He was already devastated by the fact that his house was flooded. He notices the rich man‚Äôs wife had a problem with his smell because of the flood. All of this happening, while he has to dance to these rich people‚Äôs tune (dress up as a native american for the rich man‚Äôs son). All of this was already eating up inside him. Seeing his daughter being stabbed and dying. And the rich man only caring for his car keys to save his son, and making a big deal of the dying dude‚Äôs smell, that was it. It made the dad snap. It‚Äôs a simple upper vs lower class warfare theme the movie is trying to tackle .

author: pinkbeatle2012

comment:
Not a native English speaker so I am going to try my best.
First of all, let's give credit where credit is due: the movie is well shot, it builds some very artistic pictures at times, I find it funny, it has some cool metaphors, it's fast paced, accessible and enjoyable.
I also would like to assume that this is not an absurdist or surreal like film( stuff that you find in books written by Kafka, plays by Beckett or paintings by Dali, where common sense or logic are taken away for a specific purpose).
The action portrayed in the movie is supposed to be based on certain cause and effect situations, to make it realistic. Although, despite the general positive reviews that this movie has received, I'm afraid this is not the case. Parasite is anything but plausible, and here is why:

-Rich families may be superficial, but if the Parks in Parasite represent a symbol for rich families for an universal understanding, then everything is wrong. Rich people are not stupid, I find it odd that they do not have security cameras or some kind of guards to keep the house safe in their absence. It does not seem plausible that mrs and mr Park simply agree to hire this poor family without any research of their interests, or background.
I find it odd that they did not know, even though they bought such a big house, that they did not have a basement.

-It feels wired that they got rid of the old housekeeper, in such a manner, that they truly believe she had TBC. The scene where mr Kim spills ketchup on the used napkin is very reminiscent of some cheap Mexican soap opera. And then he just touches mrs Park hand :"Ah fuck it is just tuberculosis, relax"

-Its absurd of how the Kims simply do all that mess when the Parks are away.

-The aspect that the old housekeeper just comes back, saying that she forgot smth in the basement( a fucking human being), with all kinds of bruises, cutting out the camera, does not add up.

-The fact that the Kims where really skilled and street smart does not make any sense on how they did not find jobs before.

-After their already implausible escape, when they return to their flooded home, the Kims return for the young son birthday looking flawless, after they spent that night in odd conditions.

-In the birthday scene, after the parody-like events, in life and death situations, mr Park is annoyed by the smell?
really? when his son is dying he just wants his car keys, like no one else from the guests drives a car.

And these are just a few of the facts that the movie doesn't get right, it feels awkward.
Let alone the political message, where the old housekeeper mocks and imitates North Korean politics.
The are also so many cliches, like the moment when the Kims stumble and they are seen by the old housekeeper, in that particular moment.
And one more thing, I know that this movie is full of metaphors, but what kind of crime investigation does not properly search ALL the house, basement included.
author: Prometheus

comment:
@Juan G√≥mez Fuentes Thank you man, for adding more arguments and examples.

Have a nice day!
author: Prometheus

comment:
Finally I find somebody that thinks like me about this film. I criticize the same aspects. The characters make thing that are extremelly out of their personality. The Kims demostrated to be extremelly smart and planning everything ahead, specially the kids. Then they make that stupid drunk party in the house risking loosing everything?. They let the old housekeeper just enters when they are all there with all the mess?. The main character has demostrated during the movie be very smart and focus in the detais, planning everything in advance, and then at the end, he decides in the middle of a party, with tons of people in the house, to go to the basement? And alone?. Then, like you said, the police is not going to find the basement after 3 killing in the house, they dont think, where this guy came from?. Specially having blood in the accesible basement.

Then, like you say, the cliches, like hidding under the bed, forcing the situation that everybody goes downstairs when everybody in under the table.

I find very silly the ending of the killing in the garden. After all the entire story that the writter has been able to construct, is he ending it like that, with a silly metaphor?.

I normally would have seen this movie and said, Ok, it is a good movie, and go on. But all this crazyness with a 99% in rotten tomatoes, and all the comment just saying that is the best movie ever and this like that makes me feel that I am the only one that has seen the movie.
I do not see where this movie really is the best ever.
- In cinematografy is fine, but it is far far far from being better that 1917, or Birdman, or Interstellar, or a ton of movies more.
- The actors are fine, but sometimes they did it quite bad, with those silly over reactions in their faces. People speaks about this acting like if Daniel Day-Lewis made them.
- The script is not that good. The original idea is good but the developement, specially in the half part is not well develope, not at least to make as good as people say. The writter abuse a lot of take the character way out of their personalities to make them do thing that produce the situation that the writer is forcing. Then those silly non-funny cliches like the scene of hidding under the table werent necessary at all.
-The ending is just a metaphore that the writter wanted to make even when it makes no sense and it is a silly ending, when he could have done something much better to develope the situation with the guy in the basement. You want to see a good ending, check Seven.

At the end, a good movie, but come on guys, it is not that good, it is really far from be a all times master piece. Maybe this overreaction is due to the fact that the last two years has been quite bad in real memorable movies. Or maybe people feel a little bit identified with some aspects of the movie. I do know.

I feel like when I was recommended to see "The mist", and when I check online the critics were throught the roof, and end up been one of the worst movies I have ever seen.

comment: I am glad I did not listen to this whole review, as he gave away something rather important. I thought that the first three quarters of the film is really great, some fantastic visuals, and even dialogue that you have to remember, and do for stuff later. There is that fantastic surprise which is the height of the film. But from then on, I felt the film went down hill. It was so predictable. Also the last ten or so minutes could have really been trimmed. down. For me the best Korean film that I have seen is train To Busan, and zombie movies are not my cup of tea. For the first three quarters of the film, I though it was the greatest Korean him ever made. As for it winning the academy award as best picture, I felt that the Hollywood movie and Irishman were far better. No one has suggested it, but perhaps its best picture award was a backlash to the still Hollywood so white campaign.

author: dildonius

comment:
It‚Äôs about the class status and the inferiority difference between mr park and mr Kim. The resonance of his failure as provider for his family is always present with mr park as a comparison. The smell reference is more of viewing mr Kim as being below him on the class ladder, he also has to endure the embarrassment of his insults in front of his children.
Mr Kim is a very proud individual and especially in asian culture where a person‚Äôs status is defined by their monetary worth.
Given his mental state with his family‚Äôs current predicament of having their jobs a threat with the people tied down in the basement, his home being destroyed. Also the car scene where the mrs park is saying how great it was for the rain to fall to bring up this beautiful day for the garden party without knowing it destroyed his entire home.
Then his daughter bleeding to death his son unconscious bleeding from his head and even in an emergency situation mr park still has the bear of thought to hold his nose to retrieve the keys was his tipping point and he lost control. It was an act of impulse with which he instantly regrets.

author: Dr Phil

comment:
What Parasite highlights is the appalling level of inequality in every society, which no one can turn away from.

Perhaps that‚Äôs why this film is already garnering widespread acclaim. It has already seized the Palme d‚ÄôOr along with multiple ¬≠international film awards.

There‚Äôs also speculation about whether it can be the first ever ¬≠non-English language film to win the Oscar for best picture.

The issues the movie shows are universal, and fitting of a world witnessing sweeping revolts and uprisings.

Revolutions and protests that removed decades-long dictators last year in Algeria and Sudan were built on the back of similar inequalities and resentments.

It is the poor and the have-nots who suffer the largest blow from ¬≠natural disasters as we can see from the floods in Indonesia.

The movie reminds us that it is not the rich and the powerful who pay for the consequences of global warming.

Am I the only one who like it but didn't think it was great? spoilers It doesn't delve very deeply into the characters or the theme. It's a comedy that touches on some interesting themes but never explores them. I can't think of any scene that I would just want to rewatch again and again like the great films I like. For me, that's how you know a movie is great. If there are a number of scenes in the movie you want to rewatch like the Travolta and Thurman date in Pulp Fiction.


Also, the fact that the dead housekeeper is ignored bothered me. This parasite family left her there to die and got away with it.


Good movie--A--not A+.
author: GizmoMaltese

comment:
I think personally it delves into the characters‚Äô motives and personas very well. It especially outlines how in asian culture people‚Äôs social and wealth status is a measure of their value and success.
Scenes that stood out to me spoilers* are the belt of trust scene which is beautifully shot and edited along with the great score that accompanied it. When mr Kim has a final look back at his home before leaving in the flood was another stand out scene. The scene with mr Kim driving and the mother opens the window is also fantastic. I also loved the scene with mr Kim and mr park where they are dressed as American Indians, it brilliantly depicts the power of authority from wealth.

But movies are subjective to the people‚Äôs personal taste however for me it resonated. I think the film perfectly touches on the superiority complex and division from gaps in wealth and social status. The film also portrays how in today‚Äôs society we subconsciously view others inferior to us when they fall below us on the ladder and the constant struggle to elevate and project us up the class structure.

comment: Viewing the world of dichotomous the rich and the poor in neo-capitalist society from the perspective of the lower class. Life exists over the ground and under the ground. And semi-basement("Banjiha" in the movie) under the ground. And basement under the semi-basement. The traces of poverty that cannot be hidden remain unhidden. Life under the "Banjiha" coexists with the desire for the over-the-ground life and the fear of falling the under-the-ground. We can't share the happiness in our hands, so the gap between them is only widened. The film tells a dream that can't be fulfilled. The characters' performances are filled with all the scenes without any gaps, and they meet with humor like an awl even though they follow their hearts in unexpected ways. Even if you hide all hidden symbols and meanings, it is enough to enjoy the pleasure of the movie. It's such a lucky film I've met in my life.After watching a movie, I suddenly realize that I smell my smell and am surprised.

comment:
@Bill B Well that's all subjective. "Best Picture material" is extremely subjective because of its ever-changing nature. Whatever wins Best Picture is automatically deemed Best Picture material because... well, it won Best Picture. Green Book is Best Picture material because it won, because they didn't want to give it to a B&W Netflix foreign film among six other films that had lesser chances. Fucking Green Book. The Oscars have been getting worse and worse because they are now doing something that I'm not a fan of: they're letting politics run the show. I love 12 Years a Slave, Moonlight, and Parasite, but those three films in particular probably won for the wrong reasons.
Why am I talking about this? Is it relevant? I don't know. But I like shitting on awards shows so I did it anyway.

author: Riddhiman

comment:
(NO SPOILERS)
Up to 75% into the movie...While I was intrigued from the start and up to that point I thought a few things "Oh, this is pretty clever and I don't think Ive seen such a story before"....AND...."While its interesting....I don't see why everyone is raving about it...I do...and Don't".
To that point is was a good movie....But once the Arch really went into full swing I found myself talking to my laptop screen....saying things like "NO DON'T" and "WTF??? WTF...JUST HAPPENED??"...AND...."OMFG"!!!

That last turn made me get why it had such an impact on a lot of people....Sure the class of people etc etc was packed into a good story....But I never thought to myself..."Usually lower income people etc are considered imbeciles in movies....If anything I roll my eyes a bit cause they are usually portrayed as victims...which also usually isnt the case IRL...IMO.

But this movie didn't treat them as imbeciles or victims....And also didn't treat the wealthy family as just evil people preying on others....I saw them as simply being raised a certain way etc and they had an outlook...but with no ill intent in mind.

Rich or poor...all had good and bad qualities...Which are subjective in a lot of ways anyway....it was nice to see that shown realistically for those characters while understanding no matter what side your on....This particular instance CANNOT be used as a generalization of either class....everyone is different.

THAT LAST 25% THOUGH....THAT CULMINATION WAS INDEED AN AMAZING TURN.

And the best line of the movie..."Oh, Mr. Park.... RESPECT"!!!!!!
That guy was hands down F'N Awesome haha.

Overall loved it.

author: journalwithel

comment:
:::SPOILERS::: What is it with you americans going all hurray for that film??? With all due respect (and love for Hollywood and independent movie makers in the US): have you missed european cinemas since the seventies?!I was shocked when I heard it got an Oscar , no: THE Oscar! I didn't know anything about 'Parasite' before watching it, so: perfect conditions, right? But I was not pleased. I liked the acting, tne camera work and art direction, but that's about it. I quite like the Korean movie scene too but this movie felt very european in a way, like one of those clever french comedies like 'Tanguy' for example. But: I have seen so many better scripts, more absurd plots and more cruel (and better developed) twists in the last decades (yes I'm old) that I was bored to hell in this one.
What is so fucking special, Bong Joon-ho did here? Admittedly, the basic idea is a neat one, but it goes nowhere. The characters acted like geniuses and improvised the bejesus out of them when the story needed it most - only to act like complete idiots: when the story needed it most. The only thing I did know when the film started (because I couldn't move my eyes fast enough away from the brief description) was that there is a plot twist. I hoped this would do the trick. For me it didn't. So there was a man hiding in the secret cellar. Wow. When they fell down the stairs so the real dramatic turning point that Joon-ho needed could occur I suffered a major second hand embarresment attack. That felt so insanly cheap I almost stopped watching. After that: why go dramatic after all?? Why have people dying????!!!! it made no sense. It was such an obvious and 'crafted' surprise - like uuuuh, NOW everybody will be shocked - that I felt nothing but: C'MOOOONs over and over again. Have the story escalate? Yeah sure, it desperately needed escalation at that point (and maybe before)! But why had it to be stabbing and thumping?! Don't get me wrong, I like my good amount of violence in a movie, but this felt so forced.
I don't hate that movie. It's worse. It bored me. And that's something I can never forgive ;)
Anyways, Chris, I just subbed, because I think you have a very engaging way of talking about movies, where both head AND heart are involved - like it should be in my opinion. Great stuff! Rock on!
author: Miki Laggard

comment: I'm not saying everyone is like this (I know there are some) that won't watch films with subtitles because they're not used to it, but hear me out on this: If I can watch Seven Samurai in it's unbridled 3 & a half runtime with subtitles, you can definitely do the same with Parasite, a movie that's a fraction of the length of Seven Samurai.

author: HERO Mujahid

comment:
A story there was. Thrilling scenes there were. Some pretty cinematography yes. Solid character build-up, hell no. Logical plot, no. Entertainment, not much. Consistency of characters, missing. Petty resentful ignorance towards the rich, yes. Narrow and shallow depiction of the poor, very much.

So not convincing. Every stretch of the movie i thought I started understanding the characters a bit more, but no, next stretch would make me scratch that understanding and try to rebuild again.. In the end, it made me fail to attach with any of the characters.

Without enough entertainment, what were the film makers trying to tell the audience? I completely don't get it.

Really doesn't match the hype. Wasted two hours of my life.

comment: Connor Webb i was able to predict parasite from the trailer, i dont know if thats just a me thing, but it was terribly predictable, and the ending seemed thrown in there at the last second. Sure, the dad killing him cause he didnt like being called smelly could be symbolic, but you have to think about it in a realistic sense, and thats just way too unbelievable. I just think ford vs ferrari had a much better message and the fact it was a true story made it all the better. Joker, even though derivative, had its own spin being a comic book movie, i think it was told better than taxi driver and its acting is incredible. Parasite just fell flat, the whole time i was waiting for what ‚Äúyou wont be expecting‚Äù and it never came, i dont think it wins in a story sense because of that, the acting was good but because it doesnt beat Joaquin, and i laughed more times in joker than in parasite, i gues that comedy wasnt for me

comment: @Leroy I disagree. Joker is the everyday man's blend of Scorsese (Taxi Driver and King of Comedy) and Parasite (themes about class). Its the "everyday man's" because its a recognizable brand - DC. Ford v Ferrari was fun but it had little to offer. Bale and Damon's chemistry was good. The story was full of cheese. Leo Beebe had me rolling my eyes every time I saw him smile. Every thing the writers did to make him seem like an asshole just bored the hell out of me. I've seen that before. Tracy Letts played a cartoon. It was cookie cutter.

author: Sundeep Kumar

comment:
I analyzed the film. What you may have missed from the movie:

1. The most metaphorical scene is when they are splashing water to the crazy pissing guy. It summarizes the whole idea. CLUE: Water=Flood, Kims= Richer
Pissing guy= Poorer
And the dialog in that scene says a lot more about the film (rock foreshadowing, etc)

2. The arrangement of the poor family, everytime theyre eating is always the same, till second half comes. Order turned chaos.

3. Clothes are juxtaposed. Mrs Park's closet vs poor's second-hand relief clothes (scenes after flood).

4. Smell is a metaphor
author: Mayla Diosay

comment: I hate that I seem to be the only person that doesn't have a deep emotional connection with this movie.  I thought everything about it was just OK. The directing, acting, cinematography...I didn't think it was spectacular.  I was really let down, especially after I saw it after it won best picture at the Oscars.  I thought "how in the hell did it win over Jojo,  Joker, Once Upon a Time...In America, 1917?  There's no way it's better than those, right?"  And after seeing it, I STILL think those movies are better.  I think they have better themes, are directed better, are shot better, and have better acting.

author: OpenTheMind

comment:
I have seen Mother, Memories of Murder, Snow Piercer, and Host.

I was really looking forward to Parasite. To be frank, I was disappointed. Not that it is bad, but not good enough for me.
From the very start of the story, I found it not plausible, because we are introduced to a very poor family, and yet the son and daughter are exceptionally well informed about art, child psychology, education.
Maybe the South Korean low class schools are top notch?
Maybe it's a political statement: the poor are better educated than the rich, who are very gullible, ignorant, and unobservant.
I loved the scene where the poor mother swiftly pushes the maid down the stairs. But little else.
I have seen Mother and Memories of Murder twice. I doubt I will see Parasite again. I could not suspend my disbelief: If the son and daughter are so capable, why do they not have jobs?
And, the Basquiat-like painting by the rich kid. I just cannot believe a kid that age could produce something like that.
Plausibility comes first for me.
author: Frank Rizo

comment: I'm korean and I'll tell you some reasons why the scene made like that. Youth unemployment rate is the most critical issue in Korea compared to other country. Futher, poor family's son and daugther have not degree of major. Even though they have good ability,  there is no place to show it. Maybe director would've intend this problem. And personally, I think that the kid's works were not such a high level. In fact, trauma is related improving art potential skills.

comment: @Frank Rizo Okay, I'm done with my case then. You may have a nuance in understanding art. That's not bad. Critics won't support your views tho~ your plausibility logic is not good.
author: Mayla Diosay

comment:
@Mayla Diosay Yes. I missed all of that, but it does not make it a better story. A film is basically a story. If the story starts out with anomalies, elements that do not compute, from that moment on, I lose interest.
All of the artistic elements that you cite fail to redeem this film for me.
I found the lawn party sequence, the attacks, strangely choreographed. The reaction of the guests and the hosts seemed oddly unresponsive to the violence taking place before their eyes.
I have read about the many artistic graces on display, but they do overcome my disbelief.
author: Frank Rizo

comment:
What you may have missed from the movie:

1. The most metaphorical scene is when they are splashing water to the crazy pissing guy. It summarizes the whole idea. CLUE: Water=Flood, Kims= Richer
Pissing guy= Poorer
And the dialog in that scene says a lot more about the film (rock foreshadowing, etc)

2. The arrangement of the poor family, everytime theyre eating is always the same, till second half comes. Order turned chaos.

3. Clothes are juxtaposed. Mrs Park's closet vs poor's second-hand relief clothes (scenes after flood).

4. Smell is a metaphor
