author: NERDY FULLO

comment:
This movie is kind of a Parasite.

Here's a movie that should have been nominated and should have won the Oscar:

" The Laundromat "

It's a movie, which feels like a really likable informational video about insurance fraud and tricky money schemes... Lol... Antonio Banderas and Gary Oldman are just so much fun to watch!!! It's a delightful film! Based on a true story, as well, about the Panama Papers.

For me, this beats other movies nominated for movie awards. It's an artwork, turning a boring subject into pure fun, with a unique way to tell a story and make a point as well. The characters have their ups and downs, as well. It's a Steven Soderbergh project (I had thought he retired, so glad he didn't!) and his style lifts the story and turns it into an enjoyable ride that you want to be on.

Okay, I have nothing against "Parasite", but with all the English speaking great movies this year, why did this win so much at the Oscars? It had good directing, great acting, great score, interesting locations and good camera work -- but, I just didn't really believe the story that much. It seemed that the upper class folks were too naive, and the lower class folks were too lucky. Plus, what were the lower class family going to do once they were found out? After all, it was just a matter of time, right? The father of that family seemed to have a higher endurance, in my understanding of the character, but then he goes nuts because he finds out the upper class boss of his isn't fond of his 'smell'? Seriously? This just seems silly to me. I thought he was more humble, and with more grit than to let something like that bother him. Is it realistic that the upper class in South Korea don't check on anyone that they hire? Seems unrealistic to me. So, I really wanted the movie to succeed (for me) by having the characters strike a deal with each other, or reconcile and make an agreement of some kind that brings The 'human experience' to a higher level. But, instead, we got madness, chaos and murder. Wtf? I felt this was a complete cop-out. I'm guessing that this movie may have a more relevant sense to it, culturally, for those from South Korea or living there. Because it may be drawing from a reality, there, that could be worth evaluating more deeply. I thought this was an average movie, because of the story. 5 out of 10. Snowpiercer was more interesting, and better, from this Director.

comment:
This movie is well made, directed, acted and edited. I have an issue with the message or the morale, what is this movie trying to say? It seems like the message of this movie is not a good one. That's the part where it loses me. I wish it had been about reconciling with the mistakes the family had made, and finding a resolution, then gaining positive life experience from these mistakes, and making something good of themselves.

My rating: 5 out of 10.

Final thoughts: How did this winn an Oscar???? And for Best Picture??? Can't believe it.



**SPOILER ALERT**


Why did the cute daughter have to die? :-( And why did the father of the poor family have to kill the father of the household? He was trying to drive the car to the hospital to save the stabbed girl.
I don't see the point of these deaths. It's just haotic madness.

comment:
I'm baffled at the amount of positive reviews this movie gets. I thought it was mediocre at best.

While I understood the plot of the movie, I didn't get why it was titled as "Parasite". I mean, who is the parasite? Society teaches us that the rich are not, because they (the father in this case) work for a living. The poor can't be, since they work, too.

So either no one is a parasite or, if we accept the premise of the movie, that someone is a parasite, we must agree that everyone is a parasite. The poor family is parasitizing the rich family. The rich father has a business which may be a legal form of scam, parasitizing its (poor) customers. His wife is parasitizing him. Their children are parasitizing them.

Extrapolating, there is no such thing as a parasite in nature, because in the end, every being is a "parasite" on the back of other being(s) in one way or another. Life feeds on life. It's just the way it is...

Therefore, because the concept of parasitism is such an ambiguous one, I think it was a bad choice for the title of this otherwise pathetic excuse of a movie.

parasite:
- an organism which lives on the back of another organism of a different species;
- a person who exploits others and gives nothing in return.

Now the poor family may be labeled as malevolent cheaters, but cheater doesn't necessarily mean parasite.
author: State of Being

comment:
@Explicitghost Yeah... you didn't get my point.

Anyway, this movie is not a profound meditation on philosophical or social issues (though it pretends hardly to be that), so there is nothing "to read between the lines".

I've seen where the story would go after the first few scenes, so watching till the end was a grind more or less. Actually, to be honest, it exceeded my expectations in terms of how bad it was going to be. It is just a convoluted mess failing on so many levels, nothing more, though I understand why some people might mistake this for something that it is not. But a piece of crap is a piece of crap. Nothing more to say...
author: State of Being

comment:
You answered how they are parasites in your later paragraphs buy ill recap. The poor family relies on exploiting the rich family to earn a living, doing so by scamming them and ruining the other house workers lives to replace them with their own family. The Rich family relies on the poor family to do the most basic of tasks to keep the home a livable place. They cant cook, do the dishes, or wash their own laundry. So in a way both families are parasites to each other. the twist of the movie serves as a grim reminder that it isn't just poor vs rich, but also poor vs poor as they battle for the welfare of the rich family. Being a parasite in the term you use isn't as simple as working or not working. Being caught up on simple issues like that hasn't allowed you to "read in between the lines" during your viewing of the movie.

You should give it a rewatch with that explanation in mind. Personally I think the film is great with amazing acting, writing, cinematography, and meaning. But it isn't perfect, it relies on deus ex machinas to push to the story along a little to much. But 100% a recommendation to anyone I know.

author: rishabh sahoo

comment:
I'm Korean and one of the details most foreigners(and even Koreans) miss to mention is that those families were never like that poor/rich all the way through their life!

The rich family's dad is introduced in several details as he started from the bottom - and became an icon for it(The term Ja-Su-Seong-Ga is mentioned repeatedly+His company is an IT/Tech sort of company which makes it more believable). In the poor family's house, you can see several items/details where they were far more wealthier before(not super rich, but just better off in general) just that the poor family's father had a failed business that lead this family into this poverty. Thoses family members aren't incompetant at all. Dad has several great skillsets, mom was a national level athlete, sister is good at art, and the son is educated enough to teach the rich daughter.The sub-poor couple's husband even owned his own small business back in the day.

You act like you were born with the class, in reality, you're just stationed into a system. Capital hierarchy blinds you into believing the wealthy deserves of their own class while the poor believes the same, respectiong and admiring the upperclass. loads of casualty without any villans.
author: wishing9wonder

comment: ‚Äã@Peeps and MooMoo I felt bad for the Rich Dad too. He really didn't do anything wrong!

comment: Thanks for sharing this.

author: wishing9wonder

comment:
@Peeps and MooMoo I get the point you initially followed and yes the ending was intended to make you feel that way. It was never about anybody 'deserving' of anything. The intention of the director(as he famously admitted all the time)was this.

Most of the time bad things only happened to both the poors. They were conned, they lost their jobs, they lost their house, they lost their dignity, they lost the sense of existing as a human being and reduced down to their occupation and function. they were invisible to the rich. whenever they tried to connect with the rich(like asking if they loved there SO and asking for a handshake) the rich appeared as if they were offended even, as if they were crossing a line or something.

There is no justification for the killing. Heck even the poor dad felt guilty of his actions. the director wanted to point out that as long as this inhumane class hierarchy of welth exists, very very bad things will definately happen to anyone, even the rich. it's not a matter of right or wrong, or who deserves what, it will happen.

even tho they try so hard, the rich family is highly disfunctional without the poors labor. however they draw an imaginary line between them and the poor. you can hate the poor hold them accountable for their action. but no matter what, once in a while an end of a knife blade will definately be headed towards you if this class system exists. the director wanted the ones who justify and lives(wins) upon this system to acknowledge that it horrible things may happen to them.
author: wishing9wonder

comment: What bothers me about this movie is that the poor family cheats and lies to take advantage of the rich family. This is like saying that only the dishonest get ahead, and if you play by the rules, you will be left behind. Even the poorer family in the basement have more integrity. Although the poor family gets their comeuppance at the end, I still didn't like that they were portrayed as the "heroes."
author: David Gonzales

comment: Isn't that the truth about society though? The dishonest find a way to win while those who play by the rules get left behind. And I don't think they were ever portrayed as heroes. They are portrayed as frauds who take advantage of the gullibility of others, but are also sympathetic characters who need to to be clever and cunning because they need it to survive. Also it's not like they got a hero's ending either. If anything they kind of got what they deserved in the end.
author: freepeople091

comment: David Gonzales They really weren‚Äôt portrayed as ‚Äúheroes‚Äù at all and they even paid a price for it at the end. One of the things that I loved about this film is that all of the characters were flawed in their own ways. In a sense it really takes a good hard look at humanity and shows that in the end we‚Äôre all our own worst enemies in a class system that encourages us to succumb those terrible qualities within us to ‚Äúget ahead‚Äù.

comment: Bong Joon Ho's direction, storyline, cinematography, performances, and use of symbolism utterly blew my mind. My eyes were fixated on the screen and I was sitting on the edge of my seat in suspense for more than half the movie; the suspense was really engaging and enthralling. The touching and melancholy ending, the jaw-dropping scenes that startled, shocked, and surprised me and the effective use of symbolism are some of the attributes that classify Parasite as a truly essential movie. I definitely want to rewatch this. If you don't give this film a positive review, then you don't know true cinema.
author: Outstanding Screenplays

comment: This movie was Ok. I do not get the hysterical praise for it at all. I enjoyed it, it was entertaining, but to call it a ‚Äúmasterpiece‚Äù is way over the top. Why were we supposed to care for the poor family when all of them were shitty human beings? Are we supposed to view the rich family with contempt? If so, why? For committing the crime of being successful? The rich people didn‚Äôt murder anyone, nor did they happily fuck other people out of their livelihoods. Stick man said the poor family were pretty smart people, and I agree. So couldn‚Äôt they find a better way to get by without ruining the lives of others? The rich family did nothing to deserve what they got and neither did the driver and the housekeeper. It was a decent film with flaws. But a great film, a ‚Äúmasterpiece‚Äù? Fuck no?

comment: I just saw the movie and I agree that it's fantastic and one of the best of the year, but that's a really long list for 2019. I just thought the massive plotholes were the only things keeping it from being a true masterpiece. Why didn't he just say "hey my sister would be good for this?" why did he have to pretend he didn't know her? They didn't seem to have already formulated the entire plot of bringing them all in, and I don't recall them ever mentioning why he didn't want them to know they were related. Also the buttons that controlled the lights were pretty unbelievable. Like why would that have been built that way? That was a huge MacGuffin that I found distracting when it came up. Also nothing ever came of the young boy decoding the message, so that seemed pointless. But despite all of that it was a great film and the acting and cinematography were near perfect. It's a must-see for sure.

author: ddd

comment:
i didn't feel this movie was authentic. it's more like a movie was made to fit a particular social narrative, which actually hampers the authenticity of the story and the story feels forced. the poor family is extremely smart and skilled and it's unclear how they could be so poor with all that. .people who are smart and have little regard for ethics usually thrive in a market economy even if they start with less resources.




certain situations and scenes seems highly unlikely (father not getting caught or the bunker not being found after such a horrific crime, the father surviving in the basement for years without any external help, The family's extremely reckless behavior when the rich family goes out for just one night and equally reckless and stupid actions that makes them get caught to the previous house keeper, the son fully recovering - let alone surviving - two full blows to the head with a very heavy rock) and i feel these highly improbable situations are due to the film-maker trying to push the story to fit a particular social narrative. these are common in foreign movies that are made to a western market. i highly doubt the movie was equally well accepted by the S. Korean domestic audience.




the social critique too is ambiguous (if that was done purposely, it would be great, but i highly doubt it). for instance, i thought the person living in the bunker represented those who live from welfare. well is that a criticism of the welfare system? if it is, then maybe there's a point. but trying to justify the jealousy and anger of the poor family doesn't sit well. ultimately, a son saw his father getting killed in front of him and a wife lost her husband for the only reason that they were rich and successful and somehow that doesn't count? perhaps that guy worked his ass off to reach that position. resources don't just appear out of thin air. it's the same socialist destructive and negative mindset. it looks like the poor family is just in that situation cos they never took responsibility for their lives and in some situations it's even suggested. and it's actually the poor family that doesn't give a shit about the fellow man and undercut other poor people (like the former drive and the land lady, the boy even steals his friend's gf who helped him land a job). somehow the rich guys are assholes bcos the wife is naive and the husband doesn't like the driver poking on his private life and doesn't' like how he smells? common. all this is mixed up with a forced socialist message maybe to fit a western liberal audience so ultimately the social critique too loses its focus.




All in all, i think the film is overrated cos it tried to fit a particular social narrative and wasn't true to the story. it's a very common issue with modern movies. it's why even though these films are called 'masterpieces' they never reach the levels of classics like 'seven samarui' or '12 angry men' (or even 'Joker'). cos rather than staying too to the story and characters, movies like this try to fit a contemporary political ideology, which compromises the integrity story and character development.


i liked the movie was switching genres throughout . it is something that can become a new trend.

comment: When Chris STuckmann said, "movies like this make me want to direct" solidifies what I feel about this film. It's a film that appears to be deep and takes a certain level of intelligence to understand...so when one does pick up on the symbolism/metaphors in the film they feel like they are special for being in or the secret. But the thing is...sure it's layered....but very, very thinley veiled.  Super predictable film all the way through which completely ruined it for me. It's a feel good(for the viewer who pats themself on the back) black comedy.  Although I disagree with Chris on the humor part. Didn't laugh or giggle more than  couple times at most.

comment: Pretty late watcher but I just gotta say though I get the point of it, watching the characters spend 20 minutes trying to get out of their boss' house was not what I would call enjoyable. Also felt some foreshadowing was done too late into the movie (kinda of nitpicking), like the youngest son seing a ghost could've beem placed earlier into the story. Putting it after  they found out about the basement reduced the shock value. The movie had more potential to me, execution i think is more B+ to A- to be honest, I just can't see it as a perfect movie. Additionally, too many blunders from the family made the movie kind of lazy, didn't make sense why the whole family would follow the housekeeper down to the basement, or why would the mom threaten to call the police ( I mean her whole family is still there, it was not logical to call the cops at all). In the first place why would she let the housekeeper in? These plot points were lazy and made it less enjoyable.

comment: City of God is way better that this one. Parasites is a good movie, but is not that good in a lot of scenes. For example, uses a lot of cliches, like the typical scene of hiding under the table, or the uhhh surprise, now everyone decided to come downstairs. A lot of the decisions that the caracters make are just forced, including the ending. That is more typical of a comedy movie like American Pie. The main character, base in his personallity, would have never go down to the basement in the middle of a party, because during the movie the guy demostrate to be a masive planner, thinking out of everything, and then, he is doing that?. It is obvious that the writter was forcing the end there. You cannot see that in City of God, Seven, American Beauty, Good Will Hunting, etc. That is the biggest criticism that I have with the script, that forces situations abandoning the "how that character would act in that situation". That is the equivalent of making Saul Goodman fall into a silly and obvious hustle. just to provoke a fast end or a comic situation. I am still looking for an actual deep review of the script, but for now, I can only find simplistic not based in the details reviews.

comment:
I enjoy your movie reviews, and sometimes I decide to watch movies because of you. You made me watch this movie, and thank you for that. After watching this movie at the theater, I was not able to stop thinking the movie that day. I am not sure whether you gonna post a Parasite extended spoiler review or not, but I want to share how I felt about the movie. I am originally from South Korea, so I got used to both US and Korean cultures. My understanding of the movie could be different from you. There are so many things to talk, but I believe water, a stone (scholar's rock), and ghosts are important symbols.
1) Water: Have you taken a shower with cold water? You can try just 1 minute very cold shower, not warm& hot water. It initiates your fight or flight response and makes you discomfort. The drunk guy from the beginning of the movie got cold water to wake up. I think water reveals who they are here, and water naturally flows down because of gravity inevitably. The Kim's family's day-dream (to be rich) at the Park's house has ended with rain, and they confront a brutal reality. The Park's family reveal their disgust about the poor when raining
2) A stone (scholar's rock): I think the stone means superficial wealth or luxuries like a Gucci bag. There's no real use of the stone here, it is an object to show off. $3000 Gucci bag is useful or practical for a person who makes $3000 per month? probably not. In our daily life, media constantly tell you that you have to buy those items to look like a rich person. The media owned by rich people, tell you that the poor people are worthless, and the rich people should be respected. In the movie, the stone shows up when flooding, and it is like "id" (your primitive desire) emerges from "superego" (conscience, reality=water). The son in the movie can't hide his desire to be rich. His deep inside clings to the stone, thinks the poor is worthless even though he is one of the poor.
3) Ghosts (morse code): Funny that this reminds of Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon (one of the richest people in the world), have you heard that Amazon workers can't even go to bathroom often? Ms. Park says that you will be rich if you live in the house with ghosts (hard working class, the poor). The poor are like ghosts here. The rich don't want to believe the poor exist or don't want to see them, but the rich need the poor to support their luxury life style. The guy in the basement blindly respects Mr. Park even though Mr. Park doesn't even know the guy exists.


Anyway, this is just what I think after watching the movie. Again, thanks for your movie reviews.

comment:
Honestly deserves every lick of praise it gets. This movie has it all. Great concept. Unexpected but brilliantly handled twists and turns. Fresh ideas. Social commentary. Humour. Action. Horror. Drama. All amazingly well filmed, writen and acted.
If you don't enjoy this them you can give up on watching films.

The second half has to be one of the most expertly crafted hours of film I've ever seen. So much happens at such a pace and yet it all seems to unfold so natually. It's only when it's over you realise what a wild ride it was. The trailers are just the tip of the iceberg. The set up. Act 1. See this movie!!!

comment: a guy Where did I say that? Jeez, when did people become so dense? That is not the point at all. Forget the poverty or even the murders. It was obviously opportunistic and a shot at the impossible, that's what makes this story so appealing because it's a frightening truth and desire that resides within those who cannot have the life they so desperately wish they can have. Not even just being rich, but life is just becoming more and more expensive and impossible to even live comfortably. To live comfortably with economic stability is a pipe dream and it really suggests the corruption of our systems. Let's not forget the College Admissions Scandal. It's angering how our systems keep the rich that way while the lower class busts their asses off reaching a goal that is difficult achieve because they did not grow up economically endowed.

author: Ming Guevara

comment: A picture is worth a thousand words: blood splattered on cake. ‚ÄúLet them eat cake‚Äù was Marie Antoinette‚Äôs retort to the starving masses. The blood of common workers is on the cake - the bread of the aristocracy. Sugar plantations‚Äô slaves toil to produce the sweetness of pampered lives. The frontal head shot of indigenous features in full native head dress shows in the most subtle way how the rich have obtained advantage: the nonchalance of a violent genocide in a land grab. The seeming ease with which some come into wealth is depicted by just walking up, by avarice, or marrying up. At first glance, clothes and demeanor differentiates the rich from the poor. This determines who gets ‚ÄúRespect!‚Äù The poor are treated like vermin to be exterminated. Even the toilet is elevated above where the poor lives. Passerby routinely "piss on them.‚Äù The smell of poverty remains even as they pass for fitting in.

comment:
Just saw it and really liked it, however I found a plothole towards the end, so SPOILERS?

When Kevin was hit over the head with his own rock by the crazy basement guy he's lying right by the steps to the underground secret bunker area and the door is open. We also know the door stays open because his father goes through it afterwards on his escape after killing the rich dad and uses the handle to close it. So the plothole is: Kevin lies there unconcious, almost dead, and he is found by the daugther of the rich and family and she carries him upstairs where chaos ensues and runs away with Kevin on her back. We see this too. But she never noticed the open door to the hidden basement area that was in her house all along and that she didn't know about and wondered wtf it was? I know she wouldn't think about it in the moment because of panic, but afterwards she would have told the police about it if she did notice. And we know that she never told the police because the dad of the poor family hid down there and they were never able to find him. Meaning that the police at the end still doesn't know about the hidden bunker area. Thoughts?

comment: A very good movie. Bong Joon catches the pulse of the viewer again, literally. An A. Parasite masterfully explores the class divide in the trademark style of the director. As Joon does so well, narrative builds with full of entertaining and audacious if not disturbing sequences enhancing the mystery and suspense of the plot in the process. The best thing about Joon is that his style is the same. An entertaining presentation of  unique stories which compel the viewer to think. The only complaint I have is that the heroines or actresses in Korean films are so feminine and dainty. Get more natural looking actors in female leads.

comment: I think perhaps (western) people who are watching this movie who don't know anything about Korean culture, watch a lot of Korean dramas or shows be disadvantaged at getting references will miss is that the show is unmistakably Korean through and through. The faking culture, faking schooling, lying, flexing (rich) culture, stereotypical perceptions that Koreans have, like of foreigners, americans, American "indians". The poor family is poor, you can tell, the main son uses I think an Lg g3 or g4? Pretty old phone in 2018/19. Which wouldn't feel right to be an LG ad promoting such an old phone so it more of a plot device rather than coincidental ad. The other family clearly has an iphone x since they are rich. The guy also uses cheap chinese binoculars towards the end, I know since have the same probably $10 binocular, showing that he's poor.  I could go on and on.

author: PrinceChamp Camp

comment:
Some things I noticed/learned about the move. Spoiler alert






First:
Someone commented how unrealistic that the rich family never noticed the sliding door (with metal track on floor visible) that reveals the path down.


And the rich couple don't notice the people hiding under the table.


The rich couple don't notice things under them, because they don't look down. Consciously and unconsciously, they don't look down. They don't want to see/know/interact with what's under them, because it makes them uncomfortable, vulnerable, etc. That's a line the rich couple don't want to cross down.


But the poor are always looking up. The poor family looking out the widow from the semibasement home. Looking up the steep path/stairs going up as they head to the rich family's home.



Second:
Also, the large window in the rich family's living room has the ratio of 21:9. When the rich look out from the living room, what they want to see OR inevitably see is entertainment. Like seen through a wide aspect screen.




So many layers and layers of meanings in all the scenes.

author: Sean Nissen

comment:
Spoilers ahead



1) GEUN-SAE sends an S.O.S. message in morse code. DA-SONG sees it from his tent in the garden and writes it down... but that never comes into play. What was the point?
2) KI-TAEK stabs MR. PARK because he covered his nose. Before, KI-TAEK noticed the PARKS reacting that way to him. Like there was a "poor people" smell. They're both fathers who have to help their children, yet MR. PARK still thinks something as shallow as the smell is something to be concerned about during an emergency. Also, early on, DA-SONG was sniffing the KIMS and said "They have the same smell." The KIMS took him as him noticing that they eat the same food or that they use the same detergent. However, in retrospective, it could be a hint that DA-SONG is somehow learning from his parents to tell rich and poor people apart. Is my interpretation correct?

comment: - Parasite - par¬∑a¬∑site - /Ààper…ôÀåsƒ´t/ - noun: parasite; plural noun: parasites - 1. an organism that lives in or on an organism of another species (its host) and benefits by deriving nutrients at the other's expense. - "the parasite attaches itself to the mouths of fishes" - 2. Derogatory - a person who habitually relies on or exploits others and gives nothing in return. - "the capitalist is really a parasite on the workers" - Similar: hanger-on - cadger - leech - passenger - drone - bloodsucker -

comment:
you would think after all the perfect reviews this film has been getting since cannes that somehow maybe it's a little bit overhyped but what you don't realize after you see it that all this praise won't give this gem of a movie its rightful due, this's simply the best film i've seen since 2014 & top 5 of the decade.

comment:
Just saw it. I was really looking forward to this but ended up a little disappointed with it.
Without giving away too many spoilers, I‚Äôll just say everything involving the basement just took me out of the story. Started to feel unrealistic.
I think it‚Äôs partly because the initial setup is already stretching realism slightly but walking the tightrope just right and is really entertaining. Then they throw in that twist that tips it to the side. Characters make decisions that they should realize won‚Äôt better their position. Also, there started to be a lot of exposition at this point.
If I were to grade it, I‚Äôd give it a B+. Still a great movie, just not as much as I expected. Definitely got me thinking.
Maybe I‚Äôll like it more if I see it again.

author: Alrus Joseph B. De la Calzada

comment:
I didn't know what to expect from this movie. The trailer told me just enough to draw interest without giving too much (if anything) away. I couldn't even get a read on what genre or genres it might fall into.

With almost every line, I was more intrigued at the plot, invested in the cast, engrossed in the world, and impacted by the atmosphere. The pacing felt perfect from scene to scene, minute to minute.

Not one character felt unnecessary, and I never felt like I was being hand-held through anything such as with exposition. As the story & tone shifted, my enjoyment went from laughing to being disturbed.

My first thought was "WTF? Is this actually a horror/thriller? A dark satire? A black comedy? What's going on here?" I can't explain it without spoilers, but compare it to Doki Doki Literature Club's twist.

My reaction was very similar (albeit, more sudden) the first time I went through that game. Anybody who's played knows exactly what I'm talking about and remembers how THAT scene affected them.

Everything takes a tonal 180 and only escalates from there. Parasite's twist wasn't as immediate or in-your-face, but definitely every bit as surprising in the best way. It's an absolute masterpiece imo.

author: Alucard ReavaN

comment:
The meaning of parasite(Both the rich and the poor are parasites!!)
- There are two meanings
1) infiltrate : the poor(Gitak's family and the basement family) infiltrate their money and place. And also the rich(Park's family) also infiltrate the poor and suck up their labors.
2) aversion(abhorrence): We generally abhor the parasite. If the rich and the poor don't respect each other, there are possibility for them to abhor each other because of various reasons. The limitation of Capitalism is that the gap between the rich and the poor is widening. The poor's deprivation and the rich's ignorance toward the poor can come into "conflict".
It means that the rich regard the poor as parasites and vice versa.
These days, One's effort can not lessen the gap between the rich and the poor. But it is possible the rich to harmonize with the poor and vice versa.
If the rich only think that there is a invisible line, the conflict can not be solved.
is it possible the rich and the poor become real friends at each other? How about trying to understand each other, and how about giving consideration and respect toward each other?
Then our world - The world of capitalism - can coexist between the two, and we should try not to make a world where the rich and the poor abhor each other.
In other words, Don't regard each other as a Parasite!! It only accelerates the demerit of Capitalism.


This is why the title of this film is parasite.

author: MonsieurMaskedMan

comment:
I've known NOTHING about this, other than "It's Horror" and "It's Asian", and that alone, is good enough for one of my friends, who is REALLY into this stuff, and says that, if you only watch 80's slasher flicks, you're not ready for something like, say, Martyrs (sp?). I've heard of Martyrs, from this friend, and I get that Japanese horror flicks are not for the casual western viewer, who only knows Freddy, Jason, Pennywise, the Xenomorph, the Terminator, the Predator, etc. It's a big leap from the 80's action/horror cliches, to the whole world of Japanese horror, especially the less commercial stuff. And I totally get the fear of jumping from "Generic 80's blockbuster horror" to "Japanese stuff you definitely haven't heard of before, trust me, it's sick" (and that Joss Whedon had some stuff from The Ring and some of that Eastern Horror featured in Cabin In The Woods, as just a taste of what "Eastern Horror" has in store". I haven't really seen anything in that Eastern Horror section. But. If I were to find myself wanting more, I think something like Parasite, from what I have heard, it does sound like a good "gateway drug" into this area in horror movies.


And reviewers, critics, and the like, who I already subscribe to, saying that this is GOOD, is definitely something to take seriously. I have seen that, from just a "brief glance", critics saying "Parasite is a good, Asian horror movie" around the board, is enough to get my attention.


Maybe I'll see it, when I think I'm brave enough. Horror movies aren't my first choice. I'm more "Epic, badass, sci-fi/fantasy" or "real, poignant drama" as a viewer, than I am a "I wanna get my kicks on horror flicks" kind of viewer. I've never really loved horror movies. Some are awful, some are too much to deal with, I could really use a guide, etc etc. But I do hear that Parasite is good, from multiple voices around me (wow, that could be interpreted wrong!) so I may check this out. Soon. If the thing-that-is-the-monster doesn't get me first, that is.

comment: I usually get skeptical when a movie wins the Palme d'Our. Sometimes there's really good movies that win the award and sometimes there are movies that are... well, at least not for me. But I recently watched Parasite and I think it's one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. This might be one of my all-time favorite foreign movies. I think this is the kind of movie that critics and regular moviegoers can love because it's not too artsy and ambiguous for the regular moviegoer and it's not too "mainstream" for critics and deals with themes that a lot of people can identify with. Even though Endgame might be my favorite from this year, this is a very close second. I seriously think this is one of the best movies I've seen in the past at least five years.

comment: Saw this film days ago and I echo every sentiment. I fucking loved everything about it. I tend to understand how some people might find even excellent films kinda boring because there's some truth to it where even high art films don't always aim to entertain the average viewer because it requires more investment and it prioritizes delivering a message or a unique experience more than it does to just entertain. But I honestly cannot imagine anyone finding this boring even if it is up there in excellence because it's made in a way where it's able to cater even to the most casual of tastes given its really entertaining nature and inviting cinematography. The dialogue doesn't go out of its way to be vague and complicated. Everything they say in here is exactly what a regular person would say but used in ways that serve the scenes extremely well. Man, I could talk about this film all day but this review nails the best parts of it well. Everyone must watch this film.

author: Alexander Feustel

comment:
docsamson198 I agree. I didn‚Äôt know what to expect as I didn‚Äôt see any trailers or read reviews. I just kept seeing so much praised heaped on it so I had some free time and went to the cinema down the street. I was totally expecting a serious drama about a lower class family and their struggles. I was not expecting such a lighthearted, smart, and funny film. The pacing of the film zips by for the first half. There‚Äôs so much to love about how the story plays out that when the reveal happens that introduces the next story arc, I was completely surprised by it.

It still managed to be funny, but with darker undertones, and it gradually became a tragedy only to shift into another stylistic tone. And it executed it so well without it seeming forced or gimmicky. I think this merging of tones is a welcomed surprise for western audiences who may normally think of foreign films as high brow, intellectually stimulating but otherwise boring movies. This felt modern, quick, smart, clever, and it pulls off something very tricky‚Äînot taking itself so seriously but also not being frivolous and empty. I think it truly rewards the viewer and shows how filmmakers can tell engaging, sharp stories in new ways that still feel somewhat grounded in the familiar. Very enjoyable film. One I‚Äôd like to see again.

comment:
@MeghanMisaLIAR "But its still better than Socialism and/or Communism" - but IS it? ACTUAL socialism (not this USSR crap we saw decades ago) requires the PEOPLE (democratically) control society and industry, not some supreme leader like Stalin or Mao.....in reality, the closest we've seen to actual socialism are the 'social democracies' (like Sweden, Norway, etc) and their strong social programs make for the best living standards in the world.

Wisdom and logic dictates, it's better we work together towards our common goal, rather than work against and exploit one another (this is undeniably true).
author: RP Williams

comment: @RP Williams Capitalism isn't perfect. But its still better than Socialism and/or Communism.
author: MeghanMisaLIAR

comment: @MeghanMisaLIAR   "I'm talking about the folks who start out with zero" - and a lot of them die with zero (though they work 50-60 hours a week, only earning enough to break even week after week, year after year). Plus where is this notion that one man is somehow capable of doing the work of 5 or 100 or 10,000 men, which is completely impossible (yet capitalism allows people to be paid in this way, as though they somehow did this impossible amount of work)? It's not at all a fair or just system, which was a big part of the message of this film. It's better than it's predecessor, feudalism, i suppose....but humanity is capable of a MUCH better and fair system (an actual meritocracy).
author: RP Williams

comment: @RP Williams well yes that's true. I'm talking about the folks who start out with zero.
author: MeghanMisaLIAR

comment: @MeghanMisaLIAR    "The amount of wealth you can attain is in direct correlation to how hard you work" - ?????? Are you fricking joking? A rich kid doesn't have to work a day in his life (daddy's investments will do all the earning he needs)....and don't get me started on people who have to work 3 jobs just to feed their families (while their corporate employer makes more in 4 hours than they make all year). And how about all those sweatshop kids overseas, think they love capitalism? What planet are you living on?

A French woman recommended it to me after seeing it at Cannes and I was pumped to see it, but I'll have to watch it at least once more, because honestly I don't think I "got it".
I mean understood what was happening, and I understood some of the ideas (e.g. the poor family living literally lower than the wealthy family) but I just didn't see much 'more'... it's hard to describe, it kind of felt like a social statement but I'm not sure it felt like a full movie.
And for me that's embarrassing to say because I know that this film is extremey well regarded.

comment: I think a big part of why I didn‚Äôt like Joker as much as the rest of the audience was that I watched Parasite way ahead of it. It was released early in my country, and I was completely blown away by what it had to say about society, social inequality, and class. So when I watched Joker, and then the same themes were brought up but in the most blunt and obvious way possible, it just felt flat and pretentious in comparison.

author: Muhammad Ali Khan

comment: I haven't seen Lighthouse yet, so I cannot comment on that. This year, I was waiting for parasite to be released as soon as I heard that Bong Joon Ho was directing it. I had humongous expectation. I watched movies like Us, Joker, endgame, Midsomer.., but something was missing in all these movies, even though they all are really good movies. But, Parasite completed my cinema viewing experience this year. On the first viewing, without having any knowledge about the movie, I was blown away. Like if you have big expectation, even though the movie is good, it can bring down your experience with the movie. But its not that case here.  It is undoubtedly the best movie this year. On the second viewing, I can safely say that this is a masterpiece. The story, direction, acting, cinematography, everything is great. Every dialogue, every scene, every object in the movie is meaningful in its own way. I highly recommend people to watch this movie.

NO NO NO NO NO NO!!
*off my caps lock*
Chris. I've been following your channel and your reviews. Totally love your work. But you cant give this movie an A+! The ending was a tad weak compared to 85% of the movie.

I know you're doing a spoiler free review. maybe do a special edition for this movie like "alternate endings".

I went and watch this movie with 2 other friends of mine. And we all agree on one thing. The set up was fantastic, the plot is brilliant. Script etc. But the ending or the plot twist, wasnt strong enough. Don't you think the movie should have worked more buffing a background for the Rich family and include them in some sort of twisted plot twist in the end.

I myself could come out with several different-much better endings in mind.

comment: Hmmm. I'm slightly torn. I really enjoyed the film, but that mostly hinged on how the ending tied everything together. Everything that preceded it was an extremely well made suspenseful black comedy, but it felt slightly Coen Bros or Hitchcock lite at times. But that ending, without spoiling the film, was incredibly heartwarming when you consider everything that preceded it. It also had a good message that didn't feel cheap. I felt it had a better ending than Snowpiercer, and that's why it's the better film to me. All of his films are great, though. Not one misstep in the bunch (I haven't seen Barking Dogs yet).

author: Breaker Nerd

comment: I had a hard time getting super invested in this film because I didn't like any of the characters. I felt like they were all kind of shitty people doing heartless things and I didn't care what happened to any of them. So I found myself feeling something I almost ever feel during movies: boredom. Also I felt this movie lived between reality and fantasy in a way where it didn't really take advantage of either the emotion of relatability or the visceral experience of the fantastic. This movie moved past believability for me but didn't ever seen to take advantage of the strange reality it created. I will agree it was immaculately crafted, but I felt it was a bit sterile and forgettable. My grade: B

comment: From your description I automatically dislike this movie. All this Marxist crap of class struggle bores me to no end. What if the rich family loves rainstorms? I love rainstorms, even when my ceiling is leaking and I'm losing bits and pieces of my walls. I adore snow, even when I'm really sorry for people who don't have ways to keep warm during winter. This whole opposition between rich and poor is tedious and fake and more than outdated. In the end, it's the old adage of "Rich... bad... Poor... good".

comment: It is not that flawless because you do need to suspend disbelief that a poor family whose members can't find work can be that cunning to dupe a rich family.  They could have used their street smarts to find jobs or at least do several scams as a family.  If not for that friend who refers the tutor to this rich family, the poor family can't have gotten a foot in the door. That is my issue with the movie and since I am very familiar with Asian cinema as an Asian.  However, I am glad that Westerners are now enjoying the Asian flourish when it comes to cinema.  There are many brilliant East Asian movies and TV series as well as some Bollywood if Westerners can stomach some Indian dancing with is part of Bollywood :)

comment: I have been waiting for your review for the last 4 month ( we Asia get to view this film early). I have to say this is one of the most perfect film of the year not just the movie  as a whole but the message behind it is also very deep and you can see throughout the visual especially how many time that stairs is being used in this movie. It not just how their world is different but It representing how opposite this rich and poor like when you keep moving up the life and atmosphere become clearer and  more cheerful, and turn darker and hard to live the more you go down (Hence the toilet is the most highest place in the poor family house). And the term Parasite according to me is not just mean for the poor family but also the rich one and all the people in this movie. Hope that we will get a spoiler review about this movie there so much to talk about Chris!

comment:
‚ÄúMovies are back!‚Äù 2 A+ within a week?!

I have to say the backend of this year has had some pretty great films. First half of 2019 was weak, and I felt 2018 was weak personally.

2017 was it for me. Logan. Baby Driver. Blade Runner 2049. Guardians of the Galaxy 2. Thor Ragnarok. Kong Skull Island. It. Alien Covenant. Wind River. Hostiles. Spider-Man Homecoming. Kingsman 2. War for the Planet of the Apes. Dunkirk. Wonder Woman. Get Out. John Wick 2. Three Billboards. King Arthur. Shot Caller. American Made. Logan Lucky. A Monster Calls. Lost City of Z. Mother. Brawl in Cell Block 99.

So many more, a lot of other great indie films and lower profile ones too, those are just the big ones that come to mind. A year of great variety!

So it is good to have some good movies for the first time in a while! Great review as always Chris :)

comment: @Fathel That is your opinion. Here's mine: As much as I appreciate Roma's phenomenal accomplishments visually talking, Roma's actual story and story just feels more like a set up for the visuals rather than the core of the film. It does have some good moments in it, but at times the story itself doesn't overcome the limitations it has imposed. Whereas Parasite is brilliantly flawless in every single aspect. Don't get me wrong, I like Roma quite a bit (and it definitely should have won Best Picture instead of Green Book), I just think Parasite is a slightly more complete experience.

author: lai chi long

comment:
Stunning movie in terms of the cinematography. The story was more grounded than I expected to be and I was pleased it didn't delve into the surreal or supernatural. The visual storytelling is simply outstanding and in a league of its own. The themes of the film also translate extremely well, so Western audiences should absolutely be able to identify or empathize with the characters and events.

Tremendous film. Great building of tension throughout and sublime camera work. Go see it on the biggest screen you can.
